title: Estados Unidos bloqueó a tres bancos mexicanos a los cuales acusó de "lavado de dinero" para cárteles de la droga
content: Las entidades involucradas son CIBanco, Intercam y Vector a las que se le prohibió realizar "algunas transferencias de fondos".
resumen:
Estados Unidos bloqueó a tres bancos mexicanos a los cuales acusó de "lavado de dinero" para cárteles de la droga.
Las entidades involucradas son CIBanco, Intercam y Vector a las que se le prohibió realizar "algunas transferencias de fondos".
El Gobierno de Estados Unidos, en cabeza del presidente republicano Donald Trump, bloqueó a tres bancos mexicanos a los cuales acusó de "lavado de dinero" para cárteles de la droga.
El Departamento del Tesoro en un comunicado, la Red de Control de Delitos Financieros (FinCen) llevó a cabo una investigación que concluyó que dichas instituciones estarían implicadas en lavado de dinero de la droga.
Washington los acusa de haber desempeñado un papel "vital en el lavado de millones de dólares en nombre de los cárteles con sede en México y en la facilitación de pagos para la adquisición de productos químicos" necesarios para producir fentanilo.
Trump, quien asumió su segunda administración no consecutiva en enero de 2025, ha convertido la lucha contra el fentanilo en una de sus prioridades y acusa a México de no hacer lo suficiente para combatirlo, lo que acarreó al vecino país la imposición de aranceles.
Los cárteles del narcotráfico de México fabrican ilegalmente dicho opioide sintético con sustancias procedentes de China, y afectaron a su país con casi 50.000 muertes por sobredosis en 2024.
La secretaría de Hacienda de México se quejó de que el Departamento del Tesoro no ha aportado pruebas sobre el caso.
En rueda de prensa, el subsecretario del Tesoro de EE. UU., Michael Faulkender, expuso algunos ejemplos de "cómo estas instituciones con sede en México colaboran con los cárteles para blanquear dinero".
En 2023, un empleado de CIBanco facilitó a sabiendas la creación de una cuenta para supuestamente blanquear 10 millones de dólares en nombre de un miembro del cártel del Golfo.
A finales de 2022 "ejecutivos de Intercam se reunieron directamente" con presuntos miembros de la misma organización delictiva "para discutir esquemas de lavado de dinero, incluida la transferencia de fondos desde China".

title: Sura Investments: “Hay riesgos importantes pero el dólar sigue siendo una moneda de refugio”
content: César Cuervo, CIO de Sura Investments, analiza los efectos de estos días de agitación en los mercados, así como los principales desafíos que quedan en el año para el mundo y también para el Perú.
resumen:
César Cuervo, CIO de Sura Investments, analiza los efectos de las tensiones globales y políticas arancelarias en el mercado de capitales, así como sus proyecciones para el dólar y el oro como activos refugio.

El impacto de las tensiones globales y políticas arancelarias se ha enfocado en un aumento en la percepción y en el riesgo efectivo medido como la volatilidad de los precios, que se ha incrementado en la renta variable, los ‘commodities’ y las monedas.

Sura Investments mantiene una visión estructural, pero opera con cautela, prefiriendo la renta variable sobre la renta fija y la duración en activos locales como México y Perú, pero en magnitudes más pequeñas.

El 9 de julio vence la pausa de la política arancelaria de Estados Unidos, lo que genera incertidumbre.

En Perú, Sura Investments enfatiza la importancia de tener portafolios diversificados, con posiciones en soles y dólares, acciones y bonos, y una participación en alternativos.

La renta variable ha tenido una fluctuación agresiva, mientras que las monedas latinoamericanas no han tenido repuntes excesivos en volatilidad, pero la deuda ha tenido un incremento inusual de volatilidad.

Sura Investments considera que el dólar se mantendrá como activo de refugio, a pesar de los riesgos asociados con el balance fiscal en Estados Unidos, y prevé una relativa estabilidad en el dólar con el balance de riesgos más sesgado hacia una depreciación.

El oro puede ser un diversificador importante y un resguardo de valor, y Sura Investments no ve una diferencia importante en el precio del oro.

No se prevé una recesión inminente en Estados Unidos, pero hay desaceleración en la actividad.

En Perú, se observa incertidumbre electoral y disputas entre el Ejecutivo y el Legislativo, y se espera un impacto importante en el desempeño de los actores peruanos por el posible octavo retiro de las AFP.

El octavo retiro de las AFP tiene consecuencias de corto plazo en el mercado de capitales y en el crecimiento económico, y consecuencias estructurales en la pérdida de acumulación del sistema pensional y la menor profundización en el mercado de capitales.

China enfrenta retos internos y un encarecimiento de sus productos, lo que impacta su crecimiento y debilita su posición geopolítica.

title: "Les haremos pagar": Trump amenaza a España por negativa a gastar 5% de su PIB en defensa
content: Pese a los comentarios de su homólogo, el presidente del gobierno español, Pedro Sánchez, reafirmó que su país limitará sus gastos militares anuales al 2,1% del PIB.
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, amenazó con represalias comerciales a España por negarse a aumentar su gasto en defensa hasta el 5% de su producto interior bruto (PIB), uniéndose al compromiso pactado por los países de la OTAN. Los 32 miembros de la alianza atlántica acordaron alcanzar para 2035 ese nivel (un 3,5% para defensa básica, más un 1,5% en gasto militar adicional) durante la cumbre celebrada el martes y el miércoles en La Haya, Países Bajos. El presidente del gobierno español, Pedro Sánchez, firmó la declaración, pero aseguró que su país solo alcanzará el 2,1% del PIB en gasto defensivo al supuestamente haber obtenido un aval de la alianza atlántica. Trump, en su rueda de prensa del miércoles, respondió a Sánchez: "Pagarán más". Aseguró que Estados Unidos buscará una compensación por lo que considera una falta de compromiso de España con la OTAN. Trump acudió a la cumbre de la OTAN con su canciller, Marco Rubio, y el secretario de Defensa, Pete Hegseth. Trump proclamó: "Estamos negociando un acuerdo comercial con España. Les vamos a hacer pagar el doble. Y lo digo en serio". Agregó: "Voy a negociar directamente con España. Lo voy a hacer yo mismo (…) Pagarán más así". Pedro Sánchez reafirmó que su país limitará sus gastos militares anuales al 2,1% del PIB. Sánchez dijo: "El Ministerio de Defensa nos dice que las capacidades acordadas con la OTAN representan un 2,1% de nuestro PIB, y es lo que vamos a hacer". De acuerdo con Sánchez, "ese compromiso es absolutamente compatible con el compromiso de sostener y fortalecer el Estado de bienestar en España". Pedro Sánchez aseguró haber conseguido un aval de la OTAN para satisfacer "en tiempo y forma" sus compromisos con las capacidades militares de la alianza, gastando solo un 2,1% de su PIB. Argumentó que esa es la cifra que aconsejan los técnicos de Defensa para que España alcance la aportación técnica requerida. El secretario general de la OTAN, Mark Rutte, respondió que el aporte español "tiene que ser el 3,5 % como para todos los otros aliados". Trump consideró que "es terrible lo que ha hecho España". Afirmó que la economía española va muy bien, "por lo que no sé cuál es el problema". Alegó que los españoles "son gente estupenda", pero es el único país que se niega a pagar, por lo que acusó a su gobierno de querer "que les salga gratis" el refuerzo del paraguas de seguridad de la alianza. Sentenció que la postura de España es "injusta con la OTAN". El presidente de Estados Unidos aseguró que el acuerdo para aumentar el gasto defensivo sellado este miércoles se conocerá como el "Compromiso de Defensa de La Haya". Trump se atribuyó el mérito del nuevo acuerdo al afirmar que el gasto de defensa en la OTAN ha aumentado en $700.000 millones desde que comenzó a exigir más aportaciones de los otros miembros en 2017. Pronosticó que cuando los 32 países de la alianza alcancen el objetivo de gasto en defensa del 5% de su PIB, se agregará más de un billón de dólares al año a la defensa común.

title: Tormentas sobre la democracia
content: Hasta ahora todo parecía sencillo. En una democracia, el poder se ejercía dentro de los límites claros de una constitución y de lo que se conoce como Estado de derecho. La política obedece a reglas re ...
resumen:
En una democracia, el poder se ejercía dentro de los límites de una constitución y del Estado de derecho. La política obedecía a reglas claras, respetadas por la mayoría y la minoría. Se ofrecía a los votantes la posibilidad de elegir entre la derecha y la izquierda, y los partidos se alternaban en el poder. Los gobiernos democráticos cumplían las normas, respetando los derechos de la minoría.

Esa época está siendo destrozada por el populismo y el tecnocesarismo.

El populismo se manifiesta en Varsovia, donde los polacos eligieron a un presidente cuyo programa es vago, pero cuyas pasiones son claras: defender la identidad polaca, imponer los valores de la Iglesia Católica, resistir a la inmigración y ceder ante Rusia. El populismo siempre está en contra, pero no está claro para qué. El populismo conduce a corto o largo plazo a la violencia.

El tecnocesarismo está encarnado por Elon Musk y otros oligarcas o superricos. Disponen de un peso financiero equivalente o superior al de los gobiernos. Dominan herramientas técnicas y quieren ejercer el poder político. Se definen como libertarios, amantes de una sociedad anárquica.

Atrapada entre el populismo y el tecnocesarismo, la democracia liberal ya no parece ser un modelo universal. Estados Unidos no considera que esta democracia deba ser apoyada frente a cualquier forma de dictadura.

La ley ya no se aplica a todos, lo que permite la depredación, el pillaje, la corrupción y la guerra en Ucrania, Gaza, Sudán, Congo, Libia y Siria.

La ONU no tiene influencia en los conflictos.

La solución liberal sigue siendo la menos mala para garantizar el derecho a buscar la felicidad. Las reglas del juego de la sociedad liberal, es decir, el respeto de los derechos de las personas y el deber de resistir, siguen siendo insuperables en legitimidad y universalidad.

title: Sánchez, el cisma del 5% y el cabreo de Trump con España, las claves de una cumbre histórica para la OTAN
content: Nuestro “vecino” se marchó primero y, tras la despedida de rigor y cuando ya había empezado a marcharse, se giró y nos dijo con cierto gesto burlón: “Suerte con España”.Para mí quizás sea es ...
resumen:
En la cumbre de la OTAN en La Haya, se destacaron las siguientes claves:

*   España fue el único país en manifestar su rechazo a invertir el 5% del PIB en defensa, aunque firmó la declaración final que fija dicho porcentaje para todos los países.
*   El presidente español, Pedro Sánchez, negó que vaya a cumplir lo firmado.
*   Donald Trump, presidente de Estados Unidos, expresó su enfado con España y amenazó con una subida arancelaria si no se cumple lo pactado.
*   Europa y Canadá acordaron un aumento drástico de su gasto en defensa.
*   Trump no escondió su irritación con España por limitar sus gastos militares al 2,1% del PIB.
*   El ministro español de Economía, Carlos Cuerpo, eludió comentar las amenazas de Trump.
*   Sánchez aseguró que su Gobierno se mantiene firme en no pasar del 2,1% y responsabilizó a las Fuerzas Armadas de cumplir los objetivos con ese porcentaje.
*   Sánchez presentó un perfil bajo en la cumbre, no conversó con otros líderes mundiales ni saludó a Trump, y recibió críticas veladas.
*   El acuerdo del 5% no incluye una cláusula de excepción, según Rutte.
*   Sánchez podría estar tratando de ganar tiempo para no perder el apoyo de Sumar y consolidar su mayoría parlamentaria.
*   La declaración final de la cumbre se centra en la subida del 5%, su distribución, la industria de defensa y la situación de Ucrania.
*   Washington aportó el 62% del presupuesto total de defensa de la OTAN el año pasado.
*   La cumbre se organizó para agradar a Trump, con un formato reducido y elogios al mandatario estadounidense.
*   El secretario general de la Alianza Atlántica se refirió a Trump como "papito".
*   La declaración final menciona la "amenaza a largo plazo planteada por Rusia a la seguridad euroatlántica y la amenaza persistente del terrorismo" y reafirma el apoyo a Ucrania.

title: Las empresas agroalimentarias mantienen la preocupación por las amenazas de Trump a España
content: Las empresas agroalimentarias mantienen la preocupación por la nueva amenaza de aranceles del presidente de Estados Unidos (EE.UU.), en esta ocasión solo a España; para el sector del aceite, uno de lo ...
resumen:
Las empresas agroalimentarias mantienen la preocupación por la nueva amenaza de aranceles del presidente de Estados Unidos (EE.UU.), en esta ocasión solo a España; para el sector del aceite, uno de los principales afectados es "grave", mientras el vino y la carne ponen la vista en las negociaciones.

El presidente de la sección de aceite de Cooperativas Agroalimentarias, Rafael Sánchez de Puerta, ha mostrado preocupación por las amenazas contra España del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump: "Nos parece tremendamente grave (...) Nos da pánico y desde luego (si se cumple) nos saca completamente del mercado.".

Sánchez de Puerta ha señalado que el sector "ha aprendido" por conflictos anteriores, como el litigio con EEUU por las ayudas Boeing-Airbus o por la situación actual de la aceituna de mesa en el mercado norteamericano, que hay posibilidad de poner aranceles diferentes a los países comunitarios aunque estén dentro de la UE.

El director general de la Asociación Nacional de Industrias de la Carne de España (Anice), Giuseppe Aloisio, ha abogado por "bajar un poco el tono y el volumen" de las declaraciones, que son "parte de la estrategia de comunicación de Trump", por lo que habrá que ver en qué terminan.

Ha añadido que ahora mismo hay encima de la mesa una negociación entre la UE y EEUU, por lo que una directa entre el país norteamericano y España sería "una anomalía y una novedad".

Si se consumara la amenaza sería una "mala noticia" para todo el sector agroalimentario español y, en el caso del segmento cárnico, podría en juego más de 100 millones de euros en exportaciones españolas, que se verían encarecidas por gravámenes arancelarios no previstos.

Para la Inteprofesional del Vino de España, aún es "pronto" para hacer valoraciones, por lo que el sector vinícola español se ha posicionado "al margen" de cualquier "controversia" política y ha mostrado su compromiso con "la colaboración, el diálogo y los valores europeos".

La organización ha confiado en que las relaciones comerciales entre "aliados históricos" como España y Estados Unidos continúen desarrollándose en un marco de "respeto mutuo" y libre comercio.

La amenaza del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de que España pagará por el canal comercial lo que no está dispuesta a asumir en el marco de la OTAN vuelve a dejar el aceite de oliva español expuesto a los eventuales aranceles que el mandatario decida imponer.

El aceite de oliva es el producto más exportado a EEUU, después de que en 2024 se vendieran 113.416 toneladas por un importe de 1.013 millones de euros, con un aumento del 58 % respecto a los 640 millones de 2023.

En total España exportó en 2024 a EEUU 18.179,1 millones de euros, un 3,8 % menos que un año antes, mientras que importó 28.192,6 millones, un 0,3 % menos, lo que deja un déficit comercial para España de 10.013,5 millones de euros.

En 2024 aumentó la venta de vino, que pasó de 313 a 335 millones, otro de los productos del sector agroalimentario más expuestos.

title: How Trump learned to stop worrying and love NATO
content: It was a world away from Trump’s 2018 visit to the NATO summit in Brussels. Then, he started by shoving Montenegro's Prime Minister Duško Marković out of his way before a group photo and ended by ...
resumen: At the NATO summit in The Hague, European officials used flattery and avoided specifics to win over President Donald Trump. NATO Secretary-General Mark Rutte's approach was to call Trump “daddy.” The summit's schedule was slimmed down, with praise for the president and fewer existential questions. Trump praised Rutte and the allies in his press conference, stating that NATO is “not a ripoff, they really love their countries.” Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met for an hour. Spain objected to the group’s pledge to spend 5 percent of gross domestic product on defense by 2035, which led Trump to call Spain's stance "terrible" and threaten tariffs. The summit's final communiqué was just five paragraphs, down from 38 last year. NATO leaders promised to incorporate military aid for Ukraine into their defense budgets. Trump said he left the summit "a little bit differently," impressed by the passion shown by the heads of countries.

title: Is Donald Trump making Europe great again?
content: Amidst escalating trade tensions with the US, global investors are increasingly turning their attention towards Europe, particularly Germany. Concerns ...
resumen: Amidst escalating trade tensions with the US, global investors are increasingly turning their attention towards Europe, particularly Germany. Concerns over President Trump's trade policies have weakened the dollar and spurred interest in the Eurozone. Germany's robust economy and strategic investments are attracting significant capital, with firms like Blackstone and Apollo Global Management planning substantial investments. Time is running out for American and European trade negotiators working to cut a tariff deal before a July 9 deadline set by US President Donald Trump. It remains unclear whether or not Trump's threat of imposing a 50% levy on nearly all European Union imports will materialize. Given Trump's erratic trade policy, global investors have grown increasingly wary of the US economy, and are beginning to turn their attention toward Europe, especially Germany, the continent's largest economy. While the American S&P 500 stock market index has seen big ups and downs since Trump became US president in January, Germany's blue chip DAX index has risen steadily, and is up more than 15% now. In addition, the US dollar has lost 10% of its value against the euro, with the British pound and the Swiss franc also rising against the US currency. Joachim Nagel, the president of Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, cautioned about fresh turbulence in global financial markets if the trade conflict with the US isn't resolved. The international monetary fund (IMF) already sees "signs of strain" in the US economy amid Trump's policies, warning in its April 2025 Fiscal Monitor that US debt could spiral out of control. According to the US treasury department, America is now saddled with over $36 trillion (€31.6 trillion) in debt more than 120% of its GDP as of last year and nearly twice Germany's debt-to-GDP ratio. In 2025, the US's budget deficit is expected to exceed 6.5 per cent. Stefan Wintels, CEO of Germany's state-owned development bank, KfW, believes Donald Trump's aggressive trade and tariff policies have spooked investors and driven them to reassess. Steve Schwarzman, CEO of US investment firm Blackstone, has announced plans to invest up to $500 billion in the continent over the next decade. The European commission has also acknowledged the need to strengthen the EU's single market of nearly 450 million consumers. According to a leaked strategy paper obtained by German media platform Table Briefings, "all it takes to make up for a 20% fall in the goods exports to the US, is a 2.4% increase in intra EU goods trade." The so-called SuperReturn International conference held annually in Berlin drew thousands of top investors this year, including from pension funds, insurers, and sovereign wealth funds managing around €46 trillion ($53.2 trillion) in assets. New York-based Apollo Global Management said it intends to focus even more heavily on Germany over the next decade. Apollo President Jim Zelter said they see the opportunity to put $100 billion in the ground in Germany in the next decade.

title: Trump’s ‘Great Deal’ could be India’s great fall
content: We don’t need a deal that hollows out domestic production, increases import dependence and deepens rural distress ...
resumen:
When US President Donald Trump declared he wants a “great deal” with India, it was a reaffirmation of a deeply transactional worldview, where trade is not about mutual benefit but about strategic gain. As India and the US advance towards a Free Trade Agreement (FTA), it’s time to pause and reflect. Trade deals must be symmetrical and protect the weak, not empower the dominant.

The US operates one of the most heavily subsidized farm economies. India is a patchwork of vulnerable smallholder farmers.

The dairy sector employs over 75 million rural Indians. American dairy giants benefit from $12 billion annually in federal subsidies. American cheddar sells at ₹300 per kilo. Indian producers need at least ₹475 to break even. Lowering dairy tariffs would cause a collapse in Indian milk prices. American dairy products are often made using rennet, which clashes with Indian vegetarian and religious norms.

Thanks to the US–China trade war, soybean stocks in America surged to over 46 million tonnes. India, if it slashes import duties, would become a convenient dumping ground.

In 2016, when India temporarily dropped wheat duties to zero, imports surged to nearly 6 million tonnes and domestic prices crashed. American wheat could pour into Indian markets, undermining the minimum support price system.

The US is the world’s largest corn exporter. Replacing domestic maize with cheap American imports would destabilise agriculture and local economies.

American companies export chicken legs and other “low-value” cuts. Since 2018, when India lost a WTO case and began allowing US poultry imports, the trickle has begun. Indian poultry farms would find it impossible to compete.

After India reduced import duties in late 2023, pulse imports nearly doubled in one year—from 2.45 million tonnes to 4.5 million tonnes.

After India cut tariffs on US apples by 50 per cent, imports soared 16-fold in just one year, devastating growers in Himachal Pradesh and Kashmir.

India is the world’s largest cotton producer. Cheap US cotton is seeping into Indian mills. American cotton is backed by strong price support systems.

US trade agreements often include stringent intellectual property rights provisions. If India agrees to such terms, it could surrender the right of its farmers to save and reuse seeds.

President Trump’s latest statement must be decoded for what it is: a demand for a tilted table, where America plays with loaded dice.

India has already signed 17 FTAs. This time, we are dealing with a country that treats trade as an extension of statecraft.

Negotiators must carve out sensitive sectors, insert quantitative restrictions, reject IP enforcement that threatens food security, and refuse to equate American overproduction with Indian needs.

A deal that hollows out domestic production, increases import dependence and deepens rural distress is not a trade agreement—it is economic surrender.

title: Multilateralism can evolve to be more ‘flexible’, says PM Wong at WEF event
content: This means having like-minded nations cooperate on specific issues while leaving the door open for others to join. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said in a dialogue at a World Economic Forum (WEF) event in Tianjin, China, on June 25 that multilateralism can evolve to be more ‘flexible’. He said that Singapore is proposing a workaround of getting like-minded countries to cooperate on specific issues, while leaving the door open for others to join in the future. He called this "flexible multilateralism". He said that the efforts should be open and inclusive. He urged countries to update, evolve and improve the multilateral system, rather than abandon it altogether. The US has imposed a 10 per cent baseline tariff on Singapore. PM Wong said that for small countries like Singapore, they are worried because they have limited options, limited bargaining power, and risk being marginalised. He said bigger countries will also find it hard to deal with and operate in the new environment because it will be harder for the world to address common threats, such as pandemics, climate change or financial shocks. Singapore, together with Japan and Australia, had pushed for a joint initiative about e-commerce at the World Trade Organisation (WTO). More than 70 countries have joined this initiative. PM Wong told the moderator, WEF president Borge Brende, that if like-minded countries everywhere were to do their part, then collectively, they can make a difference. PM Wong said that trade will still exist, but with changing patterns. Other drivers for global growth are technology and the move towards sustainability. PM Wong was speaking at the Annual Meeting of the New Champions, a WEF event more commonly known as Summer Davos, that attracted more than 1,700 global leaders from businesses, government, civil society and academia. Mr. Brende asked PM Wong how Singapore balances between its “special friends” – the US and China. PM Wong said that Singapore’s starting point is to look at how it advances its own national interest. He said Singapore engages with not just America and China, but also other major powers. Asked by Mr Brende how Singapore navigates the fragmented geopolitical landscape and avoids ending up between a rock and a hard place, PM Wong said: “If we end up in a hard place, it’s not just us. Many other countries will also end up in a hard place, and I think the consequence of that will be disastrous for the world.

title: Multilateralism will need to evolve to become more ‘flexible’, says Singapore PM Wong at WEF event
content: In response to the world's common threats, PM Wong said Singapore has sought to make multilateralism “more resilient, more inclusive, and better suited to the realities of our time." ...
resumen:
Singapore’s Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said multilateralism will need to evolve to become more ‘flexible’ in a dialogue at a World Economic Forum (WEF) event in Tianjin, China, on June 25, 2025.

Singapore is proposing a workaround of getting like-minded countries to cooperate on specific issues, while leaving the door open for others to join in the future.

PM Wong said, “This is what we call a flexible multilateralism.”

He added that the efforts should be open and inclusive.

He urged countries to update, evolve and improve the multilateral system.

The US has imposed a 10 per cent baseline tariff on Singapore.

PM Wong said, “For small countries like Singapore, we are worried because we have limited options, we have limited bargaining power, and we risk being marginalised.”

In response, Singapore has sought to make multilateralism “more resilient, more inclusive, and better suited to the realities of our time”.

Singapore, together with Japan and Australia, had pushed for a joint initiative about e-commerce at the World Trade Organisation (WTO).

After five years of negotiations, more than 70 countries have joined this initiative.

PM Wong told the moderator, WEF president Borge Brende, “The efforts may seem small and incremental, but if like-minded countries everywhere were to do our part, then collectively, I think we can make a difference.”

PM Wong was speaking at the Annual Meeting of the New Champions, a WEF event that attracted more than 1,700 global leaders.

Mr Brende asked PM Wong a question about how Singapore balances between its “special friends” – the US and China.

PM Wong said Singapore’s starting point is to look at how it advances its own national interest.

He said Singapore engages with not just America and China, but also other major powers.

title: Mexico close to striking a deal on US steel tariffs, Bloomberg reports
content: Bloomberg reports that the "developing framework" would alleviate crushing duties on some of the Mexican steel imports that U.S. automakers need.
resumen: Mexico could get a reprieve from the United States’ 50% tariffs on steel imports, but only on exports up to a certain limit, according to the Bloomberg news agency. The United States imposed 25% tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports in March, and doubled the rate to 50% this month. Trade negotiations between the United States and Mexico are “homing in on a possible quota system to reduce tariffs on a certain volume of steel imports.” The news agency said that “the developing framework” would “alleviate crushing duties for some of the Mexican steel imports that U.S. automakers and other industries have described as essential.” A “tariff-free steel quota” could be established based on Mexico’s export volumes between 2015 and 2017. A quota based on 2015-2017 volumes would equate to about 2.79 million metric tonnes of steel per year, according to data from the United States Department of Commerce. Steel imports from Mexico “under any threshold specified under the deal would avoid the 50% tariff but are still expected to be hit with a 10% baseline charge.” Amounts above it would be subjected to the full [50%] duty. A “tariff-free” or “tariff-reduced” quota of 2.79 million tonnes of steel per year would represent about 88% of Mexico’s steel exports to the United States last year, which totaled  3.19 million metric tonnes. Bloomberg did not report on any negotiations between the United States and Mexico related to the 50% tariff on aluminum. Mexico is the third-largest exporter of steel to the United States, but it imports more of that metal, and aluminum, from the U.S. than it sends to its northern neighbor. Economy Minister Marcelo Ebrard has traveled to Washington, D.C. on several occasions to negotiate exemptions, or at least reductions, of U.S. tariffs on steel, aluminum and vehicles made in Mexico. He is aiming to negotiate exemptions, or at least reductions, of U.S. tariffs on steel, aluminum and vehicles made in Mexico. On June 4 — the date the 50% tariff on steel and aluminum exports to the U.S. took effect — President Claudia Sheinbaum said: “In the case of Mexico, firstly, it’s unjust … because as we have said several times, Mexico imports more [from the United States] than it exports in steel and aluminum. Formally, a tariff is imposed when there is a deficit. … Secondly, from our perspective, it has no legal basis because there is a trade agreement.” The trade agreement she was referring to is the USMCA. Sheinbaum said last Wednesday that in a telephone call with U.S. President Donald Trump she proposed a separate “general agreement” between Mexico and the United States covering security, migration and trade. Sheinbaum said last Thursday that the Mexican government’s “objective” was for the agreement to be signed “very soon.”

content: Los fabricantes de smartphones han llevado al público hacia precios exorbitantes que no necesariamente reflejan un gran avance en hardware. El OnePlus 13 es un golpe en la mesa que dice: “No tienes ...
resumen:
El OnePlus 13 es un smartphone que desafía los precios exorbitantes con un rendimiento excepcional. Está equipado con Snapdragon 8 Elite, cámara Hasselblad y batería de 6000mAh.

Especificaciones:
*   Procesador Snapdragon 8 Elite
*   Pantalla OLED Pro XDR LTPO de 6.82” QHD+, 3168 x 1440. Dolby Vision y HDR10+
*   16GB de RAM
*   512GB de almacenamiento
*   Cámara trasera 50MP OIS + 50MP ultra gran angular + 50Mp Zoom óptico 6X y hasta 120X digital.
*   Cámara frontal 32MP + gran angular
*   Batería de 6,000mAh con carga rápida 100W Super VOOC.
*   Android 15 OxygenOS

El diseño conserva el OnePlus 12, con una ligera alusión a su alianza con Hasselblad. Las versiones azules y blancas cuentan con un back de piel vegana.

El dispositivo puede con edición de video, juegos en alta calidad gráfica y largas grabaciones 4K. Con su batería de 6,000mAh se puede llegar al final del día. Una carga de 15min puede llevar hasta un 40%. La versión para México no cuenta con el cargador de 100W en la caja.

La cámara ofrece fotos detalladas sin colores exagerados (gracias, Hasselblad). El zoom de 120X es más un truco, pero el trabajo de reconstrucción con IA es increíble. Fotos hasta 20X son perfectamente utilizables. El modo de ambientes es útil para situaciones de fotografía y video complicadas. Su único lado flaco es la fotografía en modo nocturno.

La pantalla es grande y brillante. Los colores son vibrantes y su contraste es generoso. Sus bocinas estéreo son poderosas y nítidas.

Cuenta con mejoras fotográficas como borrar objetos o quitar reflejos, resúmenes de artículos y transcripción de notas de voz.

title: Democracy shouldn’t be used as an ideological weapon
content: The democracy-vs-autocracy framing has widened the divide between democratic countries — “us” — and Russia and its allies — “them.” ...
resumen: Democracy shouldn’t be used as an ideological weapon. Ukraine, Gaza and the Iraq War reveal the perils of prioritizing defense over values. The United Nations Security Council holds a vote during a meeting on the third anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine at the bodies headquarters in New York on Feb. 24. By Maiko Ichihara. Contributing Writer. Jun 26, 2025. Populism is threatening democracy around the world. However, authoritarian domestic actors are not the only danger to this political system: Ironically, discourse emphasizing democracy in international politics has also served to distract attention from its essence. When Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine began three years ago, Western leaders framed the war in Ukraine as a battle not only in defense of sovereignty, one of the most widely shared norms in international politics, but democracy as well. Yet this narrative was merely focused on the national defense of a democratic state. It had the paradoxical effect of downplaying the institutions and values that define democracy, replacing them with an ideology centered on conflict between states.

title: 5 Insightful Analyst Questions From Teleflex’s Q1 Earnings Call
content: Teleflex’s first quarter results for 2025 prompted a negative market reaction, as revenues declined year over year and the company acknowledged persistent headwinds across multiple business segments.
resumen:
Teleflex's (TFX) first quarter results for 2025 prompted a negative market reaction, as revenues declined year over year and the company acknowledged persistent headwinds across multiple business segments. Management attributed the performance to continued challenges in its Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) business—driven by lost contracts and customer inventory management—alongside softness in UroLift and ongoing volume-based procurement pressures in China. CEO Liam Kelly noted, “The quarter evolved largely as expected,” but also cited the impact of macroeconomic factors and unfavorable product mix on margins.

Teleflex (TFX) Q1 CY2025 Highlights:
Revenue: $700.7 million vs analyst estimates of $699 million (5% year-on-year decline, in line).
Adjusted EPS: $2.91 vs analyst estimates of $2.88 (0.9% beat).
Adjusted EBITDA: $200 million vs analyst estimates of $189.4 million (28.5% margin, 5.6% beat).
Adjusted EPS guidance for the full year is $13.40 at the midpoint, missing analyst estimates by 4.9%.
Operating Margin: 17.9%, up from -0.6% in the same quarter last year.
Constant Currency Revenue fell 3.8% year on year (3.8% in the same quarter last year).
Market Capitalization: $5.27 billion.

Our Top 5 Analyst Questions Teleflex’s Q1 Earnings Call:
Patrick Wood (Morgan Stanley) asked whether OEM order improvement reflected supply chain shifts; CEO Liam Kelly responded that demand pickup was mostly base demand, not yet onshoring, but expected sequential improvement.
Michael Sarcone (Jefferies) pressed for details on tariff mitigation timing and EPS impact; CFO John Deren detailed ongoing supply chain, USMCA, and pricing strategies but cautioned against providing specific EPS offsets at this stage.
Jayson Bedford (Raymond James) questioned whether NewCo could be sold in parts or only as a whole; Kelly stated all options remain open, guided by maximizing shareholder value, and the process is running in parallel to a spin.
Craig Bijou (Bank of America) asked about Interventional Urology performance and UroLift’s outlook; Kelly said Palette continues to grow strongly, while UroLift remains pressured in the U.S. but is gaining traction in APAC.
Richard Newitter (Truist Securities) inquired about confidence in China’s recovery and potential product tariff exemptions; Kelly explained that the worst of China’s volume-based procurement impacts are likely past and expressed hope for medical device exemptions from tariffs.

Catalysts in Upcoming Quarters:
Analysts will closely monitor (1) the pace and effectiveness of tariff mitigation initiatives, including supply chain adjustments and pricing actions, (2) progress on the proposed separation and potential sale of NewCo assets, and (3) integration milestones for the BIOTRONIK Vascular Intervention acquisition. Additional focus will be on the recovery trajectories for OEM and China segments and the commercial traction of new products.
Teleflex currently trades at $119.15, down from $136.94 just before the earnings.

title: A relentless Trump battles a steadfast Powell on rate cuts. Who’s right?
content: President Trump certainly thinks so. He’s pounding the table for immediate rate cuts, and two of the central bank’s five governors agree. In a rare public break, they said it would make sense to start ...
resumen:
The Federal Reserve waited too long to raise interest rates when prices took off in 2021. Now, with inflation nearly back in the central bank’s comfort zone, are policy makers dragging their feet again — this time on the way down?

President Trump is pounding the table for immediate rate cuts, and two of the central bank’s five governors agree. They said it would make sense to start reducing rates as soon as their next meeting in July, not months down the road as Fed chair Jerome Powell has suggested.

The president is considering nominating a successor much earlier than usual who could serve as a kind of shadow chair before Powell’s tenure ends in May.

The Fed directly controls short-term rates, which influence borrowing costs on mortgages, credit cards, and business loans.

Vice President JD Vance said Tuesday on X: “I’d love to hear an argument for why Powell cut rates 50 points right before an election but can’t do it now with inflation lower.”

The Fed voted last week to leave its benchmark lending rate unchanged at about 4.3 percent. The short-term federal funds rate hasn’t changed since December, following a full percentage point decline in 2024.

Officials hit the pause button after inflation ticked modestly higher last winter. More recently, inflation has been cooling, but the Fed is focused on what consumer prices will do when the impact of Trump’s tariffs becomes clear.

The big unknown: Will import taxes — now the steepest since the 1930s — lead to a one-time boost to inflation that the Fed could ignore? Or will they trigger a spiral of rapidly rising prices that would force policy makers to keep rates elevated.

Michelle Bowman, vice chair for supervision of the Federal Reserve: "I would support lowering the policy rate as soon as our next meeting."

The Fed’s preferred price gauge — the personal consumption expenditures index excluding food and energy — fell to an annualized 2.1 percent in April from 2.6 percent at the end of last year. Its target is 2 percent.

Michelle Bowman, the Fed’s vice chair for supervision and a Trump appointee, said on Wednesday: “Should inflation pressures remain contained, I would support lowering the policy rate as soon as our next meeting in order to bring it closer to its neutral setting and to sustain a healthy labor market.”

Fed Governor Christopher Waller, another Trump appointee, also said he expected tariffs would boost inflation only temporarily. But Waller dismissed a key argument Trump has voiced for immediately lowering rates: reducing interest payments on the national debt.

Waller said: “Our mandate from Congress tells us to worry about unemployment and price stability. It does not tell us to provide cheap financing to the US government.”

Gregory Daco, chief economist at EY-Parthenon, wrote Wednesday on LinkedIn: “Many firms, anticipating tariff hikes, accelerated shipments in February and March. This created a sizable inventory buffer, effectively delaying the moment when higher-cost goods reach store shelves.”

Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody’s Analytics: “I think the Fed should be allowed to do its job. If it cuts rates too soon, before it is clear that inflation is not a problem, it will be counterproductive. Mortgage rates and other borrowing costs will go up, and not down.”

title: Tariffs Are Keeping Interest Rates High
content: Interest rates may have fallen this year, if not for the uncertainty and higher costs created by President Donald Trump's tariff schemes.

title: España pide a Trump que no dé consejos y acabe con la guerra en Ucrania y Gaza
content: La ministra, que asistió también a la cumbre de la OTAN de este martes y miércoles en La Haya, hizo estas declaraciones a los medios tras un acto oficial presidido por el rey Felipe VI ...
resumen: La ministra española de Defensa, Margarita Robles, aseguró que le hubiese gustado que el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, en vez de dar consejos a España, se hubiera referido a Ucrania y Gaza en la cumbre de las OTAN y le emplazó a usar su influencia para acabar con ambas guerras. Robles dijo que echó de menos que el presidente estadounidense no hubiera hecho “ni una sola mención” a Ucrania y Gaza. La ministra, que asistió también a la cumbre de la OTAN de este martes y miércoles en La Haya, hizo estas declaraciones a los medios tras un acto oficial presidido por el rey Felipe VI. La ministra advirtió de que “nadie tiene que decir a España lo que tiene que hacer“. España quiere tener las mejores relaciones con sus socios internacionales, pero fue tajante al asegurar que “no acepta lecciones de nadie“. “España es un aliado serio, fiable y comprometido que cumple, no solo habla, habla menos y cumple más“, afirmó Robles en presencia del monarca y de la cúpula militar española. “España va a seguir cumpliendo todas las misiones, todos los objetivos de capacidad que se nos demanden”, subrayó Robles, quien precisó que, sin entrar en ningún tipo de debate, el Gobierno español considera que no es una cuestión de porcentajes. El acto oficial era la entrega de diplomas a los 117 militares de los Ejércitos de Tierra y del Aire y del Espacio, y de la Armada, guardias civiles y agentes de la Policía Nacional que culminaron el Curso de Estado Mayor de la Escuela Superior de las Fuerzas Armadas. A ellos se unieron 27 oficiales extranjeros, de países como Estados Unidos, Alemania, Francia, Reino Unido, Portugal, Argentina, Brasil, Arabia Saudí, Marruecos o Corea del Sur.

title: US allows ethane to be loaded and shipped to China, but not unloaded
content: The US allows companies to load ethane for export to China but prohibits unloading without further authorization, reflecting ongoing trade tensions and export restrictions amid the US-China trade war.
resumen: The US sent letters to Enterprise Products and Energy Transfer on Wednesday informing the companies they could load ethane on vessels destined for China but could not unload the ethane in China without authorization. The letters from the US Department of Commerce follow a licensing requirement imposed several weeks ago on the companies' exports of ethane to China, which halted shipments and led to vessels anchoring in or hovering around the US Gulf Coast. The letters may signal the US preparing to lift restrictions imposed on exports to China in late May and early June. With China granting rare earth export licenses to some firms and saying it would speed up the approval process, the US now appears close to permitting ethane exports to China. If the vessels make their way to China, it may be difficult to stop them from offloading the ethane and the companies could face penalties of up to twice the value of the shipment if they do. A copy of the letter seen by Reuters and later released by Enterprise Products said, "This letter authorizes Enterprise Products to load vessels with ethane, transport and anchor in foreign ports, even if... to a party located in China," the letter said. "However, Enterprise Products may not complete such export... to a party that is located in China," without further authorization. Enterprise Products and Energy Transfer, two of the top US ethane producers and exporters, did not respond to requests for comment. About half of all US ethane exports go to China, where it is used by the petrochemical industry. The US Department of Commerce also did not immediately respond to requests for comment. The ability to load and begin transporting ethane could relieve congestion at ports along the US Gulf coast, where vessels have been stalled. Since May 23, the US imposed new restrictions on exports to China of everything from ethane and chip design software to jet engines and nuclear plant parts.

title: Family offices shift assets to Hong Kong, China and Europe from the US: BNP Paribas
content: French bank says family offices are shifting assets away from the US thanks to tariffs and other trade tensions.
resumen:
Global family offices have allocated more of their assets to Hong Kong, China, Japan and Europe at the expense of the US amid market uncertainties triggered by American tariffs, BNP Paribas Wealth Management said.

Arnaud Tellier, the Asia CEO of the French bank’s wealth-management unit, said its family office clients shifted their investment strategies after US President Donald Trump rolled out his slate of tariffs in April.

Many are actively diversifying away from US dollar assets, increasing allocations to Europe and Asia, especially Hong Kong, China and Japan, due to concerns over US dollar weakness, high US equity valuations and ongoing geopolitical risks.

This move is both a response to the US economic uncertainty and a strategic effort to capture better value and growth in other global markets.

Family offices are entities set up by wealthy families to manage their succession plans, investments and charitable endeavours.

Tellier said interest from global family offices in Chinese technology stocks has grown since Hangzhou-based artificial intelligence (AI) start-up DeepSeek launched two powerful and cost-effective large language models earlier this year, catching many investors by surprise.

We have definitely seen stronger interest in China tech stocks from family office clients after the DeepSeek moment. This enthusiasm has expanded beyond just AI, with clients now looking at hardware, AI application software, power infrastructure, and the broader tech value chain.

title: US tariffs cause self-inflicted economic harm; further trade talks imperative: US economist
content: The negative impact of the US administration's tariffs on the US' own economy has already emerged, as "most people see slowing economic growth in the US," and there should be further dialogue between ...
resumen: The negative impact of the US administration's tariffs on the US' own economy has already emerged, as "most people see slowing economic growth in the US," and there should be further dialogue between China and the US to solve their trade tensions, a US economist focusing on trade said in an interview during the 16th Annual Meeting of the New Champions, also known as the Summer Davos, in North China's Tianjin. The US government has imposed steep tariffs on China, citing its "massive trade deficit" with China. "As a trade economist, I typically argue that trade imbalance between the two countries is due to more macroeconomic forces," Robert Koopman, Hurst Senior Professional Lecturer with the School of International Service of American University and former Chief Economist at the WTO, told the Global Times. "In China, consumers save a lot, and they don't spend a lot. In the US, consumers don't save a lot, the government doesn't save at all," Koopman said. Tariffs raise prices for American consumers or reduces profitability of American firms, as only a very small amount of the tariffs imposed by the US government gets absorbed by foreign exporters, Koopman said. "Despite what the [US] administration says, it encourages a misallocation of resources in the US. The US tariffs will encourage production of goods for which we don't have a comparative advantage, and will be reallocating capital and labor from those sectors where we do have a comparative advantage to sectors that we don't," he said, noting that this results in US' slower economic growth, although not necessarily a recession. The US expert pointed out that there are a lot of leading indicators that show that US consumer sentiment is down and investment is weak. "We see the US dollar weakening, and treasury yields rising. There are a lot of negative elements in the forecast. Most people see slowing economic growth in the US and a big driver of that is the uncertainty around the tariffs," Koopman said. Firms don't know what to do, and they don't know if they should invest in the US or invest elsewhere, Koopman said. "The tariffs are bad in and of themselves, but the uncertainty around US policy - whether it's tariff policy or regulatory policy, or even the budget - has significant negative effects on both US manufacturing or US businesses, and also US households," he said. Koopman called for broader negotiations between the two countries, noting that the first meeting of the China-US economic and trade consultation mechanism recently held in London was positive for the world. The US expert said that US tariffs on China will likely remain "fairly high." If the US continues to take unilateral actions to raise tariffs, the rest of the world can start talking with one another about continued cooperation and integration and lower tariffs among themselves. The US is a large country, but it's not large compared to the global economy. So, if the rest of the world continues to cooperate and integrate, the markets remain much bigger, and there's much faster growth outside," Koopman said.

title: EU leaders meet to discuss tougher Russia sanctions, US tariffs and Middle East conflicts
content: BRUSSELS — The heads of the European Union’s 27 member nations will meet Thursday in Brussels to discuss tougher sanctions on Russia , ways to prevent painful new U.S. tariffs, and how to make their ...
resumen:
Los líderes de la Unión Europea de las 27 naciones miembros se reunirán el jueves en Bruselas para discutir sanciones más duras contra Rusia, formas de prevenir nuevas y dolorosas tarifas de Estados Unidos y cómo hacer oír sus voces en los conflictos de Oriente Medio.

El presidente ucraniano, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, se unirá a la cumbre de la UE por videoconferencia, después de reunirse con Trump el miércoles.

Los miembros discutirán una 18ª ronda de sanciones contra Rusia y si mantener un tope de precios al petróleo ruso, medidas a las que algunas naciones se oponen porque podrían aumentar los precios de la energía.

Trump amenazó con aranceles que están pesando sobre la UE, que negocia acuerdos comerciales en nombre de los 27 países miembros. El presidente de Francia criticó a Trump por iniciar una guerra comercial con aliados de larga data.

Los líderes europeos también están preocupados por las consecuencias de las guerras en Oriente Medio, y la UE está presionando para revivir las negociaciones diplomáticas con Irán sobre su programa nuclear.

Los miembros de la UE tienen desacuerdos internos que superar. Están divididos sobre qué hacer con la política europea hacia Israel debido a su conducta en Gaza. Y los partidos de izquierda están atacando el cambio de la Comisionada Europea Ursula von Der Leyen de liderazgo climático de la UE a favor de la inversión militar.

La defensa y la seguridad probablemente encabecen la agenda. La cumbre finalizará con una declaración de conclusiones que establecerá la agenda del bloque para los próximos cuatro meses.

title: Mercado cripto: si Trump se sale con la suya, ¿qué monedas pegarían un salto?
content: Las últimas noticias de Mercado cripto: si Trump se sale con la suya, ¿qué monedas pegarían un salto? | Ecos365.com.ar | Información de negocios, economía, agro, gestión y emprendimientos de la ciudad ...
resumen:
El presidente de EE. UU. tiene en la mira a Jerome Powell, el actual presidente de la Reserva Federal (Fed) y deslizó que ya tiene en mente "tres o cuatro" candidatos para reemplazarlo. De concretarse, podría desatarse una ola de recortes de tasas de interés y, con ello, un viento de cola para el mercado de las criptomonedas.

Si Trump logra imponer un presidente de la Fed más alineado con su visión de tasas de interés bajas, el principal beneficiado sería Bitcoin.

Otras criptomonedas como Ethereum (ETH), XRP y Solana (SOL) también verían un impulso significativo, especialmente por su rol central en el auge de las divisas estables con paridad al billete estadounidense.

Trump Media and Technology Group, holding de medios vinculado al mandatario, avanza con una audaz solicitud para lanzar un ETF combinado de Bitcoin y Ethereum en la Bolsa de Nueva York (NYSE).

El instrumento, denominado Truth Social Bitcoin and Ethereum ETF, apostaría fuerte por Bitcoin, manteniendo una proporción de 3 a 1 a favor de la principal criptomoneda frente a Ethereum. Además, contaría con el respaldo de Crypto.com, que actuaría como gestor, custodio y proveedor de liquidez.

title: Indonesia’s ex-president Yudhoyono urges Asean to beef up investment game amid global shifts
content: JAKARTA] South-east Asia must step up its efforts to attract long-term investment by enhancing trust, improving human capital and building a more compelling regional narrative, Indonesia’s former ...
resumen:
South-east Asia must step up its efforts to attract long-term investment by enhancing trust, improving human capital and building a more compelling regional narrative, Indonesia’s former president Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono said, warning that rising geopolitical tensions and economic realignments are reshaping the global investment landscape.

Speaking at the Asia Economic Summit in Jakarta on Thursday (June 26), he said the region faces both opportunities and risks as industries increasingly shift out of China in response to global trade tensions, particularly between the US and China.

The 75-year-old served as Indonesia’s sixth president from 2004 to 2014.

He said that to remain competitive, South-east Asia needs to expand its fiscal space, improve financial intermediation (particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises), and invest heavily in education and skills training to prepare workers for an increasingly automated, AI-driven future.

Amid mounting global volatility, from the wars in Ukraine and Gaza to intensifying strategic rivalries between major powers such as US, China and Russia, Yudhoyono urged South-east Asia nations to project a united and dependable front to international investors.

Yudhoyono also urged South-east Asian nations to tell a more unified and compelling story on the global stage.

The Asia Economic Summit was organised by Tech in Asia and The Business Times.

Robles precisó que, sin entrar en ningún tipo de debate, el Gobierno español considera que no es una cuestión de porcentajes.

El acto oficial era la entrega de diplomas a los 117 militares de los Ejércitos de Tierra y del Aire y del Espacio, y de la Armada, guardias civiles y agentes de la Policía Nacional que culminaron el Curso de Estado Mayor de la Escuela Superior de las Fuerzas Armadas.

A ellos se unieron 27 oficiales extranjeros, de países como Estados Unidos, Alemania, Francia, Reino Unido, Portugal, Argentina, Brasil, Arabia Saudí, Marruecos o Corea del Sur.

title: Trump tariff impact seen rippling through global economy in second half - Barclays
content: Investing.com - The impact of sweeping U.S. tariffs is expected to ripple through the world economy in the second half of 2025, according to analysts at Barclays.
resumen: According to Barclays analysts led by Amrut Nashikkar, the impact of U.S. tariffs is expected to ripple through the world economy in the second half of 2025. They anticipate that the effect of the tariffs will "work their way through" the world economy in the last six months of 2025. Barclays expects weak growth, but the U.S. will escape an outright recession. Tariffs will push U.S. core inflation over 3%, keeping the Fed on the sidelines for the next few meetings. Core inflation stood at 2.8% in May. The world economy "should come through the trade war relatively unscathed," and lower interest rates, German stimulus plans and a drop in policy uncertainty should help growth rebound in 2026. They forecast fourth quarter to fourth quarter global economic expansion of 2.2% in 2025 and 3.1% next year. They predict that financial markets will "increasingly tune out tariff and tax headlines" and turn their focus instead to "macro data and the extent to which the artificial intelligence dividend will boost corporate earnings, especially for large tech firms.". Equities are preferred to fixed income in this environment. Financials, health care, and mega-cap tech firms were all recommended by Barclays.

title: EU leaders meet to decide on whether to back quick US trade deal or seek better terms
content: European Union leaders are to tell the European Commission on Thursday whether they want to reach a quick trade agreement with the United States on terms that favour Washington or keep fighting for a ...
resumen:
European Union leaders are to tell the European Commission on Thursday whether they want to reach a quick trade agreement with the United States on terms that favour Washington or keep fighting for a better deal.

A quick deal seems to be the preferred option for most, officials and diplomats said, as the EU can then seek to address the unfavourable bias with some rebalancing measures of its own.

German Chancellor Friedrich Merz said, "I also support the European Commission in all its endeavours to reach a trade agreement with the USA quickly."

The Commission, which negotiates trade agreements on behalf of the EU, will ask leaders of the EU's 27 members meeting in Brussels how they want to respond to President Donald Trump's July 9 deadline for a deal.

The bloc has said it is striving for a mutually beneficial agreement, but as Washington looks set to stick to its 10% across-the board tariffs on most EU goods and threatening higher rates with prolonged talks, EU diplomats said a growing number of EU countries were now favouring a quick resolution.

Belgian Prime Minister Bart De Wever said, "If that were to end in one-sided and unfair tariffs then we have to take proportionate and very targeted countermeasures."

The bloc is already facing U.S. import tariffs of 50% on its steel and aluminium, 25% for cars and car parts, along with a 10% tariff on most other EU goods, which Trump has threatened could rise to 50% without an agreement.

The United States' only completed trade deal to date is with Britain, with the broad 10% tariff still in place. U.S. officials say it will not go lower for any trading partner.

Some 23 of the leaders will come to Brussels straight from the NATO summit in the Hague.

One EU diplomat said, "There is a group of EU countries that want to protect companies by seemingly accepting something they have gotten used to – a 10% baseline."

The European Union has agreed, but not imposed, tariffs on 21 billion euros of U.S. goods and is debating a further package of tariffs on up to 95 billion euros of U.S. imports.

Among the EU rebalancing options is a tax on digital advertising, which would hit U.S. giants like Alphabet Inc's Google, Meta, Apple, X or Microsoft and eat into the trade surplus in services the U.S. has with the EU. The bloc has a trade surplus with the U.S. in goods.

The Commission has proposed an EU-U.S. deal to cut respective tariffs on industrial goods to zero, along with potential further EU purchases of liquefied natural gas and soybeans.

Washington has shown little obvious interest, preferring to highlight items it considers as barriers, such as EU value-added tax, environmental standards and rules on online platforms, on which the EU does not want to move.

On the sidelines of the summit, EU leaders will also seek to allay the concerns of Slovakia and Hungary over ending their access to Russian gas as foreseen by the EU's plan to phase out all Russian gas imports by the end of 2027.

EU diplomats said EU leaders' assurances over gas should allow the two countries to back the EU's 18th package of sanctions against Russia, which they are now blocking.

Before the start of the summit however, Slovakia's Prime Minister Robert Fico said he would demand a delay in voting for the sanctions until Slovak concerns were addressed.

title: India, U.S. trade talks face roadblocks ahead of tariff deadline, Indian sources say
content: Trade talks between India and the U.S. have hit a roadblock over disagreements on import duties for auto components, steel and farm goods, Indian officials with direct knowledge said, dashing hopes of ...
resumen:
Trade talks between India and the U.S. have hit a roadblock over disagreements on import duties for auto components, steel and farm goods, according to Indian officials. President Donald Trump has a July 9 deadline to impose reciprocal tariffs.

India is pushing for a rollback of the proposed 26% reciprocal tariff set to take effect on July 9, along with concessions on existing U.S. tariffs on steel and auto parts. U.S. negotiators have not yet agreed to the demands.

The U.S. side wants India to commit to deeper import tariff cuts on farm goods like soybeans and corn, cars and alcoholic beverages along with easing of non-tariff barriers.

An Indian delegation is expected to travel to Washington before the deadline, although discussions may now focus on a broader agreement rather than a rushed interim deal.

India has offered tariff cuts on almonds, pistachios, walnuts, and was willing to extend preferential treatment for American imports in sectors like energy, autos and defence.

Modi and Trump agreed in February to conclude the first phase of a bilateral trade agreement by autumn 2025 and to expand trade to $500 billion by 2030, from about $191 billion in 2024.

India's exports to the U.S. rose to $17.25 billion in April-May, up from $14.17 billion a year earlier.

title: Planas destaca en Roma importancia del acuerdo UE-Mercosur para España e Italia
content: Planas ha defendido la importancia estratégica del acuerdo Unión Europea (UE)-Mercosur, al asegurar que beneficiará a sectores como el del aceite de oliva y del vino, tan importantes para España e Ita ...
resumen: El ministro de Agricultura, Pesca y Alimentación, Luis Planas, ha defendido este jueves la importancia estratégica del acuerdo Unión Europea (UE)-Mercosur, al asegurar que beneficiará a sectores como el del aceite de oliva y del vino, tan importantes para España e Italia. Planas se ha reunido en Roma con su homólogo italiano, Francesco Lollobrigida, antes de otro encuentro con el director general de la Organización de la Alimentación y Agricultura de Naciones Unidas (FAO), Qu Dongyu, en la víspera de la Conferencia de ministros de Agricultura del organismo de la ONU. El acuerdo entre la UE y Mercosur ha sido uno de los temas centrales de la reunión entre los ministros español e Italiano. Planas ha destacado ante Lollobrigida que se trata de un buen acuerdo que, entre otros sectores, beneficiará al del aceite de oliva y del vino de ambos países: "Es el logro más importante de la política exterior de la UE de los últimos años", ha remarcado, al recordar que facilitará el acceso a una población de 295 millones de personas. Los responsables de Agricultura de España e Italia también han abordado asuntos como el próximo marco financiero plurianual para los años 2028 a 2034, el presupuesto a largo plazo de la UE para la financiación de sus programas. Planas se reúne con su homólogo italiano, Francesco Lollobrigida, este jueves, en Roma. "Nos brinda la oportunidad de reconocer el valor fundamental del sistema agroalimentario y pesquero europeo", aseguró Planas. Para ello, ha añadido, es preciso garantizar una Política Agraria Común (PAC) y una Política Pesquera Común (PPC) fuertes, estables y con una dotación presupuestaria suficiente para afrontar los retos de futuro y apoyar al sector en su transición hacia modelos más sostenibles de producción. Respecto a la pesca en el Mediterráneo, el ministro ha agradecido a su homólogo que, junto con Francia, acudan unidos para abordar la modificación del reglamento comunitario que garantice una gestión pesquera que asegure la viabilidad económica del sector con la recuperación de las especies. Planas se reunirá este jueves con el director general de la Organización de la Alimentación y Agricultura de Naciones Unidas (FAO), en vísperas de su Conferencia de ministros de Agricultura, del organismo que se celebrará el viernes, en su sede en Roma.

title: Geopolítica, guerra y ciberseguridad: el riesgo invisible que ya nos afecta
content: El problema no es solo que haya ataques: es que cada actor reacciona en cadena, se endurecen las políticas de control tecnológico, y las brechas de defensa digital se ensanchan.
resumen: El ciberespacio se ha convertido en el nuevo campo de batalla y las empresas están en la línea de fuego. La nueva ecuación de riesgo que enfrentan gobiernos, empresas y ciudadanos incluye chips, satélites y servidores cloud. Los recientes anuncios de la administración Trump sobre aranceles a la tecnología son una declaración de guerra económica. Cada choque geopolítico termina amplificando una tormenta de amenazas digitales. El problema no es solo que haya ataques: es que cada actor reacciona en cadena, se endurecen las políticas de control tecnológico, y las brechas de defensa digital se ensanchan. Múltiples proveedores cloud, infraestructuras críticas y servicios digitales están bajo fuego cruzado de ciberataques con motivaciones geopolíticas. Actores pro-Irán ya han comenzado a atacar los intereses occidentales en represalia por alianzas estratégicas con Israel. Los proveedores críticos no solo son vulnerables: son objetivos. Se están materializando riesgos que antes eran “teóricos”: filtraciones por mal configuración de la nube, ataques a proveedores logísticos no tecnológicos, sanciones que interrumpen contratos y servicios, e incidentes de software originados en jurisdicciones hoy “sensibles”. El riesgo ya no depende solo del firewall, sino de con quién te relacionas, dónde está tu proveedor y qué decisiones políticas se toman a miles de kilómetros. EE.UU. ha comenzado a exigir mayor soberanía tecnológica, lo que puede fragmentar aún más el ecosistema digital global y crear nuevas monoculturas tecnológicas. Cuando todos dependen de un mismo proveedor occidental, o cuando se excluye a proveedores asiáticos sin una estrategia de resiliencia real, se genera una hiperconcentración peligrosa, especialmente para países de Latinoamérica. Se proponen tres ideas urgentes: mapeo profundo de dependencias, gobernanza con perspectiva geopolítica y estrategias de resiliencia digital transversales. Latinoamérica es parte del juego y cada tensión global tiene efectos directos en nuestros sistemas, contratos, proveedores y clientes. La guerra no solo se libra con misiles: también con malware. Andrea García Beltrán, directora de Riesgo Cibernético en Europa, Nirvana Insurance, host cibervoces podcast y Founder y ChairWomen CyberSpecsTM.
