title: Antonio Filosa, CEO de Stellantis, sobre la planta de Vigo: "Estoy impresionando por el compromiso y el entusiasmo"
content: Las cifras de ventas en Norteamérica han disminuido en general para las distintas marcas de la compañía, aún más amenazadas con los aranceles del 25 % impuestos por la administración Trump a los ...
resumen: El próximo 23 de junio, Antonio Filosa asumirá el cargo de consejero delegado del grupo Stellantis reemplazando a Carlos Tavares. Antonio Filosa recorre en estos días las principales fábricas del grupo internacional junto con los altos cargos de la compañía: Jean-Philippe Imparato, chief Operating officer, Enlarged Europe; Luca Napolitano, Stellantis commercial Operations & Global Lancia Brand y Anne Aboud, responsible for Stellantis Pro One Business Unit. Tras visitar Francia e Italia y antes de poner rumbo a Alemania y Eslovaquia, el nuevo CEO de Stellantis y sus hombres de máxima confianza recalaron en Vigo, donde les esperaba Marco Cane, director general de Iberia (España y Portugal). Antonio Filosa se mostró encantado de haber estado en España, un país "muy importante" para la compañía, y poder conocer de primera mano al equipo. "Estoy impresionado, pero no sorprendido, por el compromiso y el entusiasmo de nuestros colegas, movidos por una verdadera mentalidad emprendedora", subrayó. "La planta de Vigo es un ejemplo de experiencia y madurez. Estoy convencido de que junto con el equipo de España lograremos grandes cosas", añadió Filosa, especialmente interesado en el proyecto CustomFit, el nuevo programa de conversión y personalización. Antonio Filosa, hasta ahora Director de Operaciones de Stellantis para las Américas y Director de Calidad Global, con más de 25 años de experiencia en la industria. Antonio Filosa comenzó su carrera en la compañía en Fiat en 1999 y pasó la mayor parte de sus dos décadas y media en Brasil. Allí pasó a ser desde 2018 director de Fiat Chrysler en la región, donde llevó a la marca italiana a una posición de liderazgo, y posteriormente director de operaciones de Stellantis para Sudamérica. Ya en 2023 fue nombrado CEO global de la marca Jeep y a finales de 2024 asumió el cargo de Jefe de Operaciones en las Americas.

title: El impacto de la guerra de Irán en América Latina
content: Hay muchas especulaciones de que el conflicto de Irán podría generar un aumento de los precios del petróleo que beneficiaría a Venezuela, México, Colombia y otros productores de petróleo ...
resumen:
Hay muchas especulaciones de que el conflicto de Irán podría generar un aumento de los precios del petróleo que beneficiaría a Venezuela, México, Colombia y otros productores de petróleo latinoamericanos. La mayoría de los expertos petroleros dicen que ese escenario es poco probable.

Analistas de Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan y otras instituciones financieras dicen que los precios del petróleo podrían superar los $100 por barril si Irán interrumpe el paso de buques petroleros por el Estrecho de Ormuz, por donde pasa un 25% del transporte mundial de petróleo. La mayoría de ellos agrega que el impacto de esa potencial disrupción del transporte petrolero de sería limitada, y duraría poco.

Hay un exceso de petróleo en el mundo, en parte porque la economía mundial está creciendo a un ritmo más lento de lo que estaba previsto por las guerras arancelarias del presidente Donald Trump. Cinco días después del ataque de Israel a las instalaciones nucleares de Irán, los precios mundiales del petróleo estaban por debajo de su promedio de 2024 de $80 por barril, según un análisis del Deutsche Bank.

Irán es un exportador de petróleo relativamente pequeño, que produce alrededor del 3% de la producción mundial. Por las sanciones estadounidenses y europeas, Irán vende el 90% de su petróleo a un solo país: China. Si caen las exportaciones iraníes, eso afectaría principalmente a China, aunque ya cuenta con altos inventarios de petróleo.

En el escenario más catastrófico — si Irán bloqueara el Estrecho de Ormuz en represalia por las acciones estadounidenses o europeas en apoyo a Israel — Washington probablemente intervendría militarmente para reabrir esa importante ruta comercial. China, Rusia, Arabia Saudita y otros países probablemente criticarían de la boca para afuera semejante intervención, pero estarían aliviados de ver reabiertas sus rutas de suministro de petróleo.

Francisco J. Monaldi, director del Programa de Energía para América Latina del Instituto Baker de la Universidad de Rice, comentó que en el peor de los casos — una interrupción prolongada del Estrecho de Ormuz que haga subir drásticamente los precios del petróleo — habría una “ganancia neta” para los exportadores de petróleo latinoamericanos. Guyana, Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador y hasta cierto punto Brasil y Argentina verían un impacto positivo en sus ingresos. México hoy en día ya es un importador neto de petróleo, para (la empresa estatal) Pemex sería algo positivo. También habría algunos efectos secundarios negativos, como inflación internacional, y la posibilidad de una recesión mundial. Pero en términos netos, para esos países sería un auge importante de ingresos fiscales y de exportaciones.

Monaldi dijo que hay pocas probabilidades de que Irán pueda cerrar el Estrecho de Ormuz por mucho tiempo, porque la Armada de Estados Unidos reabriría inmediatamente esa ruta marítima, y los precios del petróleo pronto volverían a la normalidad. Podríamos ver un aumento temporal en los precios del petróleo, pero no debería haber un impacto a largo plazo.

El Banco Mundial, que recientemente publicó un informe que pronosticaba una importante desaceleración de la economía estadounidense y mundial, en parte debido a los aranceles de Trump, no anticipa un empeoramiento de la situación como resultado de la guerra con Irán.

Valerie Mercer-Backman, autora principal de la sección latinoamericana del pronóstico del Banco Mundial, comentó que, a pesar del conflicto, la tendencia general apuntaba a una “ligera disminución” de los precios mundiales del petróleo. La guerra podría producir un repunte temporal, pero no creen que los últimos acontecimientos geopolíticos tengan un impacto significativo en su pronóstico.

La dictadura de Venezuela — una de las principales beneficiarias de una potencial subida del precio del petróleo — junto con Colombia y México, podrían obtener un breve respiro económico gracias al conflicto de Irán. Pero eso no sería suficiente para ayudar a Venezuela a salir de su grave crisis económica, ni alcanzaría para resolver los problemas de México y Colombia.

title: Descubren en México túnel clandestino en frontera con EE.UU.
content: Autoridades mexicanas hallan túnel de 350 metros en Tijuana con conexión a EE. UU., usado para tráfico ilegal; incautan metanfetamina en el lugar.
resumen: Las fuerzas de seguridad de México hallaron este miércoles (18.06.2025) un túnel clandestino en la ciudad fronteriza de Tijuana (noroeste) que comunica con la estadounidense San Diego, informaron autoridades. El túnel, de 350 metros de largo, fue localizado por soldados y policías dentro de una vivienda, donde también fueron halladas «diversas dosis de metanfetamina», informó la Secretaría de Seguridad federal en un comunicado. El operativo se realizó «en coordinación» con autoridades de Estados Unidos, dijo a los periodistas Laureano Carrillo, secretario de Seguridad del estado de Baja California. En enero, fuerzas de seguridad de ambos países encontraron un túnel clandestino que comunicaba a la mexicana Ciudad Juárez (norte) con El Paso, en el estado de Texas. El gobierno mexicano multiplicó las detenciones y los decomisos de drogas en medio de las amenazas del presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles a México al alegar que el país vecino permite la entrada de drogas y migrantes indocumentados a su territorio.

title: ‘World upon his shoulders’: Farrell on the trade challenge facing the US
content: EXCLUSIVE: The trade minister tells The Saturday Paper about Australia’s edge in negotiations with the US over tariffs.
resumen: Trade Minister Don Farrell discusses Australia's edge in negotiations with the US over tariffs. Donald Trump set a deadline for remaking America’s trade relations with the world – 90 deals in 90 days, with July 8 rapidly approaching. Farrell says that the biggest meeting of trade ministers of all time was held, and everybody wanted to be talking with the Americans. A UK–US tariff deal is in place and reportedly most of a “framework” with China. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was pragmatic about Trump’s cancellation of their meeting and met with Jamieson Greer, US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and the director of the National Economic Council, Kevin Hassett. Albanese has put to them Australia’s case on the US-imposed tariffs and wants to talk about the future of the AUKUS nuclear-powered submarines agreement, which is currently under a 30-day review by the Pentagon. Albanese has managed just three phone calls and no face-to-face meetings with the US president. A ratcheting up of tariffs is hardly ideal for the US. The Australian strategy with the Trump administration, according to the trade minister, is focused on calm and clear-headedness and looking to diversify on key areas of national concern. Albanese worked with ambassador to the US Kevin Rudd in Kananaskis. Before leaving Canada, the prime minister announced that Australia will start talks on a security and defence partnership with the European Union. Farrell says that the person who wins a negotiation is the person who knows what they want and sticks to it. Farrell says it’s still not clear what the Americans want out of their trade relationship generally, but more specifically, what they want out of the relationship with Australia. Australia wants clarity on whether the “new minimum” on tariffs is going to be zero or the 10 per cent “baseline” applied on April 5 to Australian goods imported into the US. The tariffs were blocked from coming into effect in late May by a US federal court, and the Trump administration is appealing against the ruling. The 50 per cent tariffs that were also announced on products such as steel and aluminium are not affected by the ruling. Australia’s position remains that the tariffs are unjustified, as America has enjoyed a roughly 2:1 trade surplus with this country since the 1950s. Moreover, the two nations have a legally binding free trade agreement. Farrell says that Australia is actively seeking trading and security partners other than the US. Farrell says we are now selling more wine to China than before the trade freeze of several years ago. Progress has been made on a free trade agreement with India, and one with the United Arab Emirates is due to start in a few weeks. Negotiations with the European Union over a free trade agreement are more challenging, Farrell says, though he sees “plenty of positive signs”. Farrell cites “good meetings” with the new EU trade commissioner Maroš Šefčovič. One thing America wants is a reliable source of critical minerals and rare earths – 36 of them in particular. Farrell says Australia has a well-deserved reputation for honouring contracts and needs access to capital to take advantage of one of the world’s largest mineral reserves. The fate of the AUKUS agreement remains front and centre. The Albanese government took some comfort from a slight exchange at the G7 between Trump and British prime minister Keir Starmer, in which the latter described AUKUS as an “important deal”. Doubts persist about the timeline for the delivery of the promised Virginia-class subs from the US, and the plans to build SSN-AUKUS nuclear-powered subs in Adelaide. Under Secretary of Defense for Policy Elbridge Colby – who is leading the Pentagon’s review of the AUKUS deal – has long been sceptical of AUKUS. The Albanese government regards the review as “routine”. US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said it had come about after “long, personal conversations” with AUKUS counterparts, John Healey in the UK and Australia’s Defence Minister Richard Marles. The group of Labor Party members Labor Against War wants someone within the caucus to challenge the whole $368 billion AUKUS proposition.

title: Chinatown, Uptown business owners worry about tariffs as Trump's trade war continues
content: Higher costs and uncertainty are the latest challenge for Asian-owned business with ties to China, the target of Trump’s trade wars.
resumen:
The article discusses the concerns of business owners in Chinatown and Uptown, Chicago, regarding tariffs imposed during President Trump's trade wars, particularly those targeting China.

Spencer Ng, owner of Triple Crown restaurant in Chinatown, stated that after Trump ordered 145% tariffs on China in April, some vendors raised prices on ingredients from China, such as Sichuan peppercorns and red chili. The price for a case of canned water chestnuts jumped to $55 in May, compared to $35 the previous year. Costs for canned bamboo shoots and green tea have also increased. Takeout containers, commonly made in China, have increased from $25 per case last year to $32, and plastic tablecloths have increased from 25 cents each to 45 cents. Ng hasn’t raised menu prices. He estimated the overall cost of most ingredients and supplies have increased 10%-25%, or more. Monthly bills from his meat distributor were about $14,000 last year but are now about $22,000. After U.S.-China trade talks in London last week, Trump said the U.S. will get a “total of 55% tariffs, China is getting 10%.”

Aina Lei, manager of Sea Cucumber City, an herbal medicine and snacks store in Chinatown, stated that 80% of products come from China. The store at 247 W. Cermak Road has raised prices of some goods from China in recent months. For example, dried lotus seeds were $13 per pound in April but rose to $16.50 per pound last month.

Clayton Xu, policy manager at the Coalition for a Better Chinese American Community, said neighborhood shops that sell sundries from China are especially vulnerable to tariffs.

Chettha Saetia, economic development director at the Chinese Mutual Aid Association based in Uptown, stated that tariffs have raised costs by as much as 25% for businesses that import ingredients and supplies from China. He has advised them to diversify sourcing away from China to Vietnam and Thailand.

Peter Yuen, owner of La Patisserie P in Uptown, said costs have rocketed for red bean paste and melon cake ingredients that only come from China. Sacks of flour from China made from U.S. wheat costs $75, compared to $35 a year ago.

title: PM Wong to visit China, where he will discuss cooperation to strengthen rules-based order
content: This is his first visit to China as prime minister. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen:
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will visit China from June 22 to June 26.
He will discuss broader regional and global developments with Chinese leaders, and explore how both countries can work together to strengthen multilateralism and the rules-based international order.
He hopes to build closer ties with Chinese leaders, especially with President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Qiang.
Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Guo Jiakun announced the visit on June 20, stating that PM Wong will be meeting Mr. Xi, Mr. Li and Mr. Zhao Leji, chairman of the National People’s Congress.
PM Wong said that the US had helped shape the global order after World War II, which is now under strain as America signals a desire to pull back from it.
He believes the new global order will be shaped by countries both large and small.
PM Wong will emphasize the importance of upholding a rules-based multilateral order when he attends a World Economic Forum event in Tianjin next week, the Annual Meeting of the New Champions, commonly known as Summer Davos.
He acknowledged that today’s multilateral system is not perfect, but said it should be reformed and improved – not abandoned – to better serve all countries.
PM Wong said that the increasingly fragmented global environment poses challenges for a small, open economy like Singapore, which depends heavily on trade.
Singapore is working with like-minded partners to uphold free trade and a rules-based system.
Singapore is also strengthening ties with key Asian economies such as China, India, Japan and South Korea, while reaching out to further markets in the European Union, Latin America, and Africa.
PM Wong described the relationship between Singapore and China as “a very close and steadfast partnership”.
A key objective of his trip to China will be to reaffirm a shared commitment to bilateral cooperation, as Singapore and China mark the 35th anniversary of diplomatic ties.
The cooperation led to the three government-to-government projects of Suzhou Industrial Park, Tianjin Eco-city and Chongqing Connectivity Initiative.
In the interview, he expressed confidence in China’s economy despite global headwinds.

title: Una visión estadounidense de cómo terminar la guerra comercial y construir un nuevo orden económico global
content: Trump ha mostrado poco interés en adoptar un enfoque más deliberado y metódico en las negociaciones o en recalibrar sus medios para alcanzar fines más alcanzables. Pero el caos desatado por sus ...
resumen:
El artículo presenta una propuesta de Emily Kilcrease y Geoffrey Gertz publicada en la Revista Foreign Affairs el 9 de junio de 2025, sobre cómo detener la guerra comercial y reordenar la economía global desde una perspectiva estadounidense.

Los autores argumentan que, a pesar del comportamiento errático de Trump, EEUU conserva ventajas estructurales para liderar un nuevo esfuerzo comercial. Proponen que la administración Trump debe construir un nuevo conjunto de reglas y normas que faciliten la integración entre Estados con ideas afines y los desvinculen de los adversarios, especialmente China.

Kilcrease y Gertz señalan que EEUU lideró la creación de normas económicas tras la Segunda Guerra Mundial, pero China ha ascendido alejándose de los principios del mercado, creando fricciones en el orden económico global.

Para lograr una victoria en las guerras comerciales, la administración Trump debe usar los aranceles como palanca para alcanzar objetivos comerciales claros y alcanzables, priorizando objetivos.

Los autores proponen que EEUU debe colaborar con sus socios comerciales para negociar un reajuste del sistema comercial, flexibilizando el principio de no discriminación y aceptando que la política comercial diferenciará entre los socios comerciales.

EEUU debería seguir comerciando con China en manufactura de bajo costo, agricultura y algunas otras áreas, pero en sectores más estratégicos, Trump debería priorizar la reducción del riesgo de China.

Para compensar la pérdida comercial, Washington deberá profundizar la integración económica con socios y aliados afines, coordinando el uso de controles de exportación, supervisión de inversiones y medidas de seguridad de datos.

Kilcrease y Gertz postulan que Trump debería aspirar a un orden futuro compuesto por círculos concéntricos: profunda integración económica y de seguridad para aliados y socios cercanos; intercambio predecible y basado en normas entre la mayoría de los países; y una cuidadosa reducción del riesgo de los competidores.

Para lograrlo, Washington debería buscar establecer compromisos jurídicamente vinculantes con sus socios cercanos.

title: Banco Central alerta por alza en precio del petróleo: podría acelerar la inflación
content: El Banco Central de Costa Rica mantuvo su TPM en 4%, en gran parte, por la alta volatilidad que han mostrado los precios internacionales del petróleo.
resumen:
El Banco Central de Costa Rica (BCCR) señaló el más reciente aumento en el precio del petróleo como la principal amenaza inflacionaria para el país.
Róger Madrigal, presidente del ente emisor, afirmó que si el precio del crudo mantiene esta tendencia alcista y se sitúa en torno a $78 por el resto del año, la inflación entrará en su rango meta, de entre 2% y 4%, en el último trimestre de este año. En caso contrario, lo haría hasta el tercer trimestre de 2026.
Si el precio del petróleo se mantiene en $78 hasta finales de 2025, la inflación en Costa Rica ingresaría al rango de tolerancia en el cuarto trimestre de 2025.
La probabilidad de que esto ocurra es del 47%.
El efecto primario de un choque externo es un precio del combustible más caro.
El ente emisor indicó que, en la medida en que persista el incremento en el precio internacional del petróleo, es esperable un traslado directo de la inflación importada hacia la inflación local.
La tendencia al alza de los hidrocarburos se atribuye a la reciente escalada de conflictos geopolíticos, particularmente en Medio Oriente.
La Junta Directiva del Banco Central resolvió mantener la tasa de política monetaria (TPM) en 4%.
El precio del petróleo es un precio crítico para toda la economía.
William Porras, economista de Ecoanálisis, recalcó que existe incertidumbre respecto al precio del petróleo.
El Banco Central explicó que el contexto de alta inestabilidad global se vio exacerbado por la volatilidad de los precios internacionales del petróleo y añadió que no controla el impacto de choques exógenos.
El BCCR puede responder ante los posibles efectos de segunda ronda que estos choques externos generen sobre la inflación, en especial sobre las expectativas.
De concretarse el escenario, el BCCR deberá actuar con prudencia para no exacerbar las presiones inflacionarias.
En febrero de 2022, la invasión de Rusia a Ucrania provocó un repunte en los precios.
En agosto del 2022, el índice de precios al consumidor (IPC) alcanzó el 12,13%.
El 5 de julio de ese año, entró en vigor en Costa Rica una ley para congelar durante seis meses los aumentos por inflación en el impuesto a las gasolinas y el diésel.
El barril de West Texas Intermediate (WTI) cerró por encima de los $73 el 19 de junio.
Si la inflación se sale totalmente del rango de control, el ente emisor deberá evaluar sus acciones.
Alonso Alfaro, economista jefe del Banco Central, explicó que, para justificar un eventual aumento de la TPM, deberían presentarse condiciones como: una inflación creciente cercana o superior a la meta del 3%, que el indicador se aproxime al límite superior del rango de tolerancia (4%) o que las expectativas inflacionarias a futuro aumenten significativamente.
El nivel actual de la TPM, en 4%, es coherente con una postura de política monetaria neutral.
El comportamiento del precio del petróleo fue una de las principales razones por las que el BCCR mantuvo su TPM en 4%.

title: In a tit-for-tat move, EU bars China from 150-bn euro govt medical supplies market
content: The decision on medical devices comes at a time of heightened trade tensions with President Donald Trump’s United States, which has imposed customs surcharges on imports from all over the world, inclu ...
resumen: The EU banned Chinese firms from government medical device purchases worth more than five million euros ($5.8 million) in retaliation for limits Beijing places on access to its own market. The latest move covers a wide range of healthcare supplies, from surgical masks to X-ray machines, that represent a market worth 150 billion euros in the EU. The EU's trade commissioner Maros Sefcovic said the aim is to level the playing field for EU businesses. The European Commission said the move was in “response to China’s longstanding exclusion of EU-made medical devices from Chinese government contracts.” Just under 90 percent of public procurement contracts for medical devices in China “were subject to exclusionary and discriminatory measures” against EU firms. In addition to barring Chinese firms from major state purchases, “inputs from China for successful bids” would also be limited to 50 percent. In April 2024, the commission opened an investigation into Chinese public contracts for medical devices, the first under a new mechanism introduced by the EU in 2022 to obtain better access to overseas state purchases. After a year of negotiations, the commission said it had failed to make any progress with China.

title: Canadian tariffs on US steel and aluminum could rise depending on trade talks, Carney says
content: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney, who met with Trump at the Group of Seven meetings in Alberta this week, reiterated Thursday that Canada and the US “agreed to pursue negotiations toward a deal ...
resumen: Canadá, a través de su Primer Ministro Mark Carney, impondrá nuevas tarifas a las importaciones de acero y aluminio de EE. UU. el 21 de julio, dependiendo del progreso de las negociaciones comerciales con el Presidente de EE. UU. Donald Trump. Carney, quien se reunió con Trump en las reuniones del Grupo de los Siete en Alberta esta semana, reiteró que Canadá y EE. UU. "acordaron continuar las negociaciones para llegar a un acuerdo en los próximos 30 días". Canadá ajustará sus contra-aranceles existentes sobre los productos de acero y aluminio de EE. UU. el 21 de julio a niveles consistentes con el progreso realizado en el acuerdo comercial más amplio con Estados Unidos. Trump ha impuesto aranceles del 50% al acero y al aluminio, así como aranceles del 25% a los automóviles. Trump también está cobrando un impuesto del 10% a las importaciones de la mayoría de los países, aunque podría aumentar las tasas el 9 de julio, después de que expirara el período de negociación de 90 días establecido por él. Canadá y México enfrentan aranceles separados de hasta el 25% que Trump implementó con el pretexto de detener el contrabando de fentanilo, aunque algunos productos aún están protegidos en virtud del Acuerdo entre Estados Unidos, México y Canadá de 2020 firmado durante el primer mandato de Trump. Canadá es el mayor proveedor extranjero de acero, aluminio y uranio a EE. UU. y tiene 34 minerales y metales críticos que el Pentágono desea. Casi 3.6 mil millones de dólares canadienses (2.6 mil millones de dólares) en bienes y servicios cruzan la frontera cada día. Canadá es el principal destino de exportación para 36 estados de EE. UU. Trump anunció con el Primer Ministro Británico Keir Starmer que habían firmado un marco comercial el lunes que se anunció previamente en mayo. El marco comercial incluía cuotas para proteger contra algunos aranceles, pero la línea de base del 10% permanecería en gran medida, ya que la administración Trump está apostando a los ingresos arancelarios para ayudar a cubrir el costo de sus recortes de impuestos sobre la renta.

title: Las empresas chinas ponen la mira en Brasil
content: Ante los aranceles y el escrutinio en Estados Unidos y Europa, las marcas de consumo chinas apuestan por convertirse en nombres conocidos en la mayor economía de América Latina.
resumen:
Las empresas chinas necesitan urgentemente encontrar nuevos mercados debido a la intensa competencia en su país y las tensiones comerciales.

Algunas de las mayores marcas chinas de internet y comercio electrónico han puesto sus miras en establecerse en el sudeste asiático, Medio Oriente y Sudamérica, con Brasil como el premio más codiciado.

Meituan, la mayor empresa china de reparto de comida a domicilio, declaró en mayo que invertiría 1000 millones de dólares en Brasil.

Mixue, la empresa china de té y postres, dijo que contratará a miles de personas allí.

TikTok Shop se lanzó en Brasil en mayo.

Vey-Sern Ling, asesor de renta variable en Singapur del banco privado Union Bancaire Privée, dijo que las exportaciones y la expansión en el extranjero son una forma de apoyar el crecimiento continuo.

El valor global del comercio entre China y Brasil se duplicó aproximadamente en la última década.

Empresas chinas anunciaron planes para invertir unos 4700 millones de dólares en Brasil, incluyendo proyectos de minería y energías renovables y la ampliación de la fabricación de automóviles.

El presidente de Brasil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, se reunió con el líder chino, Xi Jinping en Pekín.

Jianggan Li, director ejecutivo de Momentum Works, afirmó que la relación entre los dos países es buena y esperan que lo sea durante un tiempo.

Shein tiene tres almacenes cerca de São Paulo.

Didi se hizo con una empresa emergente brasileña llamada 99 en 2018.

Temu, la rama internacional de la empresa china de comercio electrónico Pinduoduo, empezó a vender productos a los brasileños el año pasado.

Los envíos de Temu y Shein están sujetos a un impuesto sobre los paquetes de menos de 50 dólares desde el año pasado.

Ernan Cui, analista de consumo de la firma de investigación Gavekal Dragonomics en Pekín, dijo que una regulación más estricta y una competencia más dura están añadiendo presión.

Meaghan Tobin cubre temas de negocios y tecnología en Asia, con especial atención a China.

title: Las empresas de Gipuzkoa, moderadamente optimistas pese a la incertidumbre internacional
content: La institución guipuzcoana ha animado a las compañías del territorio a perseverar en la diversificación de sus ventas ...
resumen: Las empresas de Gipuzkoa afrontan el futuro con «moderado optimismo» pese a la incertidumbre internacional, agravada por el conflicto entre Israel e Irán, que podría tener efectos sobre el comercio internacional y el precio del petróleo, según advierte la Cámara. La institución guipuzcoana ha animado a las compañías del territorio a perseverar en la diversificación de sus ventas, especialmente hacia mercados extracomunitarios, en los que ya se observan «resultados alentadores». El presidente y el director general de la Cámara de Gipuzkoa, Mauricio Arregui y Javier Zubia, respectivamente, han hecho esta reflexión este viernes en una rueda de prensa en San Sebastián en la que han presentado los resultados de la encuesta cuatrimestral de perspectivas económicas elaborada por esta entidad. Arregui ha asegurado que las compañías del territorio prevén estabilidad e incluso crecimiento pese al contexto internacional que, según advierte, sigue siendo «complicado e incierto». Mauricio Arregui ha hecho un llamamiento a reforzar la competitividad de las empresas y del territorio «apostando por un ecosistema más ágil, menos burocrático y orientado a la colaboración público-privada». Ha animado asimismo a las compañías a ahondar en la diversificación de sus ventas, especialmente hacia mercados extracomunitarios. Australia, India, Marruecos, Arabia Saudita y Emiratos Árabes Unidos son algunas de las apuestas de la Cámara, que confía también en que prospere el acuerdo comercial entre la Unión Europea y Mercosur, que incluye a Brasil y Uruguay, ha recordado Zubia. El presidente de la Cámara ha insistido en la necesidad de estar preparados para afrontar amenazas como «los cambios abruptos en los mercados, la fragmentación del comercio internacional o la escasez de recursos estratégicos» como la energía, los minerales o las tierras raras. El estallido del conflicto entre Israel e Irán puede tener un impacto importante en el comercio internacional y el precio de la energía. En los últimos diez días el precio de petróleo ha crecido un 17 % y el del gas natural un 20 %. En cuanto a EEUU, tercer destino de las exportaciones de las firmas guipuzcoana, Zubia ha dicho que «seguirá siendo un mercado importante» para las firmas del territorio y que, en todo caso, habrá que esperar a que se concrete el efecto de los aranceles de la administración Trump. La encuesta de la Cámara muestra que las empresas guipuzcoanas mantienen, a nivel general, un clima de confianza y estabilidad con previsiones moderadamente optimistas para el conjunto del año en términos de actividad, inversión, exportaciones y empleo. Sectores como el de la automoción o determinados bienes de equipo atraviesan mayores dificultades. La cámara mantiene invariable la previsión de crecimiento de la economía Gipuzkoa, que fijó en un 2,1 % para 2025. Los principales factores de preocupación entre las empresas se repiten, de nuevo, y se reparten entre los costes laborales y la reducción de los márgenes, la desaceleración de la demanda, la dificultad para captar talento cualificado y el exceso de carga regulatoria y burocrática que la Cámara pide atajar.

title: Carney: Canadian tariffs on U.S. steel, aluminum could rise, depending on progress of trade talks
content: Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney said Thursday he will impose new tariffs on U.S. steel and aluminum imports on July 21 depending the progress of trade talks with U.S. President Donald Trump.
resumen: Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney said Thursday he will impose new tariffs on U.S. steel and aluminum imports on July 21 depending the progress of trade talks with U.S. President Donald Trump. Carney met with Trump at the Group of Seven meetings in Alberta this week, and reiterated Thursday that Canada and the U.S. "agreed to pursue negotiations toward a deal within the coming 30 days." Carney said: "In parallel, we must reinforce our strength at home -- and safeguard Canadian workers and businesses from the unjust U.S. tariffs. That's why today we are announcing Canada will be introducing a series of countermeasures to protect Canadian steel and aluminum workers and producers. First, Canada will adjust its existing counter-tariffs on U.S. steel and aluminum products on July 21 to levels consistent with progress made in the broader trading agreement with the United States." Carney said Trump's trade war is running the risk of a global recession. Trump has imposed 50 percent tariffs on steel and aluminum as well as 25 percent tariffs on autos. Trump is also charging a 10 percent tax on imports from most countries, though he could raise rates on July 9, after the 90-day negotiating period set by him would expire. Canada and Mexico face separate tariffs of as much as 25 percent that Trump put into place under the auspices of stopping fentanyl smuggling, through some products are still protected under the 2020 U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement signed during Trump's first term. Canada is the largest foreign supplier of steel, aluminum and uranium to the U.S. and has 34 critical minerals and metals that the Pentagon is eager for. Nearly $3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($2.6 billion) worth of goods and services cross the border each day. Canada is the top export destination for 36 U.S. states. Trump announced with British Prime Minister Keir Starmer that they had signed a trade framework Monday that was previously announced in May. The trade framework included quotas to protect against some tariffs, but the 10 percent baseline would largely remain as the Trump administration is banking on tariff revenues to help cover the cost of its income tax cuts. Carney didn't say if he would sign a deal with the U.S. if any tariffs remain in place on Canada.

title: Semana breve en mercados: incertidumbre global y alta volatilidad marcan el escenario
content: La situación actual se ve agravada por los aranceles de Estados Unidos y la inquietud provocada por Donald Trump en el comercio. La tensión global afecta el rendimiento de los mercados.
resumen: La situación actual se ve agravada por los aranceles de Estados Unidos y la inquietud provocada por Donald Trump en el comercio. Los aranceles continúan siendo un obstáculo significativo para el comercio a nivel internacional, y la inestabilidad vinculada a la figura de Donald Trump se constituye como un reto adicional para los mercados en el corto plazo, según analistas del sector. La intensificación del conflicto en Medio Oriente contribuye a un ambiente de incertidumbre, donde el ámbito político empieza a determinar el rumbo de la economía. "Mantenerse invertido -respetando el perfil de riesgo de cada inversor- permanece como la mejor opción", explica Flavio E. Castro, experto en gestión de activos de la firma Criteria. Desde el denominado “Día de la Liberación”, cuando Trump modificó nuevamente su enfoque comercial, se produjeron varios acontecimientos de gran relevancia: se disminuyeron los aranceles al 10% para la mayoría de los países, se reanudaron las negociaciones de alivio con China, y la política exterior volvió a ser tema central, señala Castro. A finales de 2024, el S&P 500 estaba cerca de los 5.900 puntos. Al cierre del 16 de junio, se ubica por encima de los 6.000 puntos, acumulando más de un 2% de aumento en dólares. En ese mismo lapso, el índice llegó a estar en terreno negativo con una caída de -17%, tomando precios de cierre y registró dos de los mayores retornos diarios de los últimos cinco años. Desde Criteria mantienen su enfoque de largo plazo: evitar decisiones impulsivas. "El verdadero efecto de las políticas proteccionistas y de los cambios en el comercio internacional sobre las ganancias de las empresas sólo se podrá evaluar con mayor claridad en los próximos trimestres", concluyen. La estrategia sigue siendo no entrar en pánico, y se sostiene la convicción de que el sector de acciones de gran capitalización y crecimiento tecnológico continuará liderando el avance positivo en los mercados, como ha ocurrido hasta la fecha. El negocio relacionado con las grandes tecnologías se mantiene firme. Nvidia, UnitedHealth y Alphabet son empresas que no solo se destacan por su sólida generación de flujos de efectivo y fuertes posiciones de liquidez, sino también por sus bajos niveles de endeudamiento y su continua inversión en bienes de capital, lo que refuerza aún más su posición estratégica a largo plazo, detalló Castro.

title: Las oportunidades de inversión están más cerca de lo que uno piensa
content: El inversionista peruano de alto patrimonio tiende a minimizar su exposición a activos locales sobre todo en lo que a renta variable se refiere.
resumen:
El inversionista peruano de alto patrimonio tiende a minimizar su exposición a activos locales sobre todo en lo que a renta variable se refiere.
El PEN ha demostrado ser una moneda muy estable a lo largo de los últimos 30 años, gracias a la solidez económica del país y al excepcional manejo del BCR.
El home bias es un sesgo que tienen los inversionistas a favorecer los activos financieros de sus propios países o de la región en comparación con inversiones de países extranjeros.
En Latinoamérica, también vemos una marcada presencia del home bias en casi todos los países con excepciones como las de Perú.
Mientras que inversionistas de Colombia, Chile o Brasil tienden a asignar un porcentaje importante de su portafolio a instrumentos de renta fija y variable de emisores locales, el inversionista peruano de alto patrimonio tiende a minimizar su exposición a activos locales sobre todo en lo que a renta variable se refiere.
Podemos encontrar al menos tres motivos que explican este comportamiento: i) el inversionista peruano tiene una marcada inclinación a guardar sus excedentes en dólares, ii) el inversionista peruano, acostumbrado a vivir en un país con alta inestabilidad, tiende a diversificar su portafolio de inversiones del riesgo país, ya que asume mucha exposición a dicho riesgo a través de sus negocios, su trabajo, sus propiedades inmobiliarias, entre otros; y iii) la falta de instrumentos en soles peruanos (PEN) con niveles razonables de liquidez.
Siendo residentes peruanos, afrontamos muchos de nuestros gastos en PEN, lo cual hace razonable mantener cierto nivel de esta moneda en la diversificación estratégica de activos de nuestros portafolios para cubrir ciertos objetivos de vida.
Hoy, por ejemplo, existen oportunidades de inversión en algunas acciones locales que pagan niveles de dividendo muy atractivos y que se encuentran a precios bastante descontados.
El inversionista de largo plazo residente en Perú no debería dejar pasar por alto este tipo de oportunidades.

title: Embajador ruso afirma enterarse del arribo de RT a Chile por la TV y dice desconocer su financiamiento
content: Resumen generado con una herramienta de Inteligencia Artificial desarrollada por BioBioChile y revisado por el autor de este artículo. El embajador de Rusia en Chile, Vladimir G. Belinsky, abordó la l ...
resumen:
El embajador de Rusia en Chile, Vladimir G. Belinsky, se enteró de la llegada de RT a Chile por la TV, al igual que muchos chilenos. Descartó haber tenido algún rol en el arribo de la estación rusa a las pantallas de Chile.

Belinsky afirma que el balance de la llegada de RT es positivo porque se trata de información nueva. Asegura desconocer cómo se financia la programación de la emisora rusa en las pantallas chilenas.

Belinsky menciona que todos los canales que emitan información abierta, positiva y constructiva, son siempre bienvenidos en Rusia.

Belinsky respondió a las críticas sobre el control de los medios de prensa en Rusia, mencionando la Constitución y las limitaciones en cuanto a incitaciones destructivas.

Belinsky afirmó que en el sitio web de RT hay publicidad y que hay periodistas chilenos trabajando en RT, incluyendo a Rick Sánchez.

Belinsky está seguro de que la agenda de RT en América Latina y en Chile es positiva y que es un paso positivo para Chile y para Rusia también.

Belinsky mencionó que en el comunicado de la embajada hay un proverbio antiguo de Rusia que dice “Mejor una vez ver que cien veces escuchar sobre algo”.

Belinsky no tiene información sobre cómo se financia RT en Chile, pero entiende que es un acuerdo comercial.

Belinsky mencionó que el conflicto en Ucrania es un tema aparte y que hay dos datos importantes sobre los sucesos en Bucha y los niños desaparecidos.

Belinsky dice que Rusia tiene una buena experiencia de intercambio con todos los sectores políticos chilenos.

Belinsky destaca el servicio diplomático de Chile, al que califica como “muy profesional”.

Belinsky asegura que los lazos entre los gobiernos de Rusia y Chile son sólidos, pese a la postura crítica del presidente Gabriel Boric.

Belinsky considera que la oferta de material de defensa es un tema comercial.

Belinsky mantiene la posición de que la solución de cualquier problema debe estar en manos de los propios países involucrados.

Belinsky enfatizó en “el rol de terceros” en la crisis migratoria desatada por el contexto en Venezuela.

Belinsky responde que “poner etiquetas a países y medirlos por un termómetro, un manómetro democrático, es una cosa bastante subjetiva”.

title: How Iran-Israel conflict affects India's overseas trade
content: The commerce ministry on Friday held consultations with key stakeholders, including shipping lines, exporters, container firms, and other departments, to assess the impact of the Iran-Israel conflict ...
resumen: On Friday, the commerce ministry held consultations with key stakeholders to assess the impact of the Iran-Israel conflict on India's overseas trade. The meeting was chaired by Commerce Secretary Sunil Barthwal. Participants informed that the situation in the Strait of Hormuz is currently stable and a ship reporting system is in place. The freight and insurance rates are also being closely monitored. The commerce secretary emphasized the need to assess the evolving situation and its impact on Indian trade and highlighted the importance of exploring all possible alternatives. Exporters stated that the war, if escalated further, would impact world trade and push both air and sea freight rates. They expressed apprehensions that the conflict may impact the movement of merchant ships from the Strait of Hormuz and the Red Sea. Nearly two-thirds of India's crude oil and half of its LNG imports pass through the Strait of Hormuz, which Iran has now threatened to close. This narrow waterway, only 21 miles wide at its narrowest point, handles nearly a fifth of global oil trade and is indispensable to India, which depends on imports for over 80 per cent of its energy needs. According to think tank GTRI, any closure or military disruption in the Strait of Hormuz would sharply increase oil prices, shipping costs, and insurance premiums, triggering inflation, pressuring the rupee, and complicating India's fiscal management. The present conflict that began with an attack on Israel on October 7, 2023 had brought cargo movement through Red Sea routes to a halt due to attacks by Houthi rebels on commercial shipping. Around 80 per cent of India's merchandise trade with Europe passes through the Red Sea, and substantial trade with the US also takes this route. Both these geographies account for 34 per cent of the country's total exports. The Red Sea Strait is vital for 30 per cent of global container traffic and 12 per cent of world trade. India's exports to Israel have fallen sharply to $2.1 billion in 2024-25 from $4.5 billion in 2023-24. Imports from Israel came down to $1.6 billion in the last fiscal from $2.0 billion in 2023-24. Similarly, exports to Iran, amounting to $1.4 billion, which were at the same level in 2024-25 as well as in 2023-24, could also suffer. India's imports from Iran were at $441 million in FY25 as against $625 million in the previous year. The conflict adds to the pressure that the world trade was under after the US President Donald Trump announced high tariffs. Based on the tariff war impact, the World Trade Organisation (WTO) has already said that global trade will contract 0.2 per cent in 2025 as against the earlier projection of 2.7 per cent expansion. India's overall exports had grown 6 per cent on year to $825 billion in 2024-25.

title: India assesses Iran-Israel conflict's impact on trade
content: India's commerce ministry will meet stakeholders to assess the impact of the Iran-Israel conflict on its trade, particularly concerning oil imports and crucial shipping routes like the Strait of ...
resumen:
India's commerce ministry will meet stakeholders to assess the impact of the Iran-Israel conflict on its trade, particularly concerning oil imports and crucial shipping routes like the Strait of Hormuz and the Red Sea. The meeting will be held on Friday and chaired by Commerce Secretary Sunil Barthwal. Stakeholders include shipping lines, exporters, container firms, and other departments.

Exporters have stated that the war, if escalated further, would impact world trade and push both air and sea freight rates. They have expressed apprehensions that the conflict may impact the movement of merchant ships from the Strait of Hormuz and the Red Sea.

Nearly two-thirds of India's crude oil and half of its LNG imports pass through the Strait of Hormuz, which Iran has now threatened to close. This narrow waterway, only 21 miles wide at its narrowest point, handles nearly a fifth of global oil trade and is indispensable to India, which depends on imports for over 80 per cent of its energy needs.

According to think tank GTRI, any closure or military disruption in the Strait of Hormuz would sharply increase oil prices, shipping costs, and insurance premiums, triggering inflation, pressuring the rupee, and complicating India's fiscal management.

Israel's June 14-15 strike on Houthi military leadership in Yemen has also heightened tensions in the Red Sea region, where Houthi forces have already attacked commercial shipping. Nearly 30 per cent of India's west-bound exports to Europe, North Africa, and the US East Coast travel through the Bab el-Mandeb Strait, now vulnerable to further disruption, the GTRI has said.

The present conflict that began with an attack on Israel on October 7, 2023, had brought cargo movement through Red Sea routes to a halt due to attacks by Houthi rebels on commercial shipping.

Around 80 per cent of India's merchandise trade with Europe passes through the Red Sea, and substantial trade with the US also takes this route. Both these geographies account for 34 per cent of the country's total exports. The Red Sea Strait is vital for 30 per cent of global container traffic and 12 per cent of world trade.

India's exports to Israel have fallen sharply to USD 2.1 billion in 2024-25 from USD 4.5 billion in 2023-24. Imports from Israel came down to USD 1.6 billion in the last fiscal from USD 2.0 billion in 2023-24.

Similarly, exports to Iran, amounting to USD 1.4 billion, which were at the same level in 2024-25 as well as in 2023-24, could also suffer. India's imports from Iran were at USD 441 million in FY25 as against USD 625 million in the previous year.

The World Trade Organisation (WTO) has already said that global trade will contract 0.2 per cent in 2025 as against the earlier projection of 2.7 per cent expansion.

India's overall exports had grown 6 per cent on year to USD 825 billion in 2024-25.

title: The ‘Green New Scam’ Is a Red-State Boon
content: House Republicans want to repeal tax credits for clean-energy projects, and the industry is already slowing. But the jobs and benefits would boost GOP-leaning states and congressional districts.
resumen:
House Republicans want to repeal tax credits for clean-energy projects, and the industry is already slowing. The jobs and benefits would boost predominantly GOP-leaning states and congressional districts.

President Donald Trump vowed in early April that he would “supercharge our domestic industrial base.”

U.S. House Republicans found billions of dollars in savings by slashing over a dozen clean-energy tax credits enacted in the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act under President Joe Biden.

The mega-bill, which passed the GOP-led House on May 22 in a 215-214 vote, would effectively strip away the Advanced Manufacturing and Production Credit and other incentives.

These incentives have bolstered the production of batteries and solar components in numerous states — top among them North Carolina, Georgia, Michigan, South Carolina, Indiana, Tennessee, Texas, Nevada, Illinois and Oklahoma, according to the Clean Investment Monitor, a joint project by the Rhodium Group and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s Center for Energy and Environmental Policy Research.

U.S. senators are now negotiating the massive budget reconciliation legislation.

Kevin Doffling, CEO and founder of Project Vanguard, warned pulling the plug on the clean-energy tax credits will stifle progress the U.S. has made against other countries, namely China. Doffling’s organization works in several states, including Arizona, Colorado, Indiana, Minnesota, Washington and Utah.

The IRA’s Advanced Manufacturing and Production Credit is awarded per unit produced and sold, and in some cases the capacity of energy output. Battery cell manufacturers can earn up to $35 per battery cell multiplied by potential kilowatt hours. In the case of solar, the credit offers producers 7 cents per solar module multiplied by wattage output. For mining operations extracting critical minerals, such as lithium, companies can receive a 10 percent tax break on the costs of production.

Most credits phase out by 2032 under the Biden-era law, except those for critical mineral mining, which continue.

A group of House Republicans, who have dubbed the tax credits the “green new scam” — echoing Trump’s rhetoric — pushed to accelerate the expiration in the final version of the mega-bill, even for critical mineral mining and production.

The House-passed bill also severely tightens language around foreign components, titled “foreign entities of concern,” making the credit practically unusable as many parts of the clean-energy manufacturing supply chain are global, industry professionals say.

The legislation also repeals “transferability,” which allows companies with little or no tax liability to sell the credits.

Schneider Electric, a global corporation with a U.S. base in Massachusetts, has facilitated 18 transfer deals worth $1.7 billion in tax credits for U.S. companies since 2023.

Silfab Solar, which recently built a solar cell manufacturing and module assembly plant in Fort Mill, South Carolina, announced in mid-May the sale of $110 million in Advanced Manufacturing and Production Credits to help fund its expansion.

Actual investment in clean-energy manufacturing since August 2022 reached $115 billion in April, up from $21 billion over the same length of time prior to the IRA, the Clean Investment Monitor found.

Of the 380 clean technology production facilities announced since the third quarter of 2022, 161 are now operational, according to CIM data.

Mike Williams, senior fellow at the liberal Center for American Progress and former deputy director of the BlueGreen Alliance, said the credit spurred a “sea change” in U.S. clean-energy manufacturing.

Active manufacturing of solar components, advanced batteries and wind turbines and vessels is concentrated in rural areas. Most are located in states that went red in the 2024 presidential election, according to the Clean Power America Association’s May 2025 State of Clean Energy Manufacturing in America report.

The renewable energy policy group estimated the industry supports 122,000 full-time manufacturing jobs across the U.S.

Active solar manufacturing sites and expansions are clustered in Texas, Ohio and Alabama, according to data from the association. Should major project announcements in Georgia pull through, the state would surpass Alabama for third place.

Advanced battery manufacturing spans 38 states, with the largest concentrations in California, Michigan and North Carolina.

Lithium, a critical mineral for battery production, is currently mined in Nevada and California. And investors are eyeing other spots in the U.S., namely Alaska, to mine and produce graphite, another critical mineral.

China largely dominates the world’s critical mineral supply chain, according to U.S. Geological Survey data for 2024.

Just over 312,900 new jobs are linked to the industry, the bulk in Republican-led congressional districts, according to the advocacy group Climate Power’s 2024 report on clean-energy employment.

Troy Van Beek, CEO and founder of the Iowa-based solar company Ideal Energy, said his business weathered the pandemic and has been able to add jobs, but is now facing uncertainty again.

The industry has seen a pullback since January and the beginning of the Trump presidency.

Six announced projects representing $6.9 billion in investment were canceled in the first quarter of 2025, according to the Clean Investment Monitor’s latest State of U.S. Clean Energy Supply Chains report.

Van Beek said recent talks to strike a deal with a solar manufacturer collapsed after threats to the tax credits.

Spencer Pederson of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association said the unpredictability is interrupting how operators are planning for the coming years.

Some House Republicans, led by Rep. Jen Kiggans of Virginia, urged party colleagues to protect the clean-energy tax credits. Her co-signers included Don Bacon of Nebraska, Mark Amodei of Nevada, Rob Bresnahan of Pennsylvania, Juan Ciscomani of Arizona, Gabe Evans and Jeff Hurd of Colorado, Dave Joyce of Ohio and Dan Newhouse of Washington, who all eventually voted for the final bill.

Far-right House members won on not only shortening the lifespan of the credits, but also on keeping the restrictive foreign entity language and on repealing a company’s ability to transfer credits.

The right-leaning National Taxpayers Union hailed the “commonsense changes” championed by the far-right House Freedom Caucus, under the leadership of Maryland Rep. Andy Harris.

According to the Penn Wharton Budget Model, the credits as of 2022 were valued at roughly $384.9 billion over 10 years.

Jeannie Salo, chief public policy officer at Schneider Electric, said in a statement to States Newsroom that “the Senate should restore and extend the timelines for key energy and manufacturing credits and their transferability to ensure the nation continues to attract key investments and projects that will power the U.S. economy and help make energy more affordable.”

Pederson said the restrictions on foreign components and company ties are “particularly restrictive coming out of the House.”

Doffling believes senators have a “longer-term vision” of the nation’s energy strategy than House members who face reelection every two years.

title: Exportadores guatemaltecos ven con preocupación aranceles de EE.UU.
content: También ven que con gran preocupación un nuevo recargo impuesto por algunas navieras. CIUDAD DE GUATEMALA — El sector exportador de Guatemala manifestó este jueves su preocupación ya que se ...
resumen:
El sector exportador de Guatemala manifestó su preocupación por los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos y un nuevo recargo impuesto por algunas navieras.

El director de la junta directiva de la Asociación de Exportadores de Guatemala, Alejandro Toledo, indicó que se encuentran con la "soga al cuello" tras un recargo de 200 dólares por contenedor impuesto por algunas navieras en el puerto de Santo Tomás de Castilla.

El nuevo recargo fue instalado por las navieras "aduciendo que hay congestión en el puerto".

El nuevo recargo "podría traducirse en un impacto económico de más de 6.5 millones de dólares para el país en el segundo semestre del año".

El sector exportador "está siendo gravemente amenazado" al sumar "una serie de obstáculos a la competitividad en los últimos seis meses".

Entre ellos se encuentra una "infraestructura vial deteriorada", además del aumento al salario mínimo del 10% ordenado por el Gobierno de Bernardo Arévalo de León, la "apreciación del quetzal (moneda guatemalteca) en un 3% recientemente" y los aranceles impuestos por Estados Unidos en abril pasado.

En mayo pasado, una comitiva del Gobierno guatemalteco y del sector empresarial viajó a Estados Unidos para intentar negociar dichos aranceles.

En 2024, el país centroamericano exportó productos y servicios por un total de 14,588 millones de dólares, un 3% más que en 2023.

title: This Loophole Buried in Trump’s Bill Is Anything but Beautiful
content: It is hard to think of a less coherent pair of policies: President Trump’s tax policy encourages the very offshoring that his tariffs are intended to stop.
resumen: President Trump’s tax policy encourages the very offshoring that his tariffs are intended to stop. The pharmaceutical industry is worth more than $600 billion. Mr. Trump and his associates have repeatedly criticized companies’ moves to offshore much drug making, particularly to Ireland. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said on April 13, “We can’t be beholden and rely upon foreign countries for fundamental things that we need.” The tax incentives in Mr. Trump’s 2017 tax and spending package helped generate this problem. Mr. Trump’s Tax Cuts and Jobs Act created a loophole that made it far more profitable for the pharmaceutical giants, including Eli Lilly, Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson and Merck, to manufacture some of their most profitable drugs in Ireland. America’s imports of pharmaceuticals soared to $250 billion in 2024, way up from $110 billion in 2016. American companies now report earning about $350 billion in profits annually in the world’s major centers of corporate tax avoidance, which include Ireland, Luxembourg, Singapore and a handful of others. Semiconductor equipment producers and other Big Tech companies use the same special tax break. The tax code offers a far lower 10.5 percent tax rate for global profits if a global company moves the profits from its intellectual property offshore. The tax rate for domestic profits is 21 percent. The tax break was created by Republicans. Pharmaceutical companies could cut their total tax bill in half by transferring their intellectual property to a subsidiary overseas. Big Pharma began reporting to the I.R.S. that it earned almost all of its income abroad. Apple uses the same 2017 provision, and its overall tax rate has been around 15 percent in a typical year. Apple is now paying the largest share of its corporate tax in Ireland. Tariffs risk raising the price of all medicines and will increase the prices of many generic medicines. Passing the Close the Round-Tripping Loophole Act that the Senate Finance Committee members Ron Wyden, Mark Warner, Raphael Warnock and Peter Welch just introduced would be a very welcome step in the right direction.

title: Companies are reconsidering how much they want to spend on consulting
content: The consulting industry has been facing some headwinds lately, from a drop in government contracts to changing spending priorities at businesses.
resumen:
El sector de la consultoría se enfrenta a dificultades, como la disminución de los contratos gubernamentales y el cambio de prioridades de gasto de las empresas.

Accenture reportó unos ingresos de 17.700 millones de dólares para el trimestre que finalizó el 31 de mayo. Las acciones de la empresa cayeron un 3,6% en las operaciones previas a la apertura del mercado después de que dijera que las nuevas reservas disminuyeron un 6% en el tercer trimestre.

Las empresas están tratando de adoptar un enfoque de bricolaje para la resolución de problemas en lugar de recurrir a consultores.

Durante la pandemia, muchas empresas recurrieron a consultores.

Las empresas se enfrentan a la incertidumbre económica y a una guerra comercial.

Algunas empresas recurren a consultores para que les ayuden a reducir costes, mientras que otras están menos interesadas en pagar a personas externas para que les digan qué hacer.

Las empresas han estado gastando mucho en inteligencia artificial, lo que deja menos espacio en el presupuesto para el asesoramiento de los humanos.

title: Don’t Lose Sight of the Oligarchy
content: Last weekend’s massive “No Kings” rallies proved Donald Trump’s deep unpopularity. But Trump should be opposed as a symptom of America’s vast warmongering, oligarchic elite, not a simply a grotesque ...
resumen:
The "No Kings" protests last weekend were a landmark in the movement against the second Trump administration. The scale of the rallies was remarkable, with estimates varying from two to six million protesters around the country. Many protesters were older and more politically moderate than typical attendees at other rallies. The protests reached deep into Trump-voting country.

Trump has acted like a king, often bypassing the need for approval from other branches of government. He has largely succeeded in imposing tariffs unilaterally, changing trade policies based on his personal whims. He has sent armed National Guard troops to back up ICE raids, arrested and threatened to deport legal permanent residents for free speech, and sent immigrants to a prison in El Salvador without due process. He may be on the brink of getting the United States into a war in Iran without Congressional approval.

In the early months of the administration, the biggest displays of public outrage against Trump were Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s “Fighting Oligarchy” rallies, which combined pushback against Trumpist authoritarianism with a broader critique of economic inequality. Sen. Elissa Slotkin (D-MI) pushed back against the “Fighting Oligarchy” slogan, proposing "No Kings" instead.

The issue in dispute between her and Sanders and AOC goes deeper than semantics. Slotkin wants to stick to the “political question” of democracy and authoritarianism, rather than broaching the “social question” of economic power and hierarchy.

Trumpism came into existence because of a wildly unequal and economically precarious society, which made the neoliberal centrism of the Democratic Party unappealing. Democrats and liberals largely responded to the rise of Trump with an empty defense of procedural democracy without tying this defense to how democracy can improve the lives of ordinary people.

The message needs to be clear: No Kings? Absolutely. But also No Oligarchy.

Emerging long-term opportunities in quantum computing.

title: Tariff Impact on Consumer Prices Could Hit This Summer, Economists Warn
content: Economists say consumers will likely feel the pinch later this summer as inventories shrink and global tensions rise.
resumen: The Federal Reserve voted to keep interest rates unchanged at Wednesday’s (June 18) FOMC meeting. Fed chair Jerome Powell said he expects “meaningful” inflation soon, noting that some of the cost burden from the Trump administration’s tariffs “will fall on the end consumer.” Four months after President Trump began imposing tariffs on major U.S. trade partners, consumer prices have remained relatively stable. May inflation came at 2.4 percent. One key factor holding inflation down is a continued decline in shelter costs, which make up the largest portion of the Consumer Price Index (CPI). Since Feb. 1, President Trump has enacted a sweeping series of tariffs via executive orders, most notably the “Liberation Day” tariffs announced on April 2 targeting about 90 countries. While Trump has paused the majority of those tariffs for 90 days, existing levies are still at record high levels. Economists widely agree that the full inflationary impact of tariffs may take months to materialize. Stephen Stanley, chief U.S. economist at Santander, expects CPI to rise to 3 percent by the end of this year, with noticeable increases starting in June and July. According to data from WarehouseQuote, the cost of bonded warehouse space has surged, now running four times higher than regular storage rates after having merely doubled in early 2024. Inventory can be held in these facilities for up to five years. KPMG economist Diane Swonk told Observer, “The largest inventory buildup happened in March, right before the ‘Liberation Day’ tariffs,” and “After Trump’s election, companies began stockpiling inventory out of fear of impending tariffs.” Ongoing trade negotiations between the White House and key trade partners are expected to conclude before July 8, when the 90-day pause expires. Economists say we’ll likely see the impact of tariffs on inflation later this summer, as companies run out of inventory and start selling goods that cost more to import. The escalating conflict between Israel and Iran—particularly fears over the potential closure of the Strait of Hormuz, a critical shipping lane through which 20 percent of the world’s oil supply flows—has added to inflation anxiety. Following Israel’s June 13 attack on Tehran, the price of crude oil surged 13 percent to $77.18 per barrel, though it has since eased to around $74. KPMG’s Swonk projects that a temporary oil price spike to $85 per barrel, followed by a pullback to $74, could lift global inflation to 4.1 percent in 2025. That’s up from her previous forecast of 3.7 percent, which had already accounted for expected tariff impacts. Because of the new tariffs, markets have lowered their expectations for interest rate cuts this year. Meanwhile, speculation is growing that Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent could be tapped to succeed Powell when his term ends next year.

title: Fed Governor Calls for Rate Cuts as Soon as July
content: Christopher J. Waller, who was appointed by President Trump, said the central bank should not wait for the labor market to weaken.
resumen:
Christopher J. Waller, an influential governor on the Federal Reserve, said the nation’s central bank should begin lowering interest rates as early as July.
Mr. Waller said the Fed could act as soon as next month, citing the fact that its main reason for holding off — price increases from the president’s tariffs — may prove only temporary.
Mr. Waller’s stance puts him at odds with some members of the Fed, including Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair.
Mr. Waller, who was appointed by Mr. Trump, suggested that the Fed could begin cutting rates more quickly than many had expected given this week’s policy statement and economic projections.
He described the job market as “solid,” but also acknowledged recent data showing that some Americans, including college graduates, are experiencing difficulty in finding employment.
He said some of those indicators were “suggesting that maybe the labor market is starting to soften more than we might want it to.”
Mr. Waller also said he did not believe trade policy, in particular, would produce a sustained, long-term bout of inflation, explaining that “not all of this is going to be passed through” to consumers.
Mr. Waller said of interest rates, “I think we’ve got room to bring it down,” and later added, making the case that the Fed has room to “start the process" as soon as next month.
Mr. Powell reiterated that the central bank was not in a hurry to act, especially when the full effects of Mr. Trump’s tariffs and other geopolitical developments were not yet clear.
Mr. Powell reaffirmed his commitment to a “wait and see” approach, as officials continue to assess how Mr. Trump’s policies may affect the central bank’s dual mandate of stable prices and maximum employment.
Mr. Powell said, prices remain steady, while there is “nothing that’s troubling” in the labor market.
Mr. Powell also acknowledged that it might take months before policymakers could truly measure the impact of the president’s policies.
Mr. Powell said, “Everyone that I know is forecasting a meaningful increase in inflation in coming months from tariffs because someone has to pay for the tariffs.”
Fed officials released new economic projections this week that showed a potential disagreement in the central bank’s approach to cutting rates later this year.
Some officials still penciled in two rate cuts this year, but nine of the 19 policymakers forecast the Fed’s doing far less.
Seven policymakers forecast no more reductions in 2025, and two predicted just one quarter-point move.
Mr. Trump has called for as much as a 2.5-percentage-point rate cut.
Mr. Trump lamented at an event at the White House this week, as he attacked Mr. Powell again for refusing to lower rates.
Mr. Waller appeared to rule out supporting a steep, immediate reduction, saying on Friday that the Fed should “start slow.”
He also maintained that it was not the Fed’s job to use interest rate cuts as a way of guaranteeing “cheap financing to the U.S. government.”
The benchmark interest rate is in a range of 4.25 to 4.5 percent.

title: La entrada al banco de los Brics: una decisión costosa en medio de crisis fiscal
content: Para poder acceder a esa entidad de desarrollo del bloque multilateral, deberá comprar títulos por la menos $2,1 billones.
resumen: Colombia fue aceptada como miembro del Nuevo Banco de Desarrollo de los Brics. Para ingresar, Colombia debe comprar acciones por al menos $2,1 billones (US $512,5 millones), pero no será socio ni tendrá voto en las cumbres del bloque económico. El Nuevo Banco de Desarrollo de los Brics se creó con un capital de US $100.000 millones. El exministro de Hacienda, José Manuel Restrepo, rector de la universidad EIA, dijo que la inversión que se realiza en relación a costo-beneficio es poca respecto a la disponibilidad de recursos y que conseguir esa fuente de recursos puede representar algo así como $2 billones. La presidenta de la Cámara Colombo Americana, AmCham Colombia, María Claudia Lacouture, compartió que la diversificación es necesaria y debe ser una prioridad para Colombia. La representante a la Cámara Lina Garrido, del Partido Cambio Radical, cuestionó el entusiasmo del Gobierno frente al anuncio. El Nuevo Banco de Desarrollo (NDB) es una entidad financiera multilateral fundada en 2014 por Brasil, Rusia, India, China y Sudáfrica. Desde marzo de 2023, la presidencia del NDB está en manos de Dilma Rousseff, expresidenta de Brasil.

title: U.S. Heading to Record Ag Trade Deficit
content: From changing consumer demand and strength of currency to new market opportunities such as the U.S.–U.K. trade agreement, understanding what’s driving the deficit is key to supporting U.S. farmers, ...
resumen: The U.S. agricultural trade deficit is widening in 2025. From January through April, the United States imported $78.2 billion in agricultural products while exporting just $58.5 billion, resulting in a $19.7 billion deficit. This is the largest ever recorded for the first four months of a year. The U.S. has been in an agricultural trade deficit since 2022. In fiscal year (FY) 2023, the trade gap reached $16.7 billion and nearly doubled in FY 2024 to $31.8 billion. USDA forecasts the FY 2025 deficit will rise to approximately $49.5 billion. In FY 2025, USDA projects that horticultural products will account for approximately 49% of total agricultural imports by value. U.S. agricultural export value, after reaching record highs in 2022, has since declined. In May 2025, the United States and the United Kingdom announced a new trade agreement. The UK represents a high-value export destination for U.S. agriculture, with total exports reaching approximately $2.18 billion in 2024. The deal removes key U.K. tariffs, including the 20% duty on U.S. beef.

title: BofA raises STOXX 600 target amid resilient global growth, warns on Mideast risks
content: STOXX 600 target raised to 530 by BofA, citing resilience, but outlook stays cautious amid ongoing global risks ...
resumen: Bank of America Global Research boosted its year-end projection for the STOXX 600 index to 530 from 500 on Friday, citing sustained resilience in global GDP following a recent truce in US-China trade talks. The pan-European benchmark, which closed Thursday at 535.86, is still around all-time highs. BofA retains a cautious attitude on European equities generally, retaining a “negative” outlook on the region’s stock market. The brokerage stated that the main reason for the resilience is that events like the Israel-Iran conflict and trade war have not yet translated into a clear-cut weakening of global growth. The new projection suggests a tiny 1.1% decline from the index’s previous closing. In the face of escalating geopolitical friction, from the trade war to the Israel/Iran tensions, European equities have generally shrugged off the impact. BofA warned that these changes could have an impact on global economic growth in the second half of the year. BofA upgraded European mining stocks to “overweight” from “market weight” in a change of sector strategy. Airlines were lowered to “underweight” from “market weight.” BofA sees the sector as being at risk of higher oil prices, particularly if the situation in the Middle East spirals even further out of control. The STOXX 600’s impressive performance this year has occurred against a backdrop of mixed economic indicators. BofA’s revised projection seeks to reconcile these dynamics by recognizing short-term strength while being cautious about structural and geopolitical risks. The brokerage’s higher year-end prediction for the STOXX 600 indicates increased near-term optimism but does not represent a significant shift in mood.

title: The Iran Emergency
content: Iran built its most critical nuclear enrichment facility, Fordo, deep inside a mountain to shield it from attacks. See illustrations that show how tough it would be to attack.
resumen:
President Trump said Iran “cannot have a nuclear weapon” but was perhaps “a few weeks away from having one.”

Israel is the nation that sprang to action and Trump is debating whether to help out.

Trump may let Israel use America’s “bunker-buster” bomb — and the plane to drop it — to try to destroy a uranium-enrichment site buried underground.

The White House says Trump will decide “within the next two weeks” if he’ll assist Israel’s effort.

U.S. intelligence agencies continue to believe that Iran has not yet decided whether to make a nuclear bomb, but that it may redouble its efforts if the U.S. attacks Fordo or if Israel kills its supreme leader.

Trump administration officials are racing to finalize trade deals with as many countries as possible before a July 9 deadline, when higher tariffs are set to snap back into effect.

A federal appeals court ruled that Trump could continue using the California National Guard to respond to protests in Los Angeles.
