title: China is trying to win over Africa in the global trade war
content: Total trade between China and Africa was worth $296bn in 2024. Yet the value of what China exported west ($179bn) was much higher than what Africa sent east ($117bn). This year, partly as a result of ...
resumen:
En China Mall, un supermercado en Kampala, Uganda, Rose Ahurra compra un juguete. Las compras indican su lugar en la clase media ugandesa, que ha acudido en masa a China Mall desde que abrió este año. El comercio total entre China y África fue de $296 mil millones en 2024. El valor de lo que China exportó al oeste ($179 mil millones) fue mucho mayor que lo que África envió al este ($117 mil millones). Este año, las exportaciones chinas al continente van camino de ser un 12% más altas. China anunció el 12 de junio que concederá acceso libre de derechos a los productos de todos los países africanos, excepto Eswatini.

Después de 25 años, Estados Unidos está a punto de poner fin a su propio acuerdo libre de derechos con África cuando la Ley de Crecimiento y Oportunidad para África (AGOA) expire el 30 de septiembre. China se ha vuelto más importante en el comercio africano en el siglo XXI. En 2003, solo 18 de los entonces 53 países de África comerciaban más con China que con Estados Unidos. Dos décadas después, ese es el caso de 52 de los 54 estados de África. La gran mayoría de este comercio es de materias primas. La mayoría de las exportaciones africanas a China provienen de tres países: Angola, Congo y Sudáfrica.

Hasit Shah, que exporta aguacates de Kenia a China (y actualmente se enfrenta a un arancel del 7%), dice que la medida "realmente nos ayudará contra la fruta peruana", que ya se beneficia de derechos del 0%. Maryna Calow de Wines of South Africa, espera que haga que el vino local sea competitivo con las variedades australianas y chilenas que ya disfrutan de derechos cero al entrar en China. Omar Bagersh, un empresario del café, dice que "la fiabilidad del suministro y los cuellos de botella estructurales", como la calidad de la logística y la burocracia, son mayores puntos de estrangulamiento.

Deborah Brautigam de la Universidad Johns Hopkins cree que los aranceles cero podrían tener un gran impacto "en un pequeño número de países de ingresos medios" que ya fabrican bienes competitivos. Carlos Lopes de la Universidad de Ciudad del Cabo argumenta que se necesita "un conjunto de políticas más deliberadas para incluir a África en las cadenas de valor". Joshua Eisenham de la Universidad de Notre Dame dice que la política de aranceles cero es un "golpe maestro político" por parte de China. Wu Peng, embajador de China en Sudáfrica, dice que muestra cómo "tomaremos acciones reales para contribuir a la industrialización y modernización de África".

Los gobiernos africanos están ofreciendo incentivos a Estados Unidos. El primer elemento es desplegar la alfombra roja para las empresas estadounidenses, sobre todo Starlink, el proveedor de Internet por satélite de Elon Musk. Congo firmó un acuerdo en mayo. Lesotho también ha abierto su mercado. La segunda parte de la oferta es la minería. Madagascar está presentando una mina de uranio; Sudáfrica está discutiendo el cromo con funcionarios estadounidenses; Congo está dando la bienvenida a la inversión estadounidense en una mina de litio; y Namibia está abierta a la inversión en una gama de tierras raras. La tercera es decir que, incluso cuando sus propios ciudadanos se enfrentan a posibles prohibiciones, aceptarán a los migrantes deportados de Estados Unidos.

title: Tariff shockwaves: Indonesia’s export strategy under fire
content: While trade negotiations between Indonesia and the US is still underway, the archipelago must reassess its non-tariff measures to address US concerns while ensuring fair trade practices and ...
resumen: The article discusses the potential impact of US reciprocal import tariffs on Indonesia's export strategy. The US is considering reciprocal tariffs, which could disrupt global trade. The Tax Foundation cited the decline in competitiveness of US industries, widening inequality, and insufficient job creation as reasons for the tariffs. Researchers suggest that permanent import tariffs have a modest impact on reducing trade deficits, and temporary tariffs can trigger a recession. The article notes that the Indonesian government must reassess its non-tariff measures due to US sanctions. The US had a services-trade surplus of US$1.6 billion in 2023 despite a goods-trade deficit with Indonesia. Indonesia can pursue bilateral negotiations with the US, consider Preferential Trade Agreements, and leverage its status under the US Generalized System of Preferences. Indonesia's average Most Favoured Nation tariffs in 2023 were around eight per cent. In the short term, Indonesia can supply goods that complement exports from heavily tariffed nations. Over the long term, Indonesia can attract FDI into intermediate-goods manufacturing and expand its diplomatic outreach. Internal reforms to enhance the business climate, raise productivity, and lower high-cost economic structures are essential. Stronger enforcement against illegal imports and more robust anti-dumping measures will protect domestic industries. Maintaining an independent foreign policy and preparing for non-economic conditions will round out its readiness. The authors are Mervin Goklas Hamonangan and Mohamad Dian Revindo.

title: The Fed Isn’t Calling It ‘Stagflation,’ but the Risks Are Rising
content: President Trump’s trade war is likely to lead to higher prices and slower growth, a challenging combination for the Fed. War in the Middle East could make the job harder still.
resumen: Las proyecciones económicas publicadas por los funcionarios de la Fed mostraron que el crecimiento se desaceleraría bruscamente este año, el desempleo aumentaría y la inflación repuntaría. Los funcionarios de la Fed dijeron que esperaban que el PIB creciera a una tasa de solo el 1,4 por ciento este año, por debajo de la tasa del 1,7 por ciento que predijeron en marzo. Esperan que los precios al consumidor suban un 3 por ciento este año, significativamente por encima de su pronóstico de marzo del 2,7 por ciento. Y esperan que el desempleo suba al 4,5 por ciento, frente al 4,4 por ciento en su pronóstico anterior. Joseph Brusuelas, economista jefe de la firma de contabilidad RSM, ha descrito el escenario como "stagflation lite". La guerra de Israel contra Irán ha provocado un aumento brusco pero hasta ahora relativamente modesto de los precios del petróleo. Alan S. Blinder, economista de Princeton y ex vicepresidente de la Fed, señaló que los episodios de estanflación en Estados Unidos a mediados y finales de la década de 1970 siguieron a los picos de los precios del petróleo. La invasión rusa de Ucrania en 2022 condujo a un aumento de los precios de la energía y los alimentos que contribuyó al aumento de la inflación posterior a la pandemia. El riesgo, agregó Brusuelas, es que los formuladores de políticas se vean atrapados en el medio y esperen demasiado para responder en cualquier dirección, lo que conduciría a una inflación excesiva o una recesión. Powell, el presidente de la Fed, no fue preguntado directamente sobre la estanflación en su conferencia de prensa del miércoles, y no la mencionó. Powell fue menos circunspecto hace un año, antes de que Trump regresara al cargo y amenazara con interrumpir los esfuerzos de la Fed para gestionar la economía posterior a la pandemia. Preguntado en mayo del año pasado sobre los riesgos de estanflación, fue despectivo, argumentando que el crecimiento aún era sólido y que la inflación se estaba enfriando.

title: Mientras EU caza migrantes y se autoflagela, China se reorienta para entrar al mundo
content: Las deportaciones masivas de Trump han golpeado a industrias clave que dependen en gran medida de los trabajadores que se encuentran ilegalmente en el país.
resumen:
China está transformando las economías y la geopolítica al enviar productos a otros países a un ritmo que no se había visto antes. El superávit comercial de China con el resto del mundo asciende a casi 500 mil millones de dólares, un aumento de más del 40 por ciento con respecto al mismo período del año anterior. China tiene muchos productos que necesita exportar, y aunque Estados Unidos le imponga aranceles, es prácticamente imposible detener los cambios en los flujos.

Estados Unidos tiene otras prioridades. Las industrias clave en Estados Unidos dependen en gran medida de trabajadores que viven ilegalmente en el país. La agresiva campaña de deportación de Trump ha chocado con una realidad económica.

El Departamento de Seguridad Nacional ordenó a los agentes de inmigración que suspendieran los arrestos en granjas, restaurantes y hoteles, enfatizando que las redadas deberían centrarse en las personas que se encuentran en Estados Unidos sin documentos y tienen antecedentes penales.

Donald J. Trump publicó en Truth Social que las operaciones de deportación masiva de inmigrantes ilegales son una misión muy importante.

La Secretaria de Agricultura, Brooke Rollins, escribió que las interrupciones graves en el suministro de alimentos perjudicarían a los estadounidenses.

La Secretaria de Seguridad Nacional, Kristi Noem, redobló los esfuerzos de la Administración para deportar a millones de personas que viven en el país sin documentos.

El Gobierno de Trump y otros conservadores argumentan que la inmigración irregular ha privado de empleos a los trabajadores estadounidenses, ha deprimido los salarios y ha saturado los recursos públicos.

Los inmigrantes que viven sin papeles en Estados Unidos representan aproximadamente el 4.4 por ciento de la fuerza laboral estadounidense, según un análisis de Goldman Sachs de los datos del censo de 2023. Su participación en la fuerza laboral en algunos sectores es mucho mayor: 19 por ciento en servicios de paisajismo, 17 por ciento en producción agrícola, 16 por ciento en sacrificio y procesamiento de animales, y 13 por ciento en construcción.

Aproximadamente 12 millones de personas emigraron a Estados Unidos entre 2021 y 2024, según la Oficina de Presupuesto del Congreso.

title: China has emerged as a linchpin of global trade stability amid uncertainties: Chinese scholar
content: Intelligent welding robots perform precise and efficient welding operations at an automobile manufacturing enterprise in Jiangdu High-Tech Industrial Development Zone, Yangzhou, East China's Jiangsu ...
resumen: China has emerged as a linchpin of global trade stability amid uncertainties. The Geneva talks in May and the first meeting of the China-US economic and trade consultation mechanism in June have produced meaningful progress. The key to reaching these agreements lies in the recognition of economic losses caused by trade frictions initiated by the US. Recent negotiation outcomes offer hope for a de-escalation in China-US trade relations. In the medium to long term, the consultation mechanism established in Geneva is poised to provide a framework for ongoing communication and joint risk management. Challenges such as geopolitical volatility, unpredictable US policies, and tech barriers targeting China still pose risks. Stable trade relations help anchor global market expectations and facilitate trade and investment. The two economies are deeply interdependent, with strong complementarity and shared interests. There is vast potential for collaboration in areas such as services trade, two-way investment, climate change, public health, and energy transition, particularly in artificial intelligence (AI) and clean energy. China and the US have complementary needs in trade, while also facing competition in high-tech sectors. Technology-driven changes will accelerate supply chain realignment and industrial restructuring, impacting bilateral trade dynamics. If the US persists in using tariffs as its primary "weapon" against China, it risks long-term failure. High tariffs would also harm the US economy by raising business costs, negatively affecting consumers, fueling domestic inflation, and undermining international competitiveness. Unilateral tariff use breaches multilateral trade rules, disrupts supply chains, and may provoke international backlash, potentially isolating the US politically and economically. China has shown strategic resolve in the face of rising global trade protectionism. China upholds multilateralism, promotes free trade, and deepens international cooperation, while remaining committed to higher-level opening-up. China has implemented proactive measures to boost consumption and investment, solidifying its economic foundation. Structural reform, and innovation-driven growth have further strengthened economic resilience, ensuring long-term economic stability. By 2025, China has emerged as a linchpin of global trade stability. China will further integrate global supply chains, serving as a key engine of global economic growth and advocating for an open world economy. China also actively supports reforms in global governance, advocating a fairer and more equitable international economic order. China's foreign trade and economy will maintain strong resilience, supported by a range of policy tools to navigate internal and external pressures and meet growth targets. Priorities include stabilizing trade, promoting investment, diversifying exports, and scaling up high tech manufacturing through targeted policies. Domestic consumption is set to grow via stimulus measures aimed at upgrading demand, while innovation-driven growth and industrial optimization will be prioritized, particularly in AI and digital economy sectors. Financial reforms will ensure moderately loose monetary policies, maintain ample liquidity, and provide greater support for venture capital, bank credit, insurance, and capital markets. The resilience of foreign trade is set to improve, innovation-led expansion will become more prominent, and structural upgrades will continue to gain traction, fueling strong development momentum. China's ability to withstand external shocks, such as US tariffs, and its endogenous growth drivers will be further reinforced. By diversifying markets, enhancing self-reliance in supply chains, and expanding exports of high-value-added products, China will significantly bolster its role and influence across the global trade system. China actively engages in global governance and advocates for building a community with a shared future for mankind. The article is based on an exclusive interview with Tian Xuan, president of the National Institute of Financial Research at Tsinghua University.

title: Political War Erupts Over PM-Trump Call As BJP Accuses Congress of G7 Forgery
content: A political controversy has erupted over a call between Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Donald Trump. The Congress, led by Jairam Ramesh, claims there is no proof of Modi's counter to Trump. The BJP ...
resumen: Una controversia política ha estallado por una llamada entre el Primer Ministro Narendra Modi y Donald Trump. El Congreso, liderado por Jairam Ramesh, afirmó que no hay pruebas de la respuesta del Primer Ministro Modi a Trump. El BJP respondió, acusando a Ramesh de usar un comunicado de enero de 2025 de EE. UU. y amplificar la supuesta falsedad de Trump. El portavoz del BJP declaró: "El Primer Ministro Narendra Modi ji... nunca, jamás, por ninguna oportunidad política, política oportunista, por ninguna razón, comprometerá lo que cree que es el interés de la India". El Primer Ministro Modi y el Presidente de EE. UU. Trump tuvieron una conversación telefónica de 35 minutos. Modi aclaró que EE. UU. no tuvo ningún papel en mediar el cese al fuego entre India y Pakistán, y no hubo discusión sobre un acuerdo comercial entre EE. UU. e India durante las hostilidades. La llamada se centró en el ataque terrorista en Pahalgam, Jammu y Cachemira, y la respuesta de India. Modi explicó el cambio de India en la política antiterrorista e invitó a Trump a la próxima Cumbre Quad en India.

title: El G-7 cierra una cumbre deslucida por la crisis en Oriente Próximo y la marcha de Trump
content: La cumbre del G-7 en Kananaskis (Canadá), eclipsada por la crisis entre Irán e Israel, concluyó este martes sin un comunicado conjunto y sin haber podido consensuar una declaración sobre la situación ...
resumen:
La cumbre del G-7 en Kananaskis (Canadá) concluyó sin un comunicado conjunto y sin haber podido consensuar una declaración sobre la situación en Ucrania.

La reunión estuvo marcada por la repentina marcha del presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, y las crecientes tensiones en Oriente Próximo.

Los líderes emitieron media docena de declaraciones sobre asuntos puntuales.

El primer ministro canadiense, Mark Carney, presentó una “declaración del presidente” a modo de resumen.

En la declaración estaba incluido un apartado dedicado a Ucrania.

La delegación estadounidense no aceptó el lenguaje empleado en el borrador sobre Ucrania y trató de diluirlo.

Carney anunció una nueva batería de sanciones contra Moscú, y un nuevo paquete de ayuda para el país invadido, por valor de 4.300 millones de dólares canadienses (unos 2.700 millones de euros).

El Gobierno británico anunció un acuerdo de su primer ministro, Keir Starmer, y de Zelenski para dar un impulso a la “siguiente etapa” de la asistencia militar a Kiev.

Trump se marcharía de Kananaskis para regresar a Washington y convocar una reunión de su Consejo de Seguridad Nacional.

Los líderes aseguraban entender que Trump sintiera la necesidad de regresar a Washington ante la gravedad de la crisis en Oriente Próximo después de que Israel atacara objetivos militares y del programa nuclear de Irán.

El presidente francés, Emmanuel Macron, dejó clara su resistencia a una posible acción militar contra Irán.

Trump rechazó suscribir la declaración conjunta sobre Oriente Próximo hasta que no se eliminó un llamamiento a Israel para rebajar la tensión.

El comercio fue otra de las áreas de desencuentro.

Los aliados de EE UU aspiraban a aproximar posiciones con Trump sobre los aranceles.

Starmer logró que Trump estampara su firma en un acuerdo que exime de aranceles a la industria aeronáutica británica y recorta al 10% los que impone al sector automotor de ese país.

La Unión Europea esperaba acelerar las negociaciones para evitar los aranceles del 50% con los que Trump amenaza a partir del 9 de julio.

La presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, aseguró que las conversaciones progresaban.

title: Anthony Scaramucci on how to handle Trump: «Treat him like he’s a reality TV producer»
content: Anthony Scaramucci, the Wall Street financier who briefly worked as Donald Trump's White House communications director, once believed the president would help heal a divided nation. Now, he says, he ...
resumen: Anthony Scaramucci, the former White House communications director, supported Donald Trump's 2016 campaign and served on the transition team. He now considers Trump a danger to the country. Scaramucci believes he made a mistake supporting Trump. He says he was fired because he pointed out to Trump that he didn't think it was a good idea to veto sanctions against Russia. Scaramucci says Trump is offended by advice. He broke with Trump by August 2019. Scaramucci says the way to handle Trump is to treat him like he's a reality television producer.

title: Market volatility: The price for investing
content: Recent market volatility has been fuelled by a mix of aggressive trade policies, economic uncertainties and rising geopolitical tensions.
resumen: Volatility is the cost of participation in the investment process. Recent market volatility has been fueled by aggressive trade policies, economic uncertainties, and rising geopolitical tensions. President Trump’s ‘Liberation Day’ tariff announcement, imposing a baseline 10% duty on nearly all imports, with some reaching 145% on Chinese goods, ignited immediate retaliatory actions, primarily from China, leading to a sharp global market decline. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York forecasts inflation may reach 4% by 2025, alongside slowing growth under 1% and rising unemployment. The Trump trade war has triggered market volatility, created turmoil and significantly heightened the risk of a US recession. Markets have already witnessed gradual rollbacks on policy as political, business and legal pressures mount, and trading partners push for concessions. The COVID crisis disrupted global supply chains and abruptly halted the world economy. During this period, the S&P 500 posted its third-largest single-day gain since 1950, surging 9.5%. The Great Financial Crisis of 2007-2009 resulted in a massive structural overhaul. The Great Depression of the 1930s marked the last time a US president imposed sweeping tariffs through the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act. Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase, noted in a Q1 2025 commentary, “The economy is facing considerable turbulence, including geopolitics, with potential positives from tax reform and deregulation, but significant risks from tariffs, trade wars, persistent inflation, high fiscal deficits, and elevated asset prices and volatility.”. The 10-year and 30-year maturities have been particularly hit, while the two-year yield has moved more in sync with the stock market. This suggests a sharp increase in term premiums, triggered by a sudden aversion to long-maturity US Treasuries. Policymakers globally have been active in adapting to the shifting environment. Germany has introduced more stimulative fiscal measures in the short term, alongside a significant increase in long-term military and defense investments. China has reaffirmed its commitment to a 5% growth target for 2025. Central banks across the globe, including in Canada, Europe, Scandinavia, Australia and New Zealand, have also continued easing policies. Uncertainty creates the conditions for outsized returns. Markets are forward-looking and constantly adjusting to new information. Volatility cuts both ways, as evidenced by the contrasting performance of US and European assets during this period. Maintaining a steady hand allows investors to harness the power of compounding, reinvestment, and timely rebalancing. Richard Maparura is senior portfolio manager, asset management, at Butterfield.

title: “Tenemos un estúpido en la Fed”: la frase de Trump que marca la decisión económica más importante de la semana en Estados Unidos
content: Conozca la más reciente decisión del banco central de Estados Unidos en medio de la política arancelaria de Donald Trump.
resumen: La Reserva Federal mantuvo sus tasas de interés por cuarta reunión consecutiva y degradó sus pronósticos para la economía y la inflación de Estados Unidos. El banco central estadounidense mantuvo sus tasas de referencia entre 4,25% y 4,5%, aunque sigue apostando por dos recortes en lo que resta del año. La Fed espera un PIB al alza de 1,4% este año frente a 1,7% que preveía en marzo y 2,1% en diciembre de 2024. La inflación, según el banco central, será de 3% y no de 2,7% como vaticinó en marzo. Asimismo, prevé un aumento del desempleo a 4,5%, frente a 4,4% esperado antes. Trump presionó por un recorte de tasas y criticó duramente al presidente del banco central, Jerome Powell. Trump dijo: “Francamente, tenemos un estúpido en la Fed, probablemente no recortará hoy”. El índice de precios al consumidor fue de 2,4% interanual en mayo, frente al 2,3% de abril. Un indicador publicado el martes muestra que las ventas minoristas retrocedieron 0,9% en mayo. Mauricio Moya, gestor de Portafolios de Grupo Financiero Mercado de Valores, dice que el mensaje de la Fed incorpora un tono ligeramente hawkish al prever menos recortes en 2025 y 2026 de los que el mercado había descontado previamente.

title: Las presiones con las que tendrá que lidiar la economía en el segundo semestre y que golpearían su dinámica en 2025
content: Colombia tendrá que lidiar en el segundo semestre del año con una serie de presiones, tanto nacionales como internacionales, que harán más difícil que su economía pueda crecer a un ritmo de entre 2,5 ...
resumen:
En el segundo semestre del año, la economía colombiana enfrentará presiones nacionales e internacionales que dificultarán su crecimiento a un ritmo de entre 2,5 y 3 por ciento anual.

Factores externos como la 'guerra' comercial de Estados Unidos, la política migratoria y la escalada bélica entre Irán e Israel, se suman a presiones locales como la inflación, la crisis fiscal, el riesgo país, la posibilidad de bajas en la calificación, un descenso más lento en la tasa de interés del Banco de la República y la incertidumbre política.

La Organización para la Cooperación y el Desarrollo Económico (OCDE) y el Banco Mundial (BM) revisaron a la baja sus proyecciones de crecimiento para Colombia. La OCDE espera un crecimiento del 2,5 por ciento, mientras que el BM recortó su pronóstico del 3 al 2,5 por ciento.

La caída de los precios del petróleo reducirá las exportaciones e ingresos fiscales, aumentando las presiones sobre la posición fiscal.

Corficolombiana mantiene su pronóstico de crecimiento en 2,6 por ciento.

Los economistas de BBVA bajaron su proyección a 2,3 por ciento.

Credicorp Capital mantiene su estimación de crecimiento de 2,3 por ciento para 2025.

El Banco de Bogotá apunta a que el PIB de Colombia se expandirá 2,7 por ciento.

Los analistas de Bancolombia mantienen su pronóstico en 2,6 por ciento.

Los economistas de Grupo Alianza creen que la economía colombiana crecerá entre 2,8 y 3 por ciento.

title: Fed holds interest rates steady, brushing off Trump’s calls for big cuts

title: WTO director defends organisation amid concerns being raised by OECS countries
content: The Director General of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, said on Tuesday that the global community is facing very challenging times with respect to trade and that this is ...
resumen: The Director General of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, addressed the seventh meeting of the OECS Assembly. She stated that the global community is facing challenging times with respect to trade, possibly the most disruptive period since the 1930s. Dominica and Antigua and Barbuda have warned that unless the rules of engagement are observed, “these institutions will not work for us.” Antigua and Barbuda’s Foreign Affairs, Immigration and Trade Minister, E P Chet Greene, said that the Caribbean's danger is the slow suffocation of economies and the stagnation of societies. Okonjo-Iweala said the decision by the United States to impose a tariff on countries, including those in the Caribbean, could result in a contraction of global trade by about 0.2 per cent. United States President Donald Trump has implemented the trade tariffs. Okonjo-Iweala said that the WTO has been modelling every single change. She said that for the OECS countries, their economies are service economies, “and therefore, mainly, are not as impacted by these tariffs as they could have been. Okonjo-Iweala said in her discussions with the United States representatives, the approach of unilateralism to solve the problem was probably not the best one to take. She said article 28 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) enables a member who is no longer pleased with the situation of the tariffs to come back and say to other members, “we want to relook at this.”. She said that the OECS countries will have an occasion to do that at the 14th ministerial meeting of the WTO in March next year. She said developing countries such as the OECS have also been critical of the system, on the grounds that it hasn’t delivered as much for them. Skerrit said that the new world order is moving towards a unilateral system. Antigua and Barbuda’s Foreign Affairs, Immigration and Trade Minister, E P Chet Greene, told the OECS Assembly that many of the major international institutions are in a state of decline.

title: Trump’s Counterproductive Global South Policy
content: Imperialist, exploitative and egocentric — these words describe U.S. policy on the Global South. The policy is deeply ingrained in Trump MAGA agenda, but it’s a loser in the long run.
resumen:
The article, "Trump’s Counterproductive Global South Policy" by Zhou Xiaoming, discusses U.S. policy towards the Global South, characterizing it as imperialist, exploitative, and egocentric, deeply rooted in the Trump MAGA agenda.

In early May, the U.S. renounced the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), specifically the 17 goals adopted by all 193 UN members in 2015, including providing clean water, sanitation, and quality education, and tackling climate change. Edward Heartney, the U.S. counselor for economic and social affairs at the U.S. mission to the UN, stated that the U.S. rejects the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the SDGs because they are inconsistent with U.S. sovereignty and adverse to the rights and interests of Americans.

The author argues that Washington has never been genuinely interested in the development of poor nations, with official development assistance largely serving self-serving purposes, such as gaining market access, promoting values, and engineering regime change, as well as being geopolitically driven.

Donald Trump's renunciation of the SDGs aligns with his general approach to the Global South. The day after he returned to the White House, Trump initiated the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate accord. In May, his administration announced its pullout from the UN-backed Loss and Damage Fund. The Trump administration is attempting to shift U.S. responsibility for climate change cleanup to its own victims.

Trump also pulled the U.S. out of the World Health Organization (WHO). The Trump administration pushes for U.S. defense spending to be increased to $1.01 trillion for fiscal year 2026, a jump of 13 percent year-on-year.

Trump is expected to dramatically slash international development assistance. Secretary of State Marco Rubio stated that aid is designed to further the national interests of the United States.

Trump has tried to extort wealth from the Global South through reciprocal tariffs, which hit developing countries particularly hard. Among 27 countries subject to tariff rates exceeding 30 percent, all but one are from the Global South. Trump’s 37 percent tariff on Bangladesh threatens to decimate the country’s garment industry, which accounts for nearly 85 percent of its exports and employs more 4 million workers. For around 30 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, Trump’s reciprocal tariffs nullify the preferential treatment under the African Growth and Opportunity Act. Lesotho faces the top rate of 50 percent. In contrast, China offers tariff-free access for all imports from all 53 African countries with which it has diplomatic ties.

Trump treats developing countries as inferiors and is obsessed with power politics. He is always ready to wield U.S. power to have his way with poor countries. He loves to set rules for the Global South as he pleases.

In 2018, Trump referred to Haiti and African nations as “shit-hole” countries.

The Trump administration's engagement with the Global South is largely driven by securing access to critical minerals and keeping China down. Trump said he would buy Greenland and threatened to use force to acquire the territory if necessary. In Asia, the Trump administration is actively pursuing a strategic partnership with Indonesia and Uzbekistan. In Africa, it is negotiating with the Democratic Republic of the Congo for cobalt and other strategic minerals. Trump is cultivating personal ties with Argentina’s President Javier Milei, largely aiming at the country’s lithium deposits.

The Trump administration uses interactions to undermine China’s ties with other developing countries. U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent smeared China’s economic and commercial activities in Latin America. The administration coerces countries to sever ties with China. It forced the Panamanian government to quit China’s Belt and Road Initiative and threatened Argentina with withdrawal of U.S. support for loans from the International Monetary Fund.

Trump demands that trading partners scale back Chinese imports and restrict Chinese investment.

Warren Buffet stated that Trump’s Global South policy was a “big mistake.”

title: Austria pushes EU to keep door open for Russian gas after war in Ukraine
content: Austria called on the European Union to leave the door open for the return of Russian gas imports after the conflict in Ukraine is over, while Brussels suggested imposing a complete ban on all Russian ...
resumen: Austria is pushing the EU to keep the door open for Russian gas imports after the war in Ukraine. The European Commission proposed cutting Russian gas imports completely by 2028. Austria called on the EU to leave the option open for the return of Russian gas imports after the conflict. The Austrian energy ministry stated that the bloc "must maintain the option to reassess the situation once the war has ended." Elisabeth Zehetner, Austrian state secretary for energy, made the remarks at an EU energy ministers' meeting in Luxembourg. The European Commission proposed cutting Russian gas imports completely by 2028. The proposed bill aims to create a legally binding ban. EU energy commissioner Dan Jørgensen dismissed Austria's argument. The Commission plan involves invoking a World Trade Organization "security exemption" provision. Austria has long relied on Russian gas, with imports before the war accounting for about 80% of its intake. OMV, Austria's state-owned energy firm, cut ties with Russian gas monopoly Gazprom last December. Leonore Gewessler, Austria's former energy minister, said the new Austrian position was "a totally wrong path." Austria has been importing more gas through Germany. EU imports of Russian liquefied natural gas (LNG) have risen, reaching a record 16.5 million tonnes in 2023. The Commission proposal would also prevent infrastructure projects like the Nord Stream pipelines.

title: Adrian Wooldridge: Reagan wasn’t the conservative he’s made out to be
content: Beneath his cowboy hat, he smuggled two ideas that were anathema to movement conservatives, neoliberalism and neoconservativism, into the heart of Republican ...
resumen: Ronald Reagan is often seen as the quintessential American conservative. However, the author argues that Reagan was an interloper in the conservative tradition, introducing neoliberalism and neoconservatism. Reagan campaigned as a movement conservative but implemented policies that disappointed his followers, such as appointing neoconservatives and establishing the foundations of neoliberalism and neoconservatism. He transformed traditional conservative beliefs into faith in globalization and supported American power and values abroad. George W. Bush, Reagan's "disciple," followed a similar pattern, campaigning as a movement conservative but governing as a neoliberal-neoconservative. Bush's policies, including tax cuts, deregulation, and spreading democracy in the Middle East, led to the Iraq War and a financial crisis. The author suggests that the collapse of the "House that Reagan built" has led to the reassertion of an older type of conservatism, emphasizing protectionism and immigration control. The author believes that a post-Trump Republican Party will not revert back to Reagan's policies.

title: Wall Street ends mixed after the Fed says it’s still waiting to see the effects of Trump’s tariffs
content: U.S. stocks drifted to a mixed finish after the Federal Reserve indicated it may cut interest rates twice this year, though it’s far from certain about that.

title: Trump's trade wars threaten the WTO, and may mean the end of globalization as we know it
content: The World Trade Organization promised a future of unlimited growth, but became a bogeyman for the left. Now its future is increasingly clouded thanks to Donald Trump. A look at globalization's ...
resumen:
The World Trade Organization (WTO) promised unlimited growth but faced criticism, particularly from the left. Its future is threatened by U.S. President Donald Trump, who wants a geoeconomic world order based on his rules. Trump criticized the 1994 WTO agreement, calling it a "disaster for America" and has a strong belief in tariffs. April 2, 2025, when Trump announced "reciprocal tariffs," is seen as a turning point. The U.S., once a champion of open markets, is now undermining the system it created. The WTO has been demonized by the left since its inception 30 years ago.

The liberalization of global trade boosts prosperity, as described by David Ricardo's theory of comparative advantage. In 1947, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) entered into force. The WTO replaced GATT in 1995, aiming for broader liberalization. The WTO, based in Geneva, was intended to resolve disputes. Renato Ruggiero, the first director-general of the WTO, said that the world would be a better place if no country is allowed to discriminate against another.

Critics of globalization warned of "colonialism" and cultural homogenization. The WTO is a secretariat that moderates and coordinates global trade. At the 1999 WTO summit in Seattle, protests escalated. Pat Buchanan, a conservative, opposed "globalists" and predicted factory closures and loss of sovereignty due to the WTO agreement.

Global trade volume increased by 125% by 2008, but major liberalization steps stalled. The unanimity principle has blocked progress. There has been increasing competition for bilateral and regional free trade agreements. China joined the WTO in 2001, and has benefited from it. Trump imposed new tariffs during his first term. The U.S. has crippled the dispute-resolution system by blocking appointments to the Appellate Body since 2019. More than 50 countries have agreed to an alternative dispute-settlement mechanism.

Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala argues that the WTO is not finished. Roberto Azevêdo, Okonjo-Iweala's predecessor, said that the system is dead as it was known.

title: Presidente de la Fed: aranceles de Trump harán subir la inflación en Estados Unidos
content: Jerome Powell, presidente de la Reserva Federal, confirmó que impuestos a las importaciones afectarán economía ...
resumen:
Jerome Powell, presidente de la Reserva Federal, confirmó que los aranceles de al menos el 10% a las importaciones impuestos por el presidente Donald Trump harán subir los precios y afectarán a la economía de Estados Unidos.

El aumento de los aranceles aduaneros este año probablemente impulsará la inflación aunque tarda un tiempo en llegar a la cadena de distribución hasta el consumidor final.

La Fed mantuvo sus tasas de referencia entre 4,25% y 4,5%, aunque sigue apostando por dos recortes en lo que resta del año.

La incertidumbre sobre la perspectiva económica bajó pero sigue alta, en tanto el producto interno bruto (PIB) crecerá menos de lo previsto y la inflación será más elevada.

La Fed espera un PIB al alza de 1,4% este año, frente a 1,7%, que preveía en marzo, y 2,1% en diciembre de 2024.

La inflación, según la Reserva Federal, será de 3% y no de 2,7% como vaticinó en marzo.

Asimismo, prevé un aumento del desempleo a 4,5%, frente a 4,4% esperado antes.

Jerome Powell indicó que debido a que la economía sigue sólida, el banco central puede tomarse el tiempo para observar lo que sucede antes de rebajar los tipos de interés.

Trump presionó por un recorte de tasas y criticó duramente a Powell.

Trump impuso en los últimos meses aranceles mínimos del 10% sobre la mayoría de productos que Estados Unidos importa y valores más altos a la importación de acero, aluminio y automóviles.

En mayo el índice de precios al consumidor fue de 2,4% interanual, frente al 2,3% de abril.

Los economistas esperan que tome varios meses para que los aranceles de Trump se reflejen en los precios al consumidor, y la Fed está procediendo con cautela.

Un indicador publicado el martes muestra que las ventas minoristas retrocedieron 0,9% en mayo.

La moderación de la inflación, de la que Trump se jacta, se debe en buena parte a la baja de los precios del petróleo.

El economista senior de KPMG, Benjamin Shoesmith, dijo que la Fed estaría recortando nuevamente sus tasas en este momento si no fuera por la incertidumbre relacionada con los aranceles y una reciente escalada de tensiones en Medio Oriente.

title: La Fed mantuvo las tasas de interés sin cambios y la previsión de dos recortes para el año
content: La Reserva Federal de Estados Unidos no cedió ante la presión del presidente Donald Trump y dejó sin cambios los tipos de interés en el rango de 4,25% al 4,50%.
resumen: La Reserva Federal (Fed) de Estados Unidos dejó sin cambios los tipos de interés en su rango actual del 4,25% al 4,50% y mantuvo la previsión de dos recortes para final de año.

title: Tariffs hit US economy forecast but the Fed unmoved by latest Trump threats with no change to interest rates
content: The US central bank has made no change to interest rates and warned the world's biggest economy will see less growth and higher inflation due to tariffs. The Federal Reserve, known as the Fed, held ...
resumen: The US central bank, the Fed, has made no change to interest rates and warned the world's biggest economy will see less growth and higher inflation due to tariffs. The Fed held rates despite President Donald Trump calling its chair, Jerome Powell, a "stupid person" on Wednesday. Mr. Trump appointed Mr. Powell in 2017. Mr. Trump has expressed anger towards the Fed chair at multiple points in the past for not bringing down borrowing costs through interest rate cuts. The tariff effect: Mr. Trump's signature economic policy of tariffs - taxes on imports - was again forecast to cause higher inflation and lower economic growth in the US. The Fed's predictions for inflation were upgraded to 3.1% for 2025 from 2.5% in December, while the outlook for US economic growth was downgraded to 1.4% from 2.1% in December. The Fed chair said the effect of those extra taxes on imports will take time to work its way through the system and show up in prices on shelves. The level of uncertainty peaked in April, when Mr. Trump announced many of his tariffs, and has since fallen, it remains elevated, Mr. Powell said. Many of the country-specific tariffs have been paused for 90 days, which is currently due to end on 8 July. The economy is in a "solid position", Mr. Powell said. Interest rates were kept at 4.25%-4.5%.

title: Fed leaves key rate unchanged as it awaits the impact of tariffs and Trump again scolds Powell
content: The Federal Reserve kept its key rate unchanged Wednesday as it waits for additional information on how tariffs and other potential disruptions will affect the economy this year.

title: Nicaragua fija en 50 kilómetros por hora la velocidad máxima permitida en sus carreteras
content: San José, 17 jun (EFE).- La Policía Nacional de Nicaragua fijó este martes en 50 kilómetros por hora (31,1 millas por hora) la velocidad máxima permitida para conductores en las carreteras de los 153 ...
resumen:
La Policía Nacional de Nicaragua fijó el martes 17 de junio de 2025 en 50 kilómetros por hora (31,1 millas por hora) la velocidad máxima permitida para conductores en las carreteras de los 153 municipios nicaragüenses.

La Policía nicaragüense impuso esos nuevos límites de velocidad por orientación del copresidente de Nicaragua, Daniel Ortega.

Las nuevas velocidades permitidas a conductores a partir del martes 17 de junio de 2025 son:
*   En carreteras, un máximo de 50 kilómetros por hora para los conductores de transporte privado o público de carga o pasajeros. Anteriormente era de 80 kilómetros por hora.
*   Para los vehículos particulares la velocidad máxima pasará de 100 kilómetros por hora a 50 kilómetros por hora.
*   Conductores de motocicletas, 40 kilómetros por hora.

Además, la Policía prohibió transportar a niños como pasajeros en motocicletas.

En 2024, los accidentes de tráfico se ubicaron entre las primeras 6 causas de defunción en el país centroamericano, de 6,8 millones de habitantes, con 1.392 fallecidos.

En 2023 un total de 623 personas murieron en las carreteras de Nicaragua, y 642 en 2022, según datos del Ministerio de Salud.

title: La economía hondureña crece 3,8 % en 2025 por consumo, servicios digitales y exportaciones
content: Tegucigalpa, 17 jun (EFE).- La economía de Honduras registró un crecimiento acumulado del 3,8 % entre enero y abril de 2025, impulsada por el dinamismo del consumo interno, el auge de los servicios di ...
resumen: La economía de Honduras registró un crecimiento acumulado del 3,8 % entre enero y abril de 2025, impulsada por el dinamismo del consumo interno, el auge de los servicios digitales y el repunte de las exportaciones, según el Banco Central de Honduras (BCH). El Índice Mensual de Actividad Económica (IMAE) reportó un «desempeño positivo» en el segundo bimestre. La variación interanual del IMAE fue del 1,8 %, mientras que la serie de tendencia del ciclo mostró en abril una variación positiva del 4,6 %. El IMAE mide los 17 principales sectores de la actividad económica. Las actividades que registraron mayor crecimiento fueron la intermediación financiera, seguros y fondos de pensiones (10,6 %); el transporte y almacenamiento (6 %); el correo y telecomunicaciones (4,7 %); la agricultura, ganadería, silvicultura y pesca (2,8 %), y el comercio (1,6 %). La industria manufacturera (maquila) registró una contracción del 0,1 %. La economía de Honduras creció en 2024 el 3,9 %. Se espera que el país centroamericano mantenga en 2025 un crecimiento entre el 3,5 y el 4,5 % y con una inflación proyectada entre el 4 y el 5 %.

Se esperan rachas de viento muy fuertes, caída de granizo y actividad eléctrica. La alerta rige desde la tarde de este domingo hasta la madrugada del lunes.

title: Trump and the Middle East Weigh on the Fed
content: Investors are anxious about whether the central bank will change course on rate cuts as geopolitical turmoil and tariffs pose inflation risks.
resumen:
On Wednesday, Jay Powell, the Fed chair, will likely face questions about the economic impact of conflict in the Middle East and how it might change the central bank’s forecasts about interest rates in the coming months.

The central bank is widely expected to hold interest rates steady on Wednesday. Markets will be watching closely the Fed’s rates forecast and Jay Powell’s news conference. High on the agenda will be questions about whether the Fed chair sees conflict in the Middle East and higher oil prices creating a new inflation risk that forces the central bank to keep rates higher for longer.

In March, the Fed signaled that it would lower its benchmark lending rate by half a percentage point this year.

Trump has repeatedly chided Powell for not cutting rates sooner, arguing that two full percentage points of cuts are warranted.

Moody’s cut America’s triple-A credit rating.

Nonpartisan congressional analysts estimate that the House version of Republicans’ huge policy bill would grow the national debt by $3.4 trillion.

The Israel-Iran conflict and Trump’s on-again-off-again tariff approach threaten to reignite inflation.

Bank of America forecasts that the Fed will make just one quarter-point cut this year.

Economists at Goldman Sachs see the Fed going with two cuts this year.

The futures market is pricing in two cuts on Wednesday.

Trump has said he plans to name a successor soon, even though Powell’s term as Fed chair doesn’t end until May.

Trump and Powell do not see eye to eye on the economy or on rates policy.

The Trump administration sends conflicting messages on immigration raids.

The Department of Homeland Security has reversed guidance exempting farms and hotels from raids.

A new poll showed that 42 percent of Americans oppose the legislation, while 23 percent support it.

The Senate passes a landmark crypto bill.

Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick talks up the “Trump Card.” A website promoting the proposed visa, which would cost $5 million and give foreigners a pathway to legal residency in the U.S., has racked up more than 68,000 registrations of interest.

With Elon Musk seemingly well and truly on the outs with President Trump, the fallout may be felt as far as Beijing.

Musk’s ties to China — where Tesla produces half its cars — were among the most glaring.

Musk’s efforts to spearhead cost cuts at the so-called Department of Government Efficiency were also troublesome.

DOGE cuts to agencies like the Labor Department and the Department of Homeland Security have hamstrung those agencies’ ability to monitor China’s business and trade dealings with Washington.

Beijing has a trump card with its lock on rare earth supplies, which are vital to Tesla and other American carmakers.

Sam Altman, OpenAI’s C.E.O., threw a jab at his company’s rival Meta.

Andy Jassy, Amazon’s C.E.O., told the tech and retail giant’s 1.5 million workers that he believes the “once-in-a-lifetime” technology will eventually lead to fewer of them working at the company.

Allison Kirkby, the C.E.O. of the British telecom BT, said that the technology could help her trim even more jobs and costs at the business. She has already announced plans to cut more than 40,000 positions and 3 billion pounds ($4 billion) in costs by the end of the decade.

Sebastian Siemiatkowski, the C.E.O. of the payments company Klarna, has long spoken about how A.I. is helping his business shed jobs.

Jensen Huang, the C.E.O. of Nvidia, said “some jobs will be obsolete” because of A.I.

Pope Leo XIV is making the technology and its potential threat to humanity a key focus of his papacy.

AXA is the top user of A.I. in the insurance industry, according to a new ranking by Evident.

Elon Musk’s xAI is said to be close to raising $9.3 billion in equity and debt from investors.

Democratic lawmakers are demanding information on the consulting firm Palantir’s more than $100 million worth of government contracts since Inauguration Day.

Chase is raising the annual fee for its Chase Sapphire Reserve card to $795.

title: Short deadline for Canada-U.S. talks helps to ‘concentrate the mind,’ Carney says
content: Mr. Carney’s comments capped a two-day summit that managed to avoid the kind of blow-up that marred the G7 meeting in Charlevoix, Que., in 2018, where Mr. Trump called then-prime-minister Justin ...
resumen:
Prime Minister Mark Carney, a day after setting a 30-day target for a landmark economic and security deal with Donald Trump, declined to explain why he selected the time frame, what kind of agreement could be achieved in that period or what would happen if the talks failed.

Mr. Carney told reporters at the conclusion of the Group of Seven leaders summit in Canada’s Rocky Mountains that a fixed date helps people focus.

Mr. Carney’s comments capped a two-day summit that managed to avoid the kind of blow-up that marred the G7 meeting in Charlevoix, Que., in 2018, where Mr. Trump called then-prime-minister Justin Trudeau “dishonest and weak.”

Several joint statements issued by the G7 leaders generated little in the way of new collaborative action on big issues, aside from closer co-operation on critical minerals and transnational repression.

And Canada’s efforts to demonstrate collective action on Russia’s war on Ukraine fell through.

As in 2018, Mr. Trump quit the 2025 summit early, disrupting plans by multiple world leaders to meet with him in Canada – and before the group could gather jointly with Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelensky.

The U.S. President used his brief time at the summit to lament Russia’s expulsion from the diplomatic forum.

Mr. Carney signalled Canada is looking closely at steel dumping as it negotiates a trade deal with the United States, an indication that Ottawa is prepared to respond to American concerns over the dumping of Chinese commodities on North American markets.

Mr. Carney did not mention China by name.

He described a “need to provide protections” against “third-country flows of steel – and mainly steel, but possibly aluminum – into Canada.”

Canadian negotiators have sought to allay Mr. Trump’s concerns as they push for the cancellation of all import taxes on Canadian goods, a stand in direct opposition to the U.S. President’s deep fondness for tariffs as a tool for raising revenue and boosting the prospects of domestic industry.

Mr. Carney acknowledged Tuesday, speaking at the close of the G7 summit, “That’s our position. And at present, the United States may have a slightly different position.”

An estimated 10 per cent of exported Chinese steel is transshipped through third countries, a trade worth roughly US$7-billion.

Canada has already placed a 25-per-cent tariff on Chinese steel.

Mr. Carney and the U.S. President on Monday agreed to accelerated negotiations with the aim of striking “within the coming 30 days” an economic and security deal that would end the Canada-U.S. trade war.

The commitment followed a 70-minute meeting between Mr. Carney and Mr. Trump at the start of the G7 summit.

Further Canada-U.S. talks are scheduled for later this week.

Mr. Trump, who told reporters this week he thought a deal with Canada was achievable, suggested that Canadians will end up paying tariffs even if the trade war is resolved.

Speaking to reporters on Air Force One as he headed home Monday, he again pitched the idea of Canada becoming the 51st state, saying if this country forgoes annexation, “they’re going to have to pay a lot of tariffs and things.”

Brian Clow, who served as deputy chief of staff to Mr. Trudeau, said he thinks the 30-day deal deadline is “aspirational” rather than a hard target.

Mr. Clow said the commitment to reach a deal within 30 days is a useful tactic to keep the United States engaged as Washington is busy negotiating with more than 15 other countries on their own deals.

The Wall Street Journal, citing an unidentified U.S. official, reported that Mr. Trump complained about Canada’s protectionism on dairy products during his talk with Mr. Carney in Kananaskis, Alta., saying its dairy industry was rigged against the U.S. because of high tariffs.

David Paterson, Ontario’s trade representative in Washington, said, “Officially everybody wants to get to zero tariffs, but we also have heard consistently from the U.S. administration that they’re wanting to maintain a degree of tariff on everybody. And that’s why we don’t have a deal yet.”

Scrapping Canada’s digital services tax is among U.S. demands in trade talks with Canada.

The 30-day negotiating window encompasses one important date: June 30, the deadline for companies to pay amounts owed under Canada’s digital services tax, a 3-per-cent charge on revenues collected by large multinational companies that is retroactive to Jan. 1, 2022.

The U.S. has fought the tax, saying it places an unfair burden on American companies and is filing a dispute under the U.S.-Mexico-Canada agreement.

In his conversation with reporters on Air Force One on Monday, Mr. Trump also said Canada will have to pay dearly to become part of the American ”Golden Dome” missile defence system.

He had earlier said the price of admission for Ottawa would be US$61-billion.

On Monday night, he said it would be US$71-billion.

On Monday, Canada’s ambassador to the U.S., Kirsten Hillman, said that Ottawa continues to argue that Mr. Trump should cut his import taxes to zero.

Canada has pursued a two-phase approach to trade talks with the U.S., hoping for an interim deal that can be followed by a broader discussion about new terms under the USMCA.

title: China's Bitcoin Mining Giants Forge U.S. Path Amid Trade Tensions
content: Chinese bitcoin mining equipment makers Bitmain, Canaan, and MicroBT are establishing manufacturing bases in the U.S. to circumvent tariff impacts from the recent U.S.-China trade war. This relocation ...
resumen: Chinese bitcoin mining equipment makers Bitmain, Canaan, and MicroBT are establishing manufacturing bases in the U.S. to circumvent tariff impacts from the recent U.S.-China trade war. This relocation aims to reduce cost-related tariffs while addressing U.S. security concerns regarding dependence on Chinese technology. The bitcoin mining sector, which could reach $12 billion by 2028, is undergoing changes not just to minimize costs but also to stimulate local competition. This restructuring aims to balance the geographic supply-demand mismatch and mitigate potential risks associated with heavy dependence on Chinese-made technology.

title: El puerco tuerce el rabo
content: Era tenso el ambiente aquella mañana en marzo de 2023. Alex Taylor, la subsecretaria de Comercio y Asuntos Agrícolas de Estados Unidos, estuvo sentada frente al presidente Cortizo. Le dijo: “No habrá ...
resumen:
El puerco forma parte de las carnes acordados dentro del TPC con Estados Unidos y Panamá.

En marzo de 2023, Alex Taylor, la subsecretaria de Comercio y Asuntos Agrícolas de Estados Unidos, le dijo al presidente Cortizo: “No habrá renegociación del Tratado de Promoción Comercial (TPC), entre ustedes y nosotros”.

Hace un mes, el ministro de Comercio inició la conformación de mesas técnicas previas a la instalación de una Comisión de Revisión Agrícola, según contempla el propio tratado.

Julio Moltó demuestra liderazgo.

El TPC incluyó una desgravación arancelaria para la carne de cerdo a 15 años: 6 de gracia y 9 de reducción progresiva. Los aranceles comenzaron a bajar en 2018 y serán eliminados en 2026.

Los representantes del gremio porcino aducen que el mercado panameño quedará “inundado” por la carne de cerdo estadounidense y denuncian que Estados Unidos ha incurrido en prácticas de competencia desleal para desplazarlos, al realizar dumping, vendiendo carne por debajo del costo real.

De octubre a diciembre de 2023 se vendieron $32 millones en exportaciones agrícolas totales a Estados Unidos. En el mismo período en 2024, fueron 43, un incremento del 34 %. De enero a marzo de 2024, se vendieron $23 millones. En el mismo período en 2025, fueron 32, un salto del 39 %.

El gremio porcino genera 40.000 empleos directos y 120.000 indirectos y afirman que el TPC los pone en alto riesgo.

Panamá tiene más consumidores que productores, y la existencia del tratado brinda a los primeros una libertad fundamental: elegir comprar o no los productos estadounidenses que importamos.

No se ha exportado ni una libra de carne de cerdo a los estadounidenses, porque no se ha alcanzado el estándar sanitario exigido.

En septiembre de 2024, el presidente fue recibido por Joe Biden.

En enero de 2025, durante su toma de posesión, Trump declaró su intención de “recuperar el Canal”.

Panamá decidió no renovar su adhesión al proyecto chino llamado la “Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta” (BRI).

Al no renovar la BRI, Panamá se distancia de China y refuerza su postura como aliado estratégico de Estados Unidos.

Estados Unidos puede colaborar para que Panamá complete los requisitos sanitarios exigidos y exportarles carne de cerdo. También pueden cooperar para retrasar, tanto como se pueda, las importaciones de su carne de cerdo, porque la economía nacional ya anda bastante tropezada y sería terrible afectar a 160.000 personas vinculadas a esa industria.

title: Beloved American toy company sends harsh message to workers
content: The reality may wind up somewhere in the middle, but for increasingly more workers the tariff fallout is already taking a toll. The toymaker Hasbro, one of the largest U.S. toy co ...
resumen: Hasbro, one of the largest U.S. toy companies, has announced it will lay off 150 workers in a cost-cutting move. Through May this year, over 696,000 people have been laid off, up 80% from last year. Hasbro is laying off workers as part of a restructuring to offset cost increases due to tariffs. The President enacted 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico in February, but the tariffs placed on China have dealt the biggest blow to the toy industry in 2025. In February, a 10% tariff was imposed on Chinese imports, which increased to 20% in March. In April, an additional 34% tariff was levied on China. In May, the tit-for-tat tariff tussle de-escalated to allow for trade negotiations. However, 30% tariffs remain on China, and coupled with tariffs enacted during Donald Trump’s first term, Chinese tariffs exceed 50%. According to S&P Global, Mattel and Hasbro source 50% and 40% of their toys from mainland China. Hasbro CEO Chris Cocks said in April, “Ultimately, tariffs translate into higher consumer prices, potential job losses as we adjust to absorb increased costs and reduced profits for our shareholders.” In Q1, Hasbro said tariff impacts would range between $100 million and $300 million in 2025, with most of the effects felt during the final two quarters of 2025. After accounting for efforts to offset tariffs, Hasbro expects them to ding profits by $60 million to $180 million. Hasbro plans to shave $1 billion in costs over the next few years, including via job cuts. Since 2023, Hasbro has reduced its headcount by 1,900 workers. The latest round of cuts involves 150 workers, or roughly 3% of Hasbro’s employees. The layoff decision comes after Hasbro’s consumer products revenue decreased 4% year over year to $398 million in the first quarter. The segment's adjusted operating loss totaled $31 million during the quarter. Magic: The Gathering saw sales soar 45% year over year in the quarter, and digital games. Net revenue in the first quarter was $887 million, up 17% from the prior year, while adjusted earnings per diluted share rose 70% to $1.04.

title: Chinese Pharma Firms Shift Strategies Amid US Trade Tensions
content: Amid escalating U.S.-China trade tensions, top Chinese drug research firms like WuXi AppTec and WuXi Biologics (HK:2269) are adjusting operations to mitigate supply chain risks. These companies are ...
resumen: Amid escalating U.S.-China trade tensions, top Chinese drug research firms like WuXi AppTec and WuXi Biologics (HK:2269) are adjusting operations to mitigate supply chain risks. These companies are stockpiling U.S. supplies, sourcing alternatives, and considering local testing options to maintain continuity in pharmaceutical development. China’s biotech sector, a key player in global drug R&D for companies like Pfizer (NYSE:PFE) and AstraZeneca (NASDAQ:AZN), traditionally relies on U.S. imports such as reagents and clinical samples. Recent tariff hikes and fears of restricted access are forcing firms to pause or reconsider new projects. Some companies, including Innovent Biologics and BeOne Medicines, are now exploring options to test U.S. clinical samples domestically rather than shipping them to China, which may significantly raise costs. According to industry sources, WuXi AppTec and its biotech clients have already swapped U.S.-made reagents for non-U.S. alternatives due to rising tariffs. WuXi Biologics reportedly placed unusually large orders with U.S. suppliers in April as a hedge against future trade policy shifts. JS Biosciences, a Chinese culture media maker, has received inquiries from at least 17 clients since April to stockpile local raw materials. Delays in importing critical components—such as culture media from Fujifilm’s U.S. unit—have already caused Chinese firms to withdraw from certain international contracts. Though U.S. and Chinese officials have signaled progress toward easing restrictions, uncertainties remain. Industry leaders like NeuExcell Therapeutics’ Chen Gong express growing concern about the unpredictable nature of future tariffs and how it may impact clinical trials and biotech investment. Over $1.4 billion in U.S. diagnostic and laboratory reagents were exported to China in 2024.

title: China weighs strategic impact, trade ties as US mulls military response in Iran
content: With limited leverage, Beijing may choose a muted response but will protect its economic interests in region, analysts say.
resumen: China probablemente se mantendrá cautelosa sobre intervenir en el conflicto en escalada entre Israel e Irán incluso si Estados Unidos se involucra militarmente, una perspectiva que traería resultados mixtos para Beijing, según observadores. La especulación sobre la intervención estadounidense ha crecido desde el viernes pasado, tras los ataques más intensos de Israel contra Irán en décadas. Washington ha enviado un portaaviones desde el Mar de China Meridional y desplegado un gran número de aviones de combate y cisterna a Oriente Medio. El presidente estadounidense Donald Trump también estaría considerando una acción militar para atacar las instalaciones nucleares de Irán. Recientemente exigió la "rendición incondicional" del líder supremo de Irán, el ayatolá Ali Khamenei, llamándolo un "objetivo fácil". El miércoles, el Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores de China expresó "serias preocupaciones" sobre el conflicto en escalada e instó a los países que tenían "influencia especial" sobre Israel - una aparente referencia a Estados Unidos - a desempeñar un "papel constructivo" para aliviar las tensiones. "[China] se opone a cualquier comportamiento que viole los propósitos y principios de la Carta de la ONU e infrinja la soberanía, la seguridad y la integridad territorial de otros países", dijo el portavoz del ministerio Guo Jiakun. "Una mayor escalada de las tensiones en Oriente Medio no es del interés de ninguna parte. Los países que tienen una influencia especial sobre Israel deberían, en particular, mantener una posición objetiva y justa y asumir sus debidas responsabilidades, y desempeñar un papel positivo y constructivo para aliviar la situación y prevenir el desbordamiento del conflicto". Beijing, que tiene estrechos lazos con Teherán, también ha dicho que está dispuesta a mediar en la paz entre Irán e Israel.

title: Así China se convirtió en el principal proveedor de mercancías de Colombia; Analdex presenta panorama
content: Según Analdex, hace falta una estrategia clara para llegar a los mercados asiáticos. China ya es el principal proveedor de Colombia.
resumen: Este año las empresas chinas seguramente serán las principales proveedoras de mercancía para Colombia. Las cifras reportadas al primer trimestre del año evidencian el crecimiento de los negocios con esta región. En marzo de 2025, en comparación con igual mes de 2024, las compras originarias en China representaron el 40,1 % de las importaciones y, en el primer trimestre, desplazaron el mercado de Estados Unidos, con el 26,3 % de participación. Javier Díaz, presidente de Analdex, comentó que esta tendencia se mantendrá este año y que evidencia un cambio en el comercio que los empresarios deben analizar. En el Foro Regional Impo-Expo, realizado por Analdex en Cali, el directivo dijo que para Colombia todos los mercados deben ser interesantes, pero aseguró que “deberíamos tener una mirada más profunda, no solo sobre China sino sobre Asia Pacífico. Negociamos un TLC con Corea, pero no le hemos aprovechado, porque no tenemos una estrategia comercial de cara a esa parte del mundo, que me parece es fundamental porque Asia es el motor de la economía mundial”. El año pasado 330 empresas nacionales vendieron en el mercado chino, mientras que 18.242 compañías importaron de ese territorio. Las ventas al país asiático sumaron US$2377 millones, mientras que las que se hicieron a EE.UU. llegaron a US$ 14.984 millones. Las importaciones de China, por parte de Colombia, se equipararon el año pasado frente a las estadounidenses.

title: Uruguay trabaja en la evacuación de su embajador y su cónsul en Irán
content: Montevideo, 17 jun (EFE).- Uruguay trabaja en la evacuación de su embajador en Teherán,Beraldo Nicola, y su cónsul en la capital de Irán, Alejandro Tomsich, tras cinco días de ataques de Israel a Irán ...
resumen:
Uruguay trabaja en la evacuación de su embajador en Teherán, Beraldo Nicola, y su cónsul en la capital de Irán, Alejandro Tomsich.
El Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores uruguayo confirmó que ambos aún se encuentran en Irán.
Uruguay no cerrará la Embajada, que continuará trabajando con personal local.
Israel llevó a cabo una ofensiva aérea de gran escala sobre Irán, denominada ‘operación León Creciente’, con 200 aviones que bombardearon un centenar de objetivos vinculados al programa nuclear iraní, incluyendo las instalaciones clave de Natanz, fábricas de misiles balísticos y centros de mando.
Irán lanzó un centenar de drones hacia Israel.
Israel e Irán intercambiaron nuevas oleadas de ataques aéreos en la quinta jornada desde que el Ejército israelí lanzó la operación a gran escala que ha causado más de 200 muertos y cientos de heridos, de acuerdo a las autoridades iraníes.
Irán hizo sonar las alarmas antiaéreas en el sur de Israel en el décimo ataque desde el viernes, el segundo de la jornada.
Los servicios de emergencia israelíes no han reportado daños o víctimas mortales, que hasta el momento ascienden a 24 desde el inicio de la ofensiva israelí.
Los bombardeos volvieron a retumbar en las calles de Teherán durante la madrugada y en horas de la tarde los proyectiles cayeron sin cesar durante media hora.
Se reportaron tres nuevas víctimas mortales en el centro de Irán, que elevarían el número total de muertos.

En Juárez ha disminuido en casi 10 mil personas la Población Económicamente Activa en el último año y medio.
Entre junio de 2023 y marzo de 2025, Ciudad Juárez ha perdido 65 mil 506 empleos en la industria manufacturera de exportación, lo que equivale a una pérdida mensual promedio de 2 mil 909 puestos laborales.
Podrían perderse más de 25 mil empleos adicionales para finales del año en curso.
Del tercer trimestre de 2023 al primer trimestre de 2025, la Población Económicamente Activa (PEA) en Juárez pasó de 782 mil 211 a 772 mil 448 personas; es decir, una disminución de 9 mil 763 individuos.
Si se suman todas las prestaciones que recibe un trabajador en Juárez, incluyendo transporte, uniformes, alimentos, el que menos gana, está percibiendo un salario integrado de alrededor de 800 pesos diarios.

title: Ishiba, Trump fail to reach pact on tariffs
content: On the sidelines of the G7 summit on Monday in Canada, Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba met US President Donald Trump for 30 minutes and urged a review of the tariffs imposed on Japan.
resumen:
Japan and the United States have yet to reach a tariff agreement, with key differences still unresolved.
On the sidelines of the G7 summit on Monday in Canada, Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba met US President Donald Trump for 30 minutes and urged a review of the tariffs imposed on Japan.
Ishiba said after the meeting that no comprehensive deal had been reached and declined to reveal specific points of disagreement.
This was the leaders' second in-person meeting since Ishiba visited Washington in February.
Ishiba reaffirmed Japan's intent to expand investment in the US, emphasizing the importance of a mutually beneficial relationship.
Trump made no commitment to easing tariffs on automobiles or other goods.
Currently, Japanese exports face 25 percent US tariffs on automobiles and parts, 50 percent on steel and aluminum, plus a 24 percent "reciprocal" tariff.
Despite six rounds of ministerial talks, the US remains reluctant to lift tariffs on automobiles — a key concern for Tokyo.
The US is Japan's largest car export market, and according to forecasts by Nomura Securities, the imposition of auto tariffs by the US could push Mazda into the red and slash Toyota's operating profit by about 30 percent.
Hidetoshi Tashiro, chief economist at Japanese consultancy Infinity LLC, warned that the earnings of Japanese automakers will deteriorate due to US tariff hikes, thereby affecting the Japanese economy.
Kazuyuki Hamada, an international political economist and Japan's former parliamentary vice-minister for foreign affairs, said: "With the Upper House election fast approaching, the Japanese government had hoped to secure at least a partial rollback of the 25 percent auto tariffs imposed by Trump. …However, the 30-minute meeting ended in disappointment, yielding only an agreement to continue ministerial-level talks."
Despite Ishiba's firm declaration that the auto industry is the very core of Japan's national interest and the government will use every means available to win concessions from the US, he failed to sway Trump's position.
Hamada also pointed out that Ryosei Akazawa, Japan's lead tariff negotiator, has visited the US six times in the past two months for talks with Trump administration officials.
Ishiba is scheduled to meet Trump again at the NATO summit on June 24.

title: China desata una nueva avalancha de exportaciones que está reconfigurando al mundo
content: A medida que los aranceles del presidente Trump cierran el mercado estadounidense, los productos chinos inundan países desde el Sudeste Asiático hasta Europa y Latinoamérica.
resumen:
China está experimentando una nueva avalancha de exportaciones que está reconfigurando el mundo. A medida que los aranceles del presidente Trump cierran el mercado estadounidense, los productos chinos inundan países desde el Sudeste Asiático hasta Europa y Latinoamérica.

Hace dos décadas, China conmocionó a Estados Unidos con su capacidad para fabricar y enviar cosas rápida y económicamente a una escala nunca vista, reconfigurando la economía y la política estadounidenses. Hoy, una nueva conmoción china se extiende por todo el mundo.

A medida que los aranceles del presidente Donald Trump comienzan a excluir a China de Estados Unidos, las fábricas chinas están enviando sus productos a otros países a un ritmo que está transformando las economías y la geopolítica.

En lo que va de año, el superávit comercial de China con el mundo es de casi US$500 mil millones, un aumento de más del 40% respecto al mismo periodo del año anterior.

La avalancha de exportaciones de China es consecuencia de la política gubernamental y de la desaceleración de la economía nacional. Pekín lleva varios años inyectando dinero en sus sectores manufactureros.

La cuota de mercado mundial de China en todas las categorías de bienes ha aumentado considerablemente, según un análisis de Fahy.

China ya ha aliviado el efecto económico de un desplome de la demanda de Estados Unidos al desviar el flujo de sus productos hacia el Sudeste Asiático, América Latina y Europa.

Trump amenaza con imponer fuertes aranceles a los mismos países que están siendo inundados por más productos chinos, como Vietnam, Camboya e Indonesia.

Algunos países se han beneficiado de un aumento de las inversiones de empresas extranjeras que intentan trasladar la producción desde China. Otros también han podido reenviar algunos productos chinos al exportarlos a Estados Unidos.

La crisis inmobiliaria de China empezó a repercutir en la economía en 2021. Los legisladores chinos no tardaron en desviar los préstamos baratos de los promotores a los exportadores y fabricantes.

China ya se había embarcado en una política industrial interna en 2015, conocida como Hecho en China 2025, para fabricar bienes de mayor valor.

China ha fabricado este año un 45 por ciento más de vehículos eléctricos que hace un año. Las exportaciones de vehículos eléctricos se han disparado un 64,6 por ciento este año, según la Asociación China de Fabricantes de Automóviles.

En Alemania, los envíos de productos chinos aumentaron el mes pasado un 20 por ciento respecto al año anterior.

En Indonesia, unas 250 mil personas perdieron su empleo en la industria de la confección en 2023 y 2024. Los fabricantes tailandeses de piezas de automóviles han cerrado debido a los vehículos eléctricos chinos. Los fabricantes de automóviles brasileños han pedido al gobierno que inicie una investigación antidumping sobre los automóviles chinos vendidos en el país.

title: The war signal heard 'round the world: Trump’s combat posture jolts global markets
content: Markets cracked under the weight of geopolitical gravity, tumbling as a storm of hard data misses and Middle East war drums smacked risk appetite into submission. What began as another jittery session ...
resumen: Markets tumbled due to geopolitical gravity and hard data misses, with President Trump's language ("We" are involved militarily) triggering a flight to safety. Equities fell, oil rose, and the dollar surged. S&P futures declined, and the Nasdaq led the downturn. Iran is reportedly ready to target U.S. regional bases if Trump greenlights strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities. The dollar saw its sharpest surge in six weeks. Treasuries rose, crude oil volatility spiked to a three-year high, and WTI neared $75. Gold struggled, while silver surged past $37, reaching its best level in 13 years. U.S. retail sales and industrial production printed ugly: -0.9% and -0.2% respectively. Traders are pricing in nearly two cuts this year, with October now the market’s favourite. The Bank of Japan held rates and deferred balance sheet tweaks until 2026. The Middle East is back at the epicentre of global market anxiety. When Trump dropped the royal “we” into comments about strikes on Iran, it was a volatility trigger. Retail sales down 0.9%. Industrial production, down 0.2%. The dollar went on a tear—clocking its biggest gain in six weeks. Treasury yields fell across the curve. Oil vol went full thermonuclear. USO out-traded XLE by notional volume. XLE and XOP were on fire. The Fed? 2026 expectations have quietly climbed—now up to 63bps from 40bps at the last FOMC. The Senate GOP lobbed a fresh legislative grenade—targeting deeper Medicaid cuts and slashing SALT deductions in Trump’s big-ticket bill. Trump is now demanding nothing short of Iran’s “unconditional surrender.”
