title: Behind Trump and Macron's war of words, G7 reveals deep Western divisions
content: From Iran to Ukraine to trade disputes, tensions have escalated between the American president and his fellow G7 leaders. Donald Trump said on Tuesday that Emmanuel Macron 'always gets it wrong' and ...
resumen:
Behind Trump and Macron's war of words, G7 reveals deep Western divisions.
From Iran to Ukraine to trade disputes, tensions have escalated between the American president and his fellow G7 leaders.
Donald Trump said on Tuesday that Emmanuel Macron 'always gets it wrong' and is 'publicity seeking.'.
Published today at 10:33 am (Paris), updated at 10:59 am.
French President Emmanuel Macron responded on Tuesday, June 17, during the second day of the G7 summit in Kananaskis, Canada, to the biting criticism directed at him the previous day by US President Donald Trump over a possible ceasefire between Israel and Iran.
Macron said, "There are leaders who change their minds; that is not my case,".
Macron added, "The ceasefire, it was mainly Trump who spoke about it," downplaying his counterpart's remark.
Macron explained, "A twist, not the first, nor the last," shortly before the G7 summit wrapped up.
After abruptly leaving the summit on Monday, the American president lashed out at his French counterpart on his Truth Social network: "Publicity seeking President Emmanuel Macron, of France, mistakenly said that I left the G7 Summit, in Canada, to go back to D.C. to work on a 'cease fire' between Israel and Iran. Wrong! (...) Whether purposely or not, Emmanuel always gets it wrong."
The exchange went well beyond the personal relationship between the two leaders.
It revealed a widening rift among Western allies over Israel's offensive in Iran, as the United States increasingly signalled toward a direct involvement in the war, including operational support to bomb underground nuclear facilities such as Fordo, and even support for regime change.
Back in Washington, President Trump called for Iran's "unconditional surrender" and threatened Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei.

title: US retail sales post biggest drop of 2025 as tariffs and economic worries bite
content: Amid warnings of a grim second half of the year, US retail sales fell 0.9%. The worse-than-expected decline coincided with decline in manufacturing and loss of home-buyer sentiment to lowest in three ...
resumen: US retail sales fell 0.9% in May, which was worse than the economists’ expectation of a 0.6% fall. This was the sharpest monthly decline in retail sales since January and the second consecutive decline after sales fell 0.1% in April. Industrial production fell 0.2% in May for the second time in three months. The 0.2% decline was more than 0.1% forecast by economists in a survey conducted by Wall Street Journal. The NAHB/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index fell to the lowest since 2022. Manufacturing rose 0.1% in May compared to 0.5% contraction the previous month on the back of a jump in automobile production. Excluding automobiles, manufacturing fell 0.3%. In May, vehicles and parts output increased 4.9%. Retail sales fell 0.3% excluding automobiles. This was worse than the estimate of 0.1%.

title: Trump’s tariffs are hurting US agriculture. Some farmers support them anyway.
content: Though there’s been plenty of backlash from the agricultural sector, Trump’s tariffs have also drawn support from a subset of farmers, who see them as a means of regaining an edge in an ...
resumen: Pepper Roberts, a farmer in Belzoni, Mississippi, supports the Trump administration’s tariffs on foreign goods, believing they will lead to better trade deals for U.S. producers. Roberts grows soybeans, cotton, corn, and other grains on a 6,250-acre farm. In January, Roberts sold corn at an inflated rate, which helped cover bills left over from last year and provided a financial buffer for the current growing season. President Donald Trump has enacted sweeping tariffs on imported goods, igniting trade disputes and disrupting global markets. A May survey of 400 U.S. producers found that 70% believe the tariffs will strengthen their industry in the long term. The same poll found that just 43% of respondents think the levies will hurt their earnings this year. China is a top destination for U.S. agricultural exports like soybeans. In 2023, agriculture exports collectively surpassed $57 billion in the 10 states bordering the Mississippi River. A federal court declared many of the president’s tariffs illegal in May. As of June 11, the U.S. and China have reportedly reached a tentative accord to deescalate their trade dispute. China has canceled mass shipments of American farm products. Brazil has dominated China’s soybean import market for more than a decade. In January 2020, Trump and China inked an agreement that called for China to purchase $80 billion in U.S. agricultural products through 2022. Cliff Heaton, a farmer in Clarksdale, Mississippi, has struggled to keep up with ballooning production costs on his 15,000-acre farm. On March 18, U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins announced that her agency would distribute up to $10 billion in subsidies to help farmers bounce back from 2024.

title: Brasil firma decreto para expandir acuerdo con Argentina sobre el comercio de vehículos
content: La mejora en las condiciones abarca el acceso al mercado para autobuses, furgonetas y camiones de hasta cinco toneladas.
resumen: El Presidente interino de Brasil, Geraldo Alckmin, firmó este martes un decreto que amplía el acuerdo automotor entre ese país y Argentina, flexibilizando las condiciones de acceso al mercado entre ambos países. La mejora en las condiciones abarca el acceso al mercado para autobuses, furgonetas y camiones de hasta cinco toneladas. El decreto además reanuda la reducción a cero de los aranceles de importación para autopartes no producidas en Brasil, aunque a cambio, las empresas que se acojan al beneficio deberán invertir el 2% del valor de las importaciones en investigación, innovación o programas industriales para el sector.

title: project44 rolls out AI tool focused on helping companies Improve supply chain decisions
content: The tool helps companies spot delays and take quick action—automatically rescheduling, rerouting, or notifying teams in real time.
resumen: Chicago-based supply chain visibility services provider project44 has launched a new tool called Decision Intelligence, a major update to its Movement platform that goes beyond tracking shipments. The idea is to help businesses not just see where things are, but actually decide what to do when something goes wrong—or better yet, before it does. The company says the tool can connect to systems like SAP and Oracle, then use artificial intelligence to spot delays, suggest fixes, and even carry them out automatically. “AI that doesn’t lead to action is just another dashboard,” said Jett McCandless, Founder and CEO of project44. “With Decision Intelligence, we’re giving companies the power to make smart decisions automatically—based on real-time data, not guesswork.”

title: Cumbre del G7 en Canadá no consigue limar las diferencias entre EEUU y la Unión Europea
content: (18 de junio del 2025. El Venezolano).- La Cumbre del G7 en Kananaskis (Canadá) concluyó el martes con importantes diferencias entre Estados Unidos y algunos de sus principales socios, especialmente ...
resumen: La Cumbre del G7 en Kananaskis (Canadá) concluyó el martes con importantes diferencias entre Estados Unidos y algunos de sus principales socios, especialmente la Unión Europea (UE), a raíz de su agresiva política comercial. El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, y el primer ministro británico, Keir Starmer, firmaron un acuerdo comercial mediante el cual el Reino Unido evitará determinados aranceles estadounidenses. Canadá y EEUU, acordaron acelerar sus negociaciones para tener listo un nuevo pacto en 30 días. La presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, anunció tras reunirse con Trump que los dos habían acordado también incrementar el ritmo negociador para llegar a un acuerdo antes del 9 de julio. Trump abandonó de forma inesperada Kananaskis en la noche del lunes por el conflicto armado entre Israel e Irán. A bordo del Air Force One de regreso a Washington, el presidente estadounidense lanzó nuevas amenazas contra Europa. Trump declaró: «Estamos hablando, pero no siento que lo que están ofreciendo sea todavía un acuerdo justo», antes de añadir: «O hacen un buen acuerdo o van a pagar lo que digamos que tienen que pagar». Von der Leyen reiteró el martes que las negociaciones prosiguen con avances. La presidenta de la Comisión Europea afirmó a preguntas de EFE que la reunión bilateral que mantuvo el lunes con Trump fue buena y dio a entender que las palabras del mandatario deben interpretarse en el marco de unas complejas negociaciones.

title: US and UK announce a trade deal, but steel imports are still being negotiated
content: U.S. President Donald Trump and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer said Monday that they had signed a trade deal that will slash tariffs on U.K. auto and aerospace industry imports — but they are ...
resumen: U.S. President Donald Trump and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer signed a trade deal that will slash tariffs on U.K. auto and aerospace industry imports, but they are still discussing how to handle steel production. The pair spoke to reporters at the Group of Seven summit in the Canadian Rockies. Trump said the pact is “a fair deal for both” and would “produce a lot of jobs, a lot of income.” Starmer said it meant “a very good day for both our countries, a real sign of strength.” The signing of the deal at the G7 followed Trump and Starmer’s announcement in May that they’d reached a framework for a trade pact that would slash U.S. import taxes on British cars, steel and aluminum in return for greater access to the British market for U.S. products, including beef and ethanol. Monday’s agreement fully covers only British cars and aerospace materials, with more work to come on steel. The new agreement removes U.S. tariffs on U.K. aerospace products, exempting Britain from a 10% levy. It also sets the tax on British autos at 10% from the end of the month, down from the current 27.5%, up to a quota of 100,000 vehicles a year. U.K. Business and Trade Secretary Jonathan Reynolds said the deal protects “jobs and livelihoods in some of our most vital sectors.” Mike Hawes, chief executive of Britain’s Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, said it was “great news for the U.K. automotive industry.” There was no final agreement to cut the tax on British steel to zero as originally foreseen. After the two leaders spoke, the White House released a statement saying that with respect to steel and aluminum, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick will “determine a quota of products that can enter the United States without being subject” to previous tariffs imposed by the Trump administration. The British government said Monday that the plan was still for “0% tariffs on core steel products as agreed.” Trump’s executive order authorizing the deal contained several references to security of supply chains, reflecting the U.S. administration’s concerns about China. There also was no final deal on pharmaceuticals, where “work will continue,” the U.K. said. The deal signed Monday also confirms that American farmers can export 13,000 metric tons (29 million pounds) of beef to the U.K. each year, and vice versa — though a British ban on hormone-treated beef remains in place.

title: La Legitimidad y Coherencia: pilares desmoronados de la estructura jurídica internacional
content: La estabilidad global no es un accidente, sino el resultado precario de una estructura jurídica internacional forjada tras dos guerras mundiales, cuyo ...
resumen:
El artículo aborda la erosión de la legitimidad y la coherencia en la estructura jurídica internacional, especialmente en el contexto de las tensiones entre Estados Unidos, Israel e Irán.

El discurso occidental, liderado por figuras como Donald Trump y Benjamin Netanyahu, es criticado por su retórica belicista y amenazas contra Irán, así como por aplicar un doble rasero en comparación con Israel, que posee un arsenal nuclear no declarado y enfrenta acusaciones de genocidio.

Se señala la hipocresía en la condena a Irán mientras se permite la impunidad a Israel, y se critica el intervencionismo de potencias como Estados Unidos en asuntos internos de otras naciones.

El artículo destaca la importancia de la verdad y la rendición de cuentas, mencionando el papel de Julian Assange y WikiLeaks.

Se argumenta que la estabilidad mundial depende de la coherencia legal y la justicia, y se critica la obsolescencia de la ONU, proponiendo una reestructuración y reforma.

Se proponen medidas para restaurar la legitimidad, como la no tolerancia a la violación de la soberanía, la rendición de cuentas universal, el desarme equitativo y el respeto a la vida civil.

Se sugiere que un orden mundial multipolar, con un Sur Global unificado y fuerte, podría ofrecer una alternativa a la impunidad y el matonaje.

El artículo es de Claudia Aranda, periodista de Pressenza.

title: Exportadores internacionales se alejan del dólar: Empresas prefieren negociar en monedas alternativas, según US Bank
content: 18-06-25.-Paula Comings, directora de ventas de divisas de US Bancorp (USB), ha detectado un cambio notable en sus conversaciones con importadores estadounidenses: cada vez con mayor frecuencia, ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Joe Biden, anunció un nuevo plan para abordar la crisis de vivienda asequible en el país. El plan, que se basa en tres pilares principales, busca aumentar la oferta de viviendas, reducir los costos de construcción y proteger a los inquilinos y propietarios.

En primer lugar, el plan propone invertir 150 mil millones de dólares en la construcción y rehabilitación de viviendas asequibles. Esta inversión se destinará a proyectos en todo el país, con un enfoque especial en las comunidades de bajos ingresos y las zonas rurales.

En segundo lugar, el plan incluye medidas para reducir los costos de construcción. Esto incluye la simplificación de los procesos de aprobación de proyectos, la eliminación de regulaciones innecesarias y la promoción de nuevas tecnologías de construcción.

En tercer lugar, el plan busca proteger a los inquilinos y propietarios. Esto incluye la implementación de nuevas leyes para prevenir los desalojos injustos, la expansión de los programas de asistencia para el alquiler y la creación de un fondo para ayudar a los propietarios a realizar mejoras en sus propiedades.

El presidente Biden afirmó que este plan es un paso crucial para garantizar que todos los estadounidenses tengan acceso a una vivienda segura y asequible. El plan se implementará en los próximos cinco años y se espera que tenga un impacto significativo en la crisis de vivienda en el país.

title: US Fed Meet Highlights: Jerome Powell-led FOMC keeps interest rates steady at 4.25%-4.50%, sees 50 bps rate cut in 2025
content: The US Fed's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) decided to keep the benchmark interest rates unchanged at 4.25% to 4.5% due to the diminished yet still elevated US economic uncertainty.
resumen:
The US Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), led by Chairman Jerome Powell, decided to keep the benchmark interest rates unchanged at 4.25% to 4.5% on June 18, 2025. The US Fed's ‘dot plot’ chart projections show that the median of Fed officials expect to lower the key benchmark interest rates by 50 basis points (bps), or 0.50%, in 2025. The officials have revised their 2026 outlook to only 25 bps of rate cuts. The US Federal Reserve has kept its key benchmark interest rates unchanged at 4.25%-4.50% since December 2024. Fed Chair Jerome Powell said inflation in goods prices is expected to accelerate over the summer due to President Donald Trump’s tariffs.

Key highlights from the Fed’s June policy:
- Dot plot shows wide dispersion on the matrix with outlook of Fed Fund rate around 3.4% in 2027
- 7 officials want no rate cut in 2025 up from 4 officials from last meeting.
- Inflation remains somewhat elevated.
- Economic projection pointed further stagflationary pressures.
- Forecast lower GDP of 1.4% down 0.3% from March meeting.
- Fed forecast Fed Rate to be 3.9% at the end of 2025, expecting two rate cuts
- Lowers 2025 growth to 1.4% and increased inflation expectations to 3%
- Forecast unemployment rate at 4.5% in 2025 and 2026
- Core PCE projected at 3.1%, 0.3% point higher in by end of 2025
- Unemployment outlook up to 4.5% or 0.1% higher from March and 0.3% higher than the current levels.

Jerome Powell said the unemployment rate has been ‘solid’ and ‘low’ at 4.2%. The US Federal Reserve highlighted that US inflation remains somewhat at an ‘elevated level’. The US Federal Reserve kept benchmark interest rates ‘unchanged’ at 4.25% to 4.5%.

title: UK Growth Forecast Cut Amid Trump Tariffs and Rising Labour Costs
content: Britains economic growth outlook has been revised downward by the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), citing rising payroll taxes and U.S. tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump. The CBI now ...
resumen: Britain’s economic growth outlook has been revised downward by the Confederation of British Industry (CBI). The CBI expects UK GDP to grow just 1.2% in 2025, down from its previous 1.6% forecast, with 2026 growth lowered to 1.0% from 1.5%. Key factors behind the downgrade include higher labour costs driven by April’s minimum wage hike and increased social security contributions. Though the UK is the only major economy with a trade deal aimed at exempting it from Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs, a 10% levy on other goods still applies. The Bank of England estimates that U.S. tariffs could reduce UK output by 0.3% over three years. April's economic contraction was also attributed to the end of a tax break on property sales, alongside market uncertainty sparked by Trump’s April 2 tariff announcement. The Bank of England is projected to lower rates gradually, with a target of 3.5% by late 2025, down from the current 4.25%. Inflation is forecast to stay above the BoE’s target through 2025, before easing to 2.5% in 2026. The CBI noted that Chancellor Rachel Reeves’ recent Spending Review will have limited short-term economic impact.

title: Sheinbaum proposes ‘general agreement’ with Trump after G7 return: Wednesday’s mañanera recapped
content: Sheinbaum said on Wednesday that she is seeking to establish a general U.S.-Mexico agreement on security, migration and trade.
resumen: Claudia Sheinbaum appeared before reporters at the National Palace in Mexico City after attending the G7 Summit in Canada. She said she had a telephone call with U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday afternoon. They agreed to work together to soon reach an agreement on various issues. Trump apologized for not being able to attend the scheduled bilateral meeting in Canada and asked if she could visit Washington, D.C., on her way back to Mexico. Sheinbaum proposed a "general agreement" with Trump, covering security, migration, and trade. She also mentioned the importance of recognizing Mexicans in the United States. Trump agreed to the general agreement. Economy Minister Marcelo Ebrard will travel to Washington to meet with U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick to discuss trade issues. Sheinbaum had a brief conversation with UN Secretary-General António Guterres. She said other world leaders at the G7 Summit spoke well of Mexico. Sheinbaum flew to Canada with Air Canada. She responded to criticism of her taking commercial flights. She disagreed with the "misogynist" interpretation of Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva's greeting.

title: Steelmaker Ternium pushes for stronger USMCA trade pact in face of tariffs
content: Ternium , a steelmaker with a massive Mexico business, on Wednesday pushed for stronger terms of a regional trade agreement ahead of a pending review, despite current headwinds from steel tariffs ...
resumen:
Ternium, a steelmaker with a massive Mexico business, on Wednesday pushed for stronger terms of a regional trade agreement ahead of a pending review, despite current headwinds from steel tariffs imposed by the government of U.S. President Donald Trump.

Shipments from Mexico to the U.S. under the U.S.-Mexico-Canada (USMCA) trade agreement are currently exempt from tariffs, though steel products face a whopping 50% tariff.

The U.S. and Mexico are negotiating a deal to reduce or eliminate the steel tariffs on imports up to a certain volume, Reuters reported last week.

The USMCA deal is up for review next year, though some officials believe it may come sooner. In a presentation to analysts in New York on Wednesday, Ternium pushed for stronger "rules of origin" as part of the review to protect the region against what it called unfair trade.

Steelmakers have accused China of engaging in a practice known as dumping, in which they sell their product abroad below market value. Products can be shipped through another country before reaching their final destination, often making their origin unclear.

"While management acknowledges the adverse effects on the global economy, they view the U.S. (tariffs) as beneficial for long-term globalization," analysts at J.P. Morgan said in a note to clients.

The U.S. shipped 2.28 million metric tons more of steel to Mexico than Mexico shipped to the U.S. in 2024, Ternium said, though the U.S. government has previously accused Mexico of flooding its domestic market with steel.

Ternium is looking to boost its market share in Mexico's local market in the coming years, management said. In Brazil, it said Chinese imports continue to pressure the market.

Ternium could also acquire the remaining shares it does not currently hold in Brazil's Usiminas (USIM5.SA), the J.P. Morgan analysts said, though it is not a priority at the moment.

title: Mexico-Canada relations take center stage during Sheinbaum’s G7 visit
content: During a busy day at the G7 in Canada, Sheinbaum held meetings with several leaders, including the prime ministers of Canada and India.
resumen:
President Claudia Sheinbaum proposed a “Summit for Economic Well-Being” and delivered a defense of Mexicans in the United States during an address to the G7 Summit in Canada on Tuesday.

She held bilateral talks with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

She said it is the “shared responsibility of all nations” to guarantee economic well-being and cooperate for development.

She told reporters at her Wednesday morning press conference in Mexico City that “Mexico is very well received.”

She was accompanied at the G7 Summit by Foreign Affairs Minister Juan Ramón de la Fuente, Economy Minister Marcelo Ebrard, Security Minister Omar García Harfuch and other officials.

She proposed that the summit bring together the G7 countries, the nations that attended this year’s event in Kananaskis as guests, members of the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC) and other “interested countries.”

The aim of the summit would be to “strengthen effective cooperation for development [and] for fair and reciprocal trade, as the basis for lasting peace that the whole world longs for.”

“All citizens from all countries must have the possibility of a life with well-being,” the president told fellow world leaders.

She said that the proposed CELAC summit could be broadened in scope by inviting G7 members and other countries.

She also spoke about Mexico’s commitment to peace.

She asserted that “it’s fundamental to recognize the people and families who have migrated out of necessity and who contribute significantly to the economies of the countries that receive them,” including the “hardworking and honest” Mexicans in the United States.

She gave an impassioned defense of Mexican immigrants in the United States.

She said that they “don’t deserve discrimination, but rather respect and recognition.”

The ultimate goal is that people have well-paid employment and access to an honorable life in their places of origin.

The Mexican president delivered her address to G7 leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron and United Kingdom Prime Minister Keir Starmer.

Trump left the G7 Summit on Monday to attend to the conflict between Israel and Iran, scuttling plans for a bilateral meeting with Sheinbaum on Tuesday.

She told reporters on Wednesday morning that she had a “very important meeting” with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney on Tuesday.

She said that they agreed to continue working together for the USMCA trade agreement, and to further strengthen the trade, cultural and educational relations between Mexico and Canada and the investment of Canadian companies in Mexico.

She added that they spoke about the agreement so that Mexican workers can go to work in Canada, mainly agricultural workers.

She told the prime minister that Mexico “very much values” its relationship with Canada.

She noted that “a lot of Mexicans also live in Canada” and thanked Carney for the invitation to the G7 Summit.

She gifted the Canadian prime minister a soccer ball made by members of the Wixárika community in Mexico.

Carney said that the “enduring value of the president’s leadership” was “immediately clear.”

Carney also highlighted the “importance of Mexico being at the center of international cooperation.”

Both Sheinbaum and Carney said they supported the idea of holding a trilateral meeting that included Trump.

Sheinbaum also held bilateral meetings on Tuesday with Prime Minister Modi of India, German Chancellor Friedrich Merz, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, European Council President António Costa and South Korean President Lee Jae-myung.

She said that she had a “very good meeting” with Modi.

She said that they spoke about the importance of strengthening economic ties between India and Mexico, particularly in some sectors like the pharmaceutical industry and the technological industry.

She said that she proposed to Modi the establishment of “investment agreements” between Mexico and India.

Modi said that he congratulated Sheinbaum on her “historic electoral victory” in 2024.

He wrote that they both see an immense potential for the ties between India and Mexico to strengthen even more in the future, especially in sectors like agriculture, semiconductors, critical minerals, health care, among others.

Sheinbaum said on social media on Tuesday that she spoke to von der Leyen and Costa about “the update of our trade agreement” with the European Union.

The European Commission president said in a social media post directed to Sheinbaum that “Mexico is a key partner for Europe.”

Sheinbaum said she spoke to Merz about the “strategic relationship” between Mexico and Germany as well as “opportunities for economic cooperation.”

She said that her discussion with the recently elected president of South Korea focused on “bringing our countries closer and enriching ties between our peoples.”

She missed out on the opportunity to meet Trump face-to-face for the first time, but did speak to the U.S. president by telephone on Tuesday.

She said on social media that they “agreed to work together to soon reach an agreement on various issues that concern us today,” among which are U.S. tariffs on imports from Mexico and Mexico’s opposition to the proposed remittances tax in the United States.

At the G7, Sheinbaum appeared between French President Macron and Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in an official leaders’ photo.

The leaders of Italy, Japan, Ukraine, Brazil and South Africa were also at the event, as was United Nations Secretary General António Guterres, among other dignitaries.

title: Trump afirma que Unión Europea no ofrece un ‘acuerdo justo’ sobre aranceles
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, afirmó que la Unión Europea todavía no ha ofrecido un “acuerdo justo” en las negociaciones comerciales con Washington.
resumen: Donald Trump afirmó este martes que la Unión Europea (UE) todavía no ha ofrecido un “acuerdo justo” en las negociaciones comerciales con Washington. El republicano ha anunciado aranceles aduaneros generalizados tanto a socios como adversarios, aunque aplazó su implementación hasta el 9 de julio. Trump también impuso aranceles adicionales al sector automovilístico, al acero y el aluminio, lo que ha impactado a varios de los socios comerciales de Estados Unidos, incluida la UE. Trump dijo a periodistas a bordo del avión presidencial Air Force One al regresar de la cumbre del G7 Canadá: “Estamos dialogando, pero todavía no siento que estén ofreciendo un acuerdo justo”. “Y haremos un buen trato o simplemente pagarán lo que nosotros digamos que paguen”, añadió el mandatario. Trump abandonó prematuramente el encuentro de líderes debido al conflicto entre Israel e Irán. Trump se reunió brevemente con la presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, que describió el encuentro como una “discusión buena e intensa”. Las negociaciones con Estados Unidos están en marcha, incluso este martes al margen del G7, y ambas partes están trabajando intensamente para lograr un acuerdo antes de que entren en vigor los aranceles en julio. El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, permanece en la cumbre encabezando las negociaciones con los otros países del G7. La jefa de la Comisión Europea añadió que una solución negociada es su solución favorita, aunque advirtió que el bloque está listo para tomar medidas de represalia si se rompe el diálogo.

title: Trump Grows Pissed at Tulsi Gabbard as Israel-Iran Conflict Worsens
content: President Trump is reportedly furious with Tulsi Gabbard after the director of national intelligence posted a professionally produced, three-minute long X video last week referencing past nuclear ...
resumen: President Trump is reportedly furious with Tulsi Gabbard after the director of national intelligence posted a professionally produced, three-minute long X video referencing past nuclear disasters. Gabbard’s post seems like a clear rebuke of U.S. support for Israel’s war on Iran. In the video, Gabbard says, "As we stand here today, closer to the brink of nuclear annihilation than ever before, political elite warmongers are carelessly fomenting fear and tensions between nuclear powers." Trump stated on Tuesday when asked about Gabbard’s video on Air Force One, “I don’t care what she said. I think they were very close to having a weapon.” A senior administration official told Politico that the video made Trump not super hot on her and he doesn’t like it when people are off message.

title: US can't reverse re-globalization trend
content: Having enjoyed more than three decades of the unrivalled global hegemony since the end of the Cold War, the US now finds itself challenged by China's rising technological prowess, industrial scale and ...
resumen: The US and China are engaged in high-stakes bilateral trade negotiations. The broader implications for global trade lie in the shifts away from multilateralism and US dollar hegemony, and toward a new, multipolar global trade architecture. The US is experiencing growing anxiety over its relative decentering. The US has been increasingly dismissing multilateral institutions in favor of "deal-making" with individual countries. The US administration tried to simultaneously increase domestic manufacturing output and maintain the dollar's status as the global reserve currency. The hollowing out of US manufacturing was never principally a result of trade agreements, but a symptom of a deeper reorientation of US capital. The US still manufactures products such as high-end equipment and advanced electronics, but their production is capital-intensive, not labor-intensive. The rest of the world is adapting to the US' contradictions. Some emerging economies are accelerating trade settlements in their national currencies and exploring alternative clearing mechanisms. ASEAN member states are reducing their reliance on the dollar in regional trade, particularly with China, Japan and the Republic of Korea. The demand for the dollar as a trade settlement medium is gradually diminishing, which the European Central Bank sees as an opportunity for the euro to play a more prominent role in global trade. The new globalization that is emerging is multipolar in character, regional in structure and decentralized in operations. Institutions such as the World Trade Organization will likely persist. The US' retreat from multilateralism poses risks but also creates new space for many countries, especially in the Global South. The growing importance of South-South trade is reducing the Global South's dependence on Western markets and institutions, with the Belt and Road Initiative creating corridors of trade and production. The US remains a major consumer market, responsible for about 14 percent of global imports. The Sino-US trade tango should not be seen as the primary determinant of the future of global trade, but a mirror of the broader historical shift: from unipolarism to multipolarism, from dollar dominance to currency diversification, from multilateralism to mosaic regionalism. The world isn't de-globalizing; it is re-globalizing on new terms and under new rules. The author is an adviser to former Australian prime minister Kevin Rudd, adjunct professor at Queensland University of Technology and a senior research fellow at Taihe Institute.

title: Trump’s Envoy to China Calls Out Threat of Foreign Supply Chains
content: The US wants to revamp its trading relationship with China and the world by bringing many critical supply chains back onshore, the American ambassador to Beijing said.
